question: While the defendant was in jail on a pending charge, his landlord called the police because rent had not been paid and because he detected a disagreeable odor coming from the defendant's apartment into the hallways. The police officer who responded to the call knew that the defendant was in jail. He recognized the stench coming from the defendant's apartment as that of decomposing flesh and, without waiting to obtain a warrant and using the landlord's passkey, entered the apartment with the landlord's consent. The lease to these premises gave the landlord a right of entry, at any reasonable hour, for the purpose of making repairs. The police officer found a large trunk in the bedroom which seemed to be the source of the odor. Upon breaking it open, he found the remains of the defendant's former mistress. The landlord's consent to the police officer's search of the defendant's apartment is

options.optionA: A. a waiver of the defendant's Fourth Amendment rights, because a landlord has implied consent to enter a tenant's apartment.
options.optionB: B. a waiver of the defendant's Fourth Amendment rights, because the lease gave the landlord express authority to enter the premises.
options.optionC: C. not a waiver of the defendant's Fourth Amendment rights, because the landlord lacked probable cause to believe a crime was then in the process of commission.
options.optionD: D. not a waiver of the defendant's fourth Amendment rights, because the landlord had neither actual nor apparent authority to permit the entry.

explanation.Legal_Concept: Waiver of Fourth Amendment rights by a third party, specifically a landlord's authority to consent to a police search of a tenant's premises.
explanation.Fact_Analysis: The landlord, with knowledge of the defendant's incarceration, entered the defendant's apartment with a police officer using a passkey, citing a lease provision allowing entry for repairs. The police officer found a trunk containing human remains, prompting the question of whether the landlord's consent was sufficient to waive the defendant's Fourth Amendment rights.
explanation.Rule_Application: A third party, such as a landlord, can only waive a tenant's Fourth Amendment rights if they have actual or apparent authority to do so. The lease provision in this case only granted the landlord limited rights of entry for repairs, not a general authority to control the premises or permit police searches.
explanation.Legal_Conclusion: Given that the landlord lacked actual or apparent authority to permit the entry, their consent did not waive the defendant's Fourth Amendment rights. Therefore, the correct answer is that the landlord's consent was not a waiver of the defendant's Fourth Amendment rights, supporting option D.

question: Two bullies hated a bartender and agreed to start a fight with the bartender and, if the opportunity arose, to kill him. The two bullies met the bartender in the street outside his bar and began to push him around. Three men who also hated the bartender stopped to watch. One of the men threw one of the bullies a knife. A second man told the bully, "Kill him." The third man, who made no move and said nothing, hoped that the bully would kill the bartender with the knife. One bully held the bartender while the other bully stabbed and killed him. On a charge of murdering the bartender, the man who said "Kill him" to one of the bullies is

options.optionA: A. not guilty, because his words did not create a "clear and present danger" not already existing.
options.optionB: B. not guilty, because mere presence and oral encouragement, whether or not he has the requisite intent, will not make him guilty as an accomplice.
options.optionC: C. guilty, because with intent to have the bully kill the bartender, he shouted encouragement to the bully.
options.optionD: D. guilty, because he aided and abetted the murder through his mere presence plus his intent to see the bartender killed.

explanation.Legal_Concept: Aiding and abetting in criminal law, specifically the requirements for liability as an accomplice to a crime.
explanation.Fact_Analysis: A man verbally encouraged a bully to kill a bartender by saying 'Kill him' while the bully was in the process of attacking the bartender. The bully then stabbed and killed the bartender.
explanation.Rule_Application: To be held criminally liable as an accomplice, an individual must have the intent that the crime be committed and must aid or abet in its commission. Verbal encouragement can constitute sufficient aiding if it is intended to facilitate the crime.
explanation.Legal_Conclusion: Given that the man had the requisite intent for the bartender's murder and provided verbal encouragement to the bully, which aided in the commission of the crime, he should be found guilty of murder as an accomplice, supporting option C.

question: Two bullies hated a bartender and agreed to start a fight with the bartender and, if the opportunity arose, to kill him. The two bullies met the bartender in the street outside a bar and began to push him around. Three men who also hated the bartender stopped to watch. One of the men threw one of the bullies a knife. A second man told the bully, "Kill him." The third man, who made no move and said nothing, hoped that the bully would kill the bartender with the knife. One bully held the bartender while the other bully stabbed and killed him. On a charge of murdering the bartender, the third man who made no move and said nothing is

options.optionA: A. not guilty, because mere presence, coupled with silent approval and intent, is not sufficient.
options.optionB: B. not guilty, because he did not tell the bully ahead of time that he hoped the bully would murder the bartender.
options.optionC: C. guilty, because he had a duty to stop the killing and made no attempt to do so.
options.optionD: D. guilty, because he was present and approved of what occurred.

explanation.Legal_Concept: Criminal liability for the actions of another, specifically the requirements for actus reus in accomplice liability.
explanation.Fact_Analysis: The third man was present at the scene where two bullies attacked and killed the bartender, and he silently approved of and hoped for the bartender's death. However, he made no move and said nothing to encourage or aid the bullies.
explanation.Rule_Application: To be criminally liable as an accomplice, a person must provide some form of aid or encouragement to the principal actor. Mere presence, even when combined with silent approval and intent, does not meet the actus reus requirement for accomplice liability.
explanation.Legal_Conclusion: Given that the third man's actions consisted solely of being present and silently approving of the crime, without any overt act of aid or encouragement, he should be found not guilty of murdering the bartender, supporting option A.

question: This question describes an offense. Select from the choices (A-D) the most serious offense of which the defendant could be properly convicted. The defendant, an avid fan of his home town football team, shot at the leg of a star player for a rival team, intending to injure his leg enough to hospitalize him for a few weeks, but not to kill him. The victim died of loss of blood.

options.optionA: A. Involuntary manslaughter
options.optionB: B. Voluntary manslaughter
options.optionC: C. Murder
options.optionD: D. None of the above

explanation.Legal_Concept: Murder at common law, specifically the concept of malice aforethought and its implications for criminal liability.
explanation.Fact_Analysis: The defendant intentionally shot at the leg of a rival football team's star player, intending to cause injury severe enough to hospitalize him for a few weeks, but not to kill him. However, the victim died due to loss of blood.
explanation.Rule_Application: Murder is defined as the unlawful killing of another with malice aforethought. Malice aforethought can be established through intent to kill, intent to inflict great bodily harm, or actions demonstrating gross recklessness toward human life. In this case, the defendant's intent to inflict great bodily harm (hospitalizing the victim) constitutes malice aforethought, even though he did not intend to kill.
explanation.Legal_Conclusion: Given the defendant's actions were done with malice aforethought, as evidenced by his intent to cause significant harm, the most serious offense for which he could be properly convicted is murder, supporting option C.

question: This question describes an offense. Select from the choices (A-D) the most serious offense of which the defendant could be properly convicted. The defendant, a worker in a metal working shop, had long been teasing a young colleague by calling him insulting names and ridiculing him. One day the colleague responded to the teasing by picking up a metal bar and attacking the defendant. The defendant could have escaped from the shop. He parried the blow with his left arm, and with his right hand struck the colleague on his jaw from which the young man died.

options.optionA: A. Involuntary manslaughter
options.optionB: B. Voluntary manslaughter
options.optionC: C. Murder
options.optionD: D. None of the above

explanation.Legal_Concept: Self-defense in criminal law, particularly the justification of using force in response to an imminent threat of harm.
explanation.Fact_Analysis: The defendant was being attacked by a colleague with a metal bar after a history of verbal teasing. The defendant parried the blow with one arm and struck the colleague on the jaw with the other, resulting in the colleague's death.
explanation.Rule_Application: A person can claim self-defense if the action taken is reasonably necessary to prevent imminent harm from the use of unlawful force. The force used must be reasonable in light of the threat posed. In this case, the defendant's use of force was reasonable given the colleague's attack with a metal bar.
explanation.Legal_Conclusion: Given that the defendant was acting in self-defense and used reasonable force in response to an imminent threat, he should not be convicted of any offense. Therefore, the correct answer is D, None of the above.

question: The plaintiff took a diamond ring to a pawnshop and borrowed $20 on it. It was agreed that the loan was to be repaid within 60 days and if it was not, the pawnshop owner, the defendant, could sell the ring. A week before expiration of the 60 days, the defendant had an opportunity to sell the ring to a customer for $125. He did so, thinking it unlikely that the plaintiff would repay the loan and if he did, the defendant would be able to handle him somehow, even by paying him for the ring if necessary. Two days later, the plaintiff came in with the money to reclaim his ring. The defendant told him that it had been stolen when his shop was burglarized one night and that therefore he was not responsible for its loss: Larceny, embezzlement, and false pretenses are separate crimes in the jurisdiction. It is most likely that the defendant has committed which of the following crimes?

options.optionA: A. Larceny
options.optionB: B. Embezzlement
options.optionC: C. Larceny by trick
options.optionD: D. Obtaining by false pretenses

explanation.Legal_Concept: Embezzlement in the context of property law, specifically the fraudulent conversion of another's property by someone with lawful possession.
explanation.Fact_Analysis: The defendant, with lawful possession of the plaintiff's diamond ring as a pawnshop owner, sold the ring before the agreed 60-day period expired and then lied to the plaintiff about the ring being stolen, indicating an intent to permanently deprive the plaintiff of the property.
explanation.Rule_Application: Embezzlement occurs when someone with lawful possession of another's property fraudulently converts that property. In this scenario, the defendant had lawful possession of the ring as part of the pawn agreement but then sold it without the plaintiff's consent and lied about its disposition, fitting the definition of embezzlement.
explanation.Legal_Conclusion: Given the defendant's actions of selling the ring without the plaintiff's consent and then deceiving the plaintiff about the ring's fate, the defendant has committed embezzlement, making option B the correct answer.

question: The plaintiff took a diamond ring to a pawnshop and borrowed $20 on it. It was agreed that the loan was to be repaid within 60 days and if it was not, the pawnshop owner, the defendant, could sell the ring. A week before expiration of the 60 days, the defendant had an opportunity to sell the ring to a customer for $125. He did so, thinking it unlikely that the plaintiff would repay the loan and if he did, the defendant would be able to handle him somehow, even by paying him for the ring if necessary. Two days later, the plaintiff came in with the money to reclaim his ring. The defendant told him that it had been stolen when his shop was burglarized one night and that therefore he was not responsible for its loss. Larceny, embezzlement, and false pretenses are separate crimes in the jurisdiction. Suppose that instead of denying liability, the defendant told the plaintiff the truth--that he sold the ring because he thought the plaintiff would not reclaim it--and offered to give the plaintiff $125. The plaintiff demanded his ring. The defendant said, "Look buddy, that's what I got for it and it's more than it's worth." The plaintiff reluctantly took the money. The defendant could most appropriately be found guilty of

options.optionA: A. Larceny
options.optionB: B. Embezzlement
options.optionC: C. False Pretenses
options.optionD: D. None of the above

explanation.Legal_Concept: Embezzlement in criminal law, specifically the fraudulent conversion of another's property by someone with lawful possession.
explanation.Fact_Analysis: The defendant, with lawful possession of the plaintiff's diamond ring as a pawnshop owner, sold the ring before the agreed-upon 60-day period expired, without the plaintiff's consent, and then lied about the ring being stolen when the plaintiff came to reclaim it.
explanation.Rule_Application: Embezzlement occurs when someone with lawful possession of another's property fraudulently converts that property. The defendant's actions of selling the ring before the agreed time and then deceiving the plaintiff about its whereabouts demonstrate a clear intent to permanently deprive the plaintiff of the ring, fitting the definition of embezzlement.
explanation.Legal_Conclusion: Given the defendant's fraudulent conversion of the plaintiff's property while in lawful possession, the most appropriate charge would be embezzlement, supporting option B.

question: This question is based on the four case summaries A - D. Select the case that would be most applicable as a precedent. A man, a heroin addict, broke into a house and took several cameras and watches, which he promptly pawned to obtain cash with which to obtain a "fix." The man was later charged with larceny of the cameras and watches.

options.optionA: A. Commonwealth v. Mason. Two sisters see a wealthy neighbor's pedigreed dog on the street. They take the dog home, intending to conceal it until the owner offers a reward. Held, guilty of larceny.
options.optionB: B. Saferite v. State. Two young men saw a motor car on the street with the keys in the ignition lock. They drove the car to a neighboring town with the intention, they said, of visiting the wife of one of the them. The car was wrecked on their way back. Conviction for larceny reversed.
options.optionC: C. People v. Noblett. The defendant, a tenant of a city apartment, advertised it for sublease. A person agreed to sublease for three months, and on March 12, paid the defendant $550, the total agreed rental. The person was to receive possession on March 20, but possession was never given him. Held, not guilty of common law larceny.
options.optionD: D. King v. Pear. From a stablekeeper, the defendant hired a horse to go to Sutton and back, saying he would be back at 8 p.m. He did not return. Investigation shows that the defendant had given a false address, and that he had sold the horse the same day. Conviction of larceny affirmed.

explanation.Legal_Concept: Larceny and the requirement of intent to permanently deprive the owner of their property, including the conversion of stolen goods into monetary value.
explanation.Fact_Analysis: A man broke into a house, stole cameras and watches, and then pawned them to obtain cash for a heroin fix. The question is whether this action constitutes larceny, focusing on the intent to convert stolen property into money.
explanation.Rule_Application: For a conviction of larceny, the intent to permanently deprive the owner of their property is crucial. This includes situations where the stolen property is converted into something else of monetary value, such as selling or pawning the items.
explanation.Legal_Conclusion: The case that best serves as a precedent is one where the defendant took property with the intent to conceal it until a reward was offered, highlighting the principle that the intent to convert property into monetary value or another form of benefit is sufficient for a larceny conviction, supporting option A.

question: A man suffered from the delusion that he was a special agent of God. He frequently experienced hallucinations in the form of hearing divine commands. The man believed God told him several times that the local Roman Catholic bishop was corrupting the diocese into heresy, and that the bishop should be "done away with." The man, a devout Catholic, conceived of himself as a religious martyr. He knew that shooting bishops for heresy is against the criminal law. He nevertheless carefully planned how he might kill the bishop. One evening the man shot the bishop, who was taken to the hospital where he died two weeks later. The man told the police he assumed the institutions of society would support the ecclesiastical hierarchy, and he expected to be persecuted for his God-inspired actions. A psychiatrist examined the man and found that the man suffered from schizophrenic psychosis, that in the absence of this psychosis he would not have shot the bishop, and that because of the psychosis the man found it extremely difficult to determine whether he should obey the specific command that he do away with the bishop or the general commandment "Thou shalt not kill." The man was charged with murder. If the man interposes an insanity defense, and the jurisdiction in which he is tried has adopted only the M'Naghten test of insanity, then the strongest argument for the defense under that test is that

options.optionA: A. The man did not know the nature of the act he was performing.
options.optionB: B. The man did not know that his act was morally wrong.
options.optionC: C. The man did not know the quality of the act he was performing.
options.optionD: D. The man's acts were the product of a mental disease.

explanation.Legal_Concept: Insanity defense in criminal law, specifically the M'Naghten test for determining criminal responsibility.
explanation.Fact_Analysis: The man, suffering from schizophrenic psychosis, believed he was acting on divine commands to kill the bishop, whom he thought was corrupting the diocese. Despite knowing that shooting bishops is against the law, he planned and executed the act, expecting persecution for his actions.
explanation.Rule_Application: The M'Naghten test holds that a defendant is not criminally responsible if, due to a defect of reason from disease of the mind, they did not know the nature and quality of the act they were doing, or if they did know it, that they did not know what they were doing was wrong. In this case, the man's mental defect led him to believe his actions were right, indicating he did not know his act was morally wrong.
explanation.Legal_Conclusion: Given the man's mental state and the application of the M'Naghten test, the strongest argument for the defense is that the man did not know his act was morally wrong, supporting option B.

question: A state statute makes it a felony for any teacher at a state institution of higher education to accept anything of value from a student at the same institution. A student at the state university offered his English teacher $50 in exchange for a good grade in his English course. The teacher agreed and took the money. The teacher and the student are tried jointly for violation of the state statute. The teacher is charged with violating the statute and the student with aiding and abetting him. The student's best argument for a dismissal of the charge against him is that

options.optionA: A. a principal and an accessory cannot be tried together, since the principal must be convicted first.
options.optionB: B. he cannot be an accessory, since he is the victim of the crime.
options.optionC: C. the legislature did not intend to punish the person giving the thing of value.
options.optionD: D. he did not assist the teacher in violating the statute.

explanation.Legal_Concept: Accessory liability and legislative intent in criminal law, particularly when a statute specifically names only one party as being criminally liable.
explanation.Fact_Analysis: A state statute makes it a felony for any teacher at a state institution of higher education to accept anything of value from a student at the same institution. The teacher accepted $50 from a student in exchange for a good grade, and both are tried jointly for violation of the statute.
explanation.Rule_Application: When a statute specifically names only one party as being criminally liable, but the offense necessarily requires at least two parties, courts will infer that the legislature did not intend to punish the unnamed party. In this case, the statute only explicitly prohibits the teacher from accepting something of value, suggesting the legislature did not intend to punish the student for giving it.
explanation.Legal_Conclusion: Given the statute's wording and the necessary involvement of two parties, the student's best argument for dismissal is that the legislature did not intend to punish the person giving the thing of value, supporting option C.

question: In which of the following situations is the defendant most likely to be guilty of the crime charged?

options.optionA: A. Without the permission of the owner, the defendant takes the owner's car with the intention of driving it three miles to a grocery store and back. The defendant is charged with larceny.
options.optionB: B. The defendant gets permission to borrow the owner's car for the evening by falsely promising to return it, although he does not intend to do so. Two days later, he changes his mind and returns the car. The defendant is charged with larceny by trick.
options.optionC: C. The defendant gets permission to borrow the owner's car for the evening by misrepresenting his identity and falsely claiming he has a valid driver's license. He returns the car the next day. The defendant is charged with obtaining property by false pretenses.
options.optionD: D. With permission, the defendant, promising to return it by 9:00 p.m., borrows the owner's car. Later in the evening, the defendant decides to keep the car until the next morning and does so. The defendant is charged with embezzlement.

explanation.Legal_Concept: Larceny by trick, a form of larceny involving obtaining possession of property with the owner's consent through fraud or misrepresentation, with the intent to permanently deprive the owner of the property.
explanation.Fact_Analysis: The defendant obtained permission to borrow the owner's car for the evening by falsely promising to return it, but had no intention of doing so. Two days later, the defendant changed his mind and returned the car.
explanation.Rule_Application: Larceny by trick requires that the defendant obtain possession of the property with the owner's consent, but through fraud or misrepresentation, and with the intent to permanently deprive the owner of the property. In this scenario, the defendant's false promise to return the car constitutes the necessary fraud or misrepresentation, and his initial intent to keep the car permanently satisfies the intent requirement.
explanation.Legal_Conclusion: Given that the defendant obtained possession of the car through false pretenses and initially intended to permanently deprive the owner of the car, the defendant is most likely guilty of larceny by trick, supporting option B.

question: While testifying in a civil trial, a witness was asked on cross-examination if he had been convicted in the circuit court of stealing $200 from his employer on August 16, 2007. The witness said, "No, I have never been convicted of any crime." In fact, the witness had pleaded guilty to such a charge and had been placed on probation. The witness was then charged with perjury on the ground that his statement denying the conviction was false. A statute in the jurisdiction defines perjury as knowingly making a false statement while under oath. At trial, the state proved the witness's statement and the prior conviction. The witness testified that the attorney who represented him in the theft case had told him that, because he had been placed on probation, he had not been convicted of a crime. The witness had served his probationary period satisfactorily and been discharged from probation. The alleged advice of the attorney was incorrect. If the jury believes the witness, it should find him

options.optionA: A. guilty, because his mistake was one of law.
options.optionB: B. guilty, because reliance on the advice of an attorney is not a defense.
options.optionC: C. not guilty if the jury also finds that his reliance on the attorney's advice was reasonable.
options.optionD: D. not guilty, because he lacked the necessary mental state.

explanation.Legal_Concept: Perjury, specifically the requirement of knowingly making a false statement under oath and the necessary mental state for conviction.
explanation.Fact_Analysis: The witness denied a prior conviction for stealing from his employer, claiming he had never been convicted of any crime. However, he had pleaded guilty and been placed on probation. The witness testified that his attorney had advised him that, due to the probation, he was not considered convicted.
explanation.Rule_Application: For a conviction of perjury, the statute requires that the defendant knowingly made a false statement under oath. The defendant's mental state is crucial; if the defendant honestly believed the statement was true, they did not knowingly make a false statement. In this case, if the jury believes the witness's testimony about his attorney's advice, it indicates the witness lacked knowledge of the statement's falsity.
explanation.Legal_Conclusion: Given the witness's potential honest belief in the truth of his statement, based on his attorney's advice, he would lack the necessary mental state for perjury. Therefore, the correct verdict would be not guilty due to the absence of the requisite mental state, supporting option D.

question: A defendant was driving through an apartment building area plagued with an unusually high incidence of burglaries and assaults. Acting pursuant to a police department plan to combat crime by randomly stopping automobiles in the area between midnight and 6:00 a.m., a police officer stopped the defendant and asked him for identification. As the defendant handed the officer his license, the officer directed a flashlight into the automobile and saw what appeared to be the barrel of a shotgun protruding from under the front seat on the passenger side of the car. The officer ordered the defendant from the car, searched him, and discovered marijuana cigarettes and a shotgun. At the defendant's trial for unlawful possession of narcotics, his motion to suppress the use of the marijuana as evidence should be

options.optionA: A. sustained, because the marijuana was discovered as a result of the unlawful stopping of the defendant's automobile.
options.optionB: B. sustained, because the use of the flashlight constituted a search of the interior of the defendant's automobile without probable cause.
options.optionC: C. denied, because the officer's conduct was consistent with the established police plan.
options.optionD: D. denied, because the discovery of the gun in plain view created the reasonable suspicion necessary to justify the arrest and search of the defendant.

explanation.Legal_Concept: The Fourth Amendment's protection against unreasonable searches and seizures, particularly in the context of random stops of automobiles.
explanation.Fact_Analysis: A police officer, acting under a department plan to combat crime, randomly stopped the defendant's vehicle in a high-crime area between midnight and 6:00 a.m. The officer then used a flashlight to look into the car, saw what appeared to be a shotgun, and subsequently searched the defendant, finding marijuana.
explanation.Rule_Application: The Fourth Amendment prohibits unreasonable searches and seizures. Random stops of automobiles, even in high-crime areas, are considered unreasonable without specific articulable suspicion or probable cause. Since the initial stop was improper, any evidence obtained directly from that stop, including the marijuana, is subject to suppression.
explanation.Legal_Conclusion: Given the improper initial stop of the defendant's vehicle, the evidence of marijuana found on his person should be suppressed. Therefore, the defendant's motion to suppress the use of the marijuana as evidence should be sustained, supporting option A.

question: In which of the following situations is the defendant most likely to be guilty of common-law murder?

options.optionA: A. During an argument in a bar, a man punches the defendant. The defendant, mistakenly believing that the man is about to stab him, shoots and kills the man.
options.optionB: B. While committing a robbery of a liquor store, the defendant accidentally drops his revolver, which goes off. The bullet strikes and kills the victim, a customer in the store.
options.optionC: C. While hunting deer, the defendant notices something moving in the bushes. Believing it to be a deer, the defendant fires into the bushes. The bullet strikes and kills the victim, another hunter.
options.optionD: D. In celebration of the Fourth of July, the defendant discharges a pistol within the city limits in violation of a city ordinance. The bullet ricochets off the street and strikes and kills the victim.

explanation.Legal_Concept: Common-law murder, specifically the felony murder rule, where a killing occurs during the commission of a violent felony.
explanation.Fact_Analysis: The defendant in answer B was committing an armed robbery, a violent felony, when the victim was accidentally killed by a bullet from the defendant's dropped revolver.
explanation.Rule_Application: The felony murder rule holds that if a killing occurs during the commission of a violent felony, the defendant can be charged with murder, even if the killing was accidental. In this case, the defendant's actions in committing the robbery created a foreseeable risk of death, and the defendant bears criminal responsibility for the victim's death.
explanation.Legal_Conclusion: Given that the defendant's actions in committing the armed robbery created a situation in which death was foreseeable, and the killing occurred during the commission of that felony, the defendant is most likely to be found guilty of common-law murder under the felony murder rule, supporting option B.

question: A father, disappointed by his 8-year-old son's failure to do well in school, began systematically depriving the child of food during summer vacation. Although his son became seriously ill from malnutrition, the father failed to call a doctor. He believed that as a parent he had the sole right to determine whether the child was fed or received medical treatment. Eventually the child died. An autopsy disclosed that the child had suffered agonizingly as a result of the starvation, that a physician's aid would have alleviated the suffering, and that although the child would have died in a few months from malnutrition, the actual cause of death was an untreatable form of cancer. The father was prosecuted for murder, defined in the jurisdiction as an "unlawful killing of a human being with malice aforethought." The father should be

options.optionA: A. acquitted, because of the defendant's good faith belief concerning parental rights in supervising children.
options.optionB: B. acquitted, because summoning the physician or feeding the child would not have prevented the child's death from cancer.
options.optionC: C. convicted, because the father's treatment of his son showed reckless indifference to the value of life.
options.optionD: D. convicted, because the child would have died from malnutrition had he not been afflicted with cancer.

explanation.Legal_Concept: Causation in criminal law, specifically the requirement that the defendant's actions be the actual and proximate cause of the victim's death to establish liability for murder.
explanation.Fact_Analysis: The father's actions of depriving his son of food led to serious illness from malnutrition, but an autopsy revealed the child's death was actually caused by an untreatable form of cancer. The father's failure to provide food or medical attention did not prevent the child's death from cancer.
explanation.Rule_Application: For a defendant to be convicted of murder, their actions must be the actual and proximate cause of the victim's death. In this case, the father's actions, although harmful and negligent, did not cause the child's death, as the child would have died from cancer regardless of the father's actions.
explanation.Legal_Conclusion: Given that the father's actions were not the cause of the child's death, and the child would have died from cancer regardless, the father should be acquitted of murder. This supports option B, as the father's failure to provide food or summon a physician did not prevent the child's death from cancer.

question: A professional poker player had cheated a man in a card game. Angered, the man set out for the poker player's house with the intention of shooting him. Just as he was about to set foot on the poker player's property, the man was arrested by a police officer who noticed that the man was carrying a revolver. A statute in the jurisdiction makes it a crime to "enter the property of another with the intent to commit any crime of violence thereon." If charged with attempting to violate the statute, the man should be found

options.optionA: A. not guilty, because the statute defines an attempted crime and there cannot be an attempt to attempt.
options.optionB: B. not guilty, because to convict him would be to punish him simply for having a guilty mind.
options.optionC: C. guilty, because he was close enough to entering the property and he had the necessary state of mind.
options.optionD: D. guilty, because this is a statute designed to protect the public from violence, and the man was dangerous.

explanation.Legal_Concept: Attempt to commit a crime, specifically the elements required for conviction under a statute criminalizing entry onto another's property with intent to commit a crime of violence.
explanation.Fact_Analysis: The man, motivated by anger over being cheated in a card game, armed himself with a revolver and traveled to the poker player's house with the intention of shooting him. He was arrested just before stepping onto the property.
explanation.Rule_Application: To be convicted of attempt, one must have the specific intent to commit the crime and take a substantial step towards its commission. The statute in question criminalizes entering another's property with the intent to commit a crime of violence. The man's actions of obtaining a weapon and approaching the poker player's property demonstrate both the requisite intent and substantial steps towards committing the crime.
explanation.Legal_Conclusion: Given the man's clear intent to commit violence by shooting the poker player and his substantial steps towards entering the property for that purpose, he should be found guilty of attempting to violate the statute, supporting option C.

question: A defendant held up a gasoline station. During the robbery he shot and killed a customer who attempted to apprehend him. The defendant was prosecuted for premeditated murder and convicted. Thereafter, he was indicted for armed robbery of the station. Before the trial, his attorney moved to dismiss the indictment on the ground that further proceedings were unconstitutional because of the defendant's prior conviction. The motion to dismiss should be

options.optionA: A. granted, because once the defendant was convicted on any of the charges arising out of the robbery, the prosecution was constitutionally estopped from proceeding against the defendant on any charge stemming from the same transaction.
options.optionB: B. granted, because the double jeopardy clause prohibits a subsequent trial on what is essentially a lesser included offense.
options.optionC: C. denied, because there is no constitutional requirement that all known charges against the defendant be brought in the same prosecution.
options.optionD: D. denied, because estoppel does not apply when the defendant is charged with violating two different statutes.

explanation.Legal_Concept: Double jeopardy and the requirement for bringing all known charges in the same prosecution.
explanation.Fact_Analysis: The defendant was convicted of premeditated murder for killing a customer during a robbery and was later indicted for armed robbery of the same station. The defendant's attorney moved to dismiss the indictment, arguing that further proceedings were unconstitutional due to the prior conviction.
explanation.Rule_Application: The double jeopardy clause does not require that all known charges be brought in the same prosecution. Additionally, armed robbery is considered a separate offense from premeditated murder and is not a lesser included offense. Therefore, the prosecution for armed robbery does not violate the double jeopardy clause.
explanation.Legal_Conclusion: Given that there is no constitutional requirement for all charges to be brought at once and that armed robbery is a distinct offense from premeditated murder, the motion to dismiss should be denied, supporting option C.

question: Adams, Bennett, and Curtis are charged in a common law jurisdiction with conspiracy to commit larceny. The state introduced evidence that they agreed to go to a neighbor's house to take stock certificates from a safe in the neighbor's bedroom, that they went to the house, and that they were arrested as they entered the neighbor's bedroom. Adams testified that he thought the stock certificates belonged to Curtis, that the neighbor was improperly keeping them from Curtis, and that he went along to aid in retrieving Curtis's property. Bennett testified that he suspected Adams and Curtis of being thieves and joined up with them in order to catch them. He also testified that he made an anonymous telephone call to the police alerting them to the crime and that the call caused the police to be waiting for them when they walked into the neighbor's bedroom. Curtis did not testify. If the jury believes Adams, it should find him

options.optionA: A. guilty, because there was an agreement, and the entry into the bedroom is sufficient for the overt act.
options.optionB: B. guilty, because good motives are not a defense to criminal liability.
options.optionC: C. not guilty, because he did not have a corrupt motive.
options.optionD: D. not guilty, because he did not intend to steal.

explanation.Legal_Concept: Conspiracy to commit a crime, specifically the requirement of intent to commit the crime as an element of conspiracy.
explanation.Fact_Analysis: Adams, Bennett, and Curtis were charged with conspiracy to commit larceny for agreeing to retrieve stock certificates from a neighbor's safe. Adams claimed he believed the certificates belonged to Curtis and he was aiding in retrieving Curtis's property, while Bennett joined to catch Adams and Curtis in the act and alerted the police.
explanation.Rule_Application: Conspiracy requires an agreement to commit a crime and the intent that the crime be committed. A defendant's good motives or lack thereof are irrelevant if they did not intend to commit the crime. In this case, if Adams genuinely believed he was helping Curtis retrieve his property, he lacked the requisite intent to commit larceny.
explanation.Legal_Conclusion: Given that Adams did not intend to steal the stock certificates but rather believed he was aiding in the retrieval of Curtis's property, he should be found not guilty of conspiracy to commit larceny, supporting option D.

question: Adams, Bennett, and Curtis are charged in a common law jurisdiction with conspiracy to commit larceny. The state introduced evidence that they agreed to go to a neighbor's house to take stock certificates from a safe in the neighbor's bedroom, that they went to the house, and that they were arrested as they entered the neighbor's bedroom. Adams testified that he thought the stock certificates belonged to Curtis, that the neighbor was improperly keeping them from Curtis, and that he went along to aid in retrieving Curtis's property. Bennett testified that he suspected Adams and Curtis of being thieves and joined up with them in order to catch them. He also testified that he made an anonymous telephone call to the police alerting them to the crime and that the call caused the police to be waiting for them when they walked into the neighbor's bedroom. Curtis did not testify. If the jury believes Bennett, it should find him

options.optionA: A. guilty, because there was an agreement, and the entry into the bedroom is sufficient for the overt act.
options.optionB: B. guilty, because he is not a police officer and thus cannot claim any privilege of apprehending criminals.
options.optionC: C. not guilty, because he did not intend to steal.
options.optionD: D. not guilty, because he prevented the theft from occurring.

explanation.Legal_Concept: Conspiracy to commit a crime, specifically the requirement of intent to commit the crime for a conspiracy charge.
explanation.Fact_Analysis: Bennett joined Adams and Curtis in a plan to enter a neighbor's house to take stock certificates from a safe, but he testified that his intention was to catch Adams and Curtis in the act of theft, not to participate in it. He also made an anonymous call to the police, which led to their arrest upon entering the neighbor's bedroom.
explanation.Rule_Application: For a conspiracy charge to be valid, there must be both an agreement to commit a crime and the intent to commit that crime. If Bennett's intention was to apprehend the thieves rather than to participate in the theft, he lacks the requisite intent to be guilty of conspiracy.
explanation.Legal_Conclusion: Given Bennett's stated intention to catch Adams and Curtis rather than to participate in the theft, and his actions to alert the police, he should be found not guilty of conspiracy to commit larceny, supporting option C.

question: Adams, Bennett, and Curtis are charged in a common law jurisdiction with conspiracy to commit larceny. The state introduced evidence that they agreed to go to a neighbor's house to take stock certificates from a safe in the neighbor's bedroom, that they went to the house, and that they were arrested as they entered the neighbor's bedroom. Adams testified that he thought the stock certificates belonged to Curtis, that the neighbor was improperly keeping them from Curtis, and that he went along to aid in retrieving Curtis's property. Bennett testified that he suspected Adams and Curtis of being thieves and joined up with them in order to catch them. He also testified that he made an anonymous telephone call to the police alerting them to the crime and that the call caused the police to be waiting for them when they walked into the neighbor's bedroom. Curtis did not testify. If the jury believes both Adams and Bennett, it should find Curtis

options.optionA: A. guilty, because there was an agreement, and the entry into the bedroom is sufficient for the overt act.
options.optionB: B. guilty, because he intended to steal.
options.optionC: C. not guilty, because a conviction would penalize him for exercising his right not to be a witness.
options.optionD: D. not guilty, because Adams and Bennett did not intend to steal.

explanation.Legal_Concept: Conspiracy to commit a crime, specifically the requirements for a valid conspiracy charge including agreement and intent.
explanation.Fact_Analysis: Adams, Bennett, and Curtis were charged with conspiracy to commit larceny. Adams believed the stock certificates belonged to Curtis and that the neighbor was improperly keeping them, while Bennett suspected Adams and Curtis of being thieves and joined to catch them, even alerting the police. Curtis did not testify.
explanation.Rule_Application: A conspiracy charge requires an agreement between co-conspirators to commit a crime and that at least two of them intend for the crime to be committed. If the jury believes Adams and Bennett, neither had the intent to steal, thus there was no true agreement to commit larceny.
explanation.Legal_Conclusion: Given that neither Adams nor Bennett intended to steal, and Curtis's intent is not established, there is no valid conspiracy. Therefore, Curtis should be found not guilty of conspiracy to commit larceny, supporting option D.

question: A driver, while intoxicated, drove his car through a playground crowded with children just to watch the children run to get out of his way. His car struck one of the children, killing her instantly. Which of the following is the best theory for finding the driver guilty of murder?

options.optionA: A. Transferred intent.
options.optionB: B. Felony murder, with assault with a deadly weapon as the underlying felony
options.optionC: C. Intentional killing, since he knew that the children were there, and he deliberately drove his car at them
options.optionD: D. Commission of an act highly dangerous to life, without an intent to kill but with disregard of the consequences

explanation.Legal_Concept: Murder under the theory of implied malice through gross recklessness towards human life.
explanation.Fact_Analysis: The driver, while intoxicated, deliberately drove his car through a crowded playground, striking and killing a child. His actions demonstrated a clear disregard for the safety and lives of the children present.
explanation.Rule_Application: At common law, murder can be established through malice aforethought, which does not require a specific intent to kill. Malice can be implied when an individual's actions show gross recklessness towards human life, indicating a disregard for the potential consequences of their behavior.
explanation.Legal_Conclusion: Given the driver's actions were highly dangerous to life and showed a blatant disregard for human safety, his behavior can be classified as gross recklessness. This satisfies the requirement for malice aforethought, making him guilty of murder under the theory of implied malice, supporting option D.

question: Which of the following is most likely to be found to be a strict liability offense?

options.optionA: A. A city ordinance providing for a fine of not more than $200 for shoplifting.
options.optionB: B. A federal statute making it a felony to possess heroin.
options.optionC: C. A state statute making it a felony to fail to register a firearm.
options.optionD: D. A state statute making the sale of adulterated milk a misdemeanor.

explanation.Legal_Concept: Strict liability offenses, particularly in the context of public welfare crimes where mens rea is not required.
explanation.Fact_Analysis: The question asks for the identification of a strict liability offense among the given options, which include various types of crimes and penalties.
explanation.Rule_Application: Strict liability offenses are characterized by the absence of a mens rea requirement and typically involve lighter penalties. They are often related to public welfare and regulatory matters. Among the options provided, the sale of adulterated milk as a misdemeanor aligns with the definition of a strict liability offense, as it focuses on the act itself rather than the intent or knowledge of the actor.
explanation.Legal_Conclusion: Given the characteristics of strict liability offenses, the most likely option to be classified as such is the state statute making the sale of adulterated milk a misdemeanor, which supports option D.

question: A student broke into a professor's office in order to look at examination questions. The questions were locked in a drawer, and the student could not find them. The student believed that looking at examination questions was a crime, but this belief was mistaken. Charged with burglary, the defendant should be

options.optionA: A. acquitted, because he did not complete the crime, and he has not been charged with attempt.
options.optionB: B. acquitted, because what he intended to do when he broke in was not a crime.
options.optionC: C. convicted, because he had the necessary mental state and committed the act of breaking and entering.
options.optionD: D. convicted, because factual impossibility is not a defense.

explanation.Legal_Concept: Burglary and the requisite mental state for committing the crime, specifically the intent to commit a felony.
explanation.Fact_Analysis: A student broke into a professor's office with the intention of looking at examination questions, believing this act to be a crime. However, looking at examination questions is not a crime, and thus not a felony.
explanation.Rule_Application: For a burglary conviction, the prosecution must prove that the defendant broke and entered into a structure with the intent to commit a felony. Since the act the student intended to commit (looking at examination questions) is not a felony, the student lacked the requisite mental state for burglary.
explanation.Legal_Conclusion: Given that the student's intended action was not a crime, the student cannot be convicted of burglary. Therefore, the correct verdict would be acquitted, supporting option B.

question: The defendant, while eating in a restaurant, noticed that a departing customer at the next table had left a five-dollar bill as a tip for the waitress. The defendant reached over, picked up the five dollar bill, and put it in his pocket. As he stood up to leave, another customer who had seen him take the money ran over to him and hit him in the face with her umbrella. Enraged, the defendant choked the customer to death. The defendant is charged with murder. He requests the court to charge the jury that they can find him guilty of voluntary manslaughter rather than murder. The defendant's request should be

options.optionA: A. granted, because the jury could find that the defendant acted recklessly and not with the intent to cause death or serious bodily harm.
options.optionB: B. granted, because the jury could find that being hit in the face with an umbrella constitutes adequate provocation.
options.optionC: C. denied, because the evidence shows that the defendant intended to kill or to cause serious bodily harm.
options.optionD: D. denied, because the evidence shows that the defendant provoked the assault on himself by his criminal misconduct.

explanation.Legal_Concept: Voluntary manslaughter and the 'heat of passion' defense as a mitigation of malice aforethought in murder charges.
explanation.Fact_Analysis: The defendant was struck in the face with an umbrella by another customer after being seen taking a five-dollar bill left as a tip. The defendant then choked the customer to death. The question is whether the jury can consider voluntary manslaughter due to the 'heat of passion' provoked by the umbrella attack.
explanation.Rule_Application: For a 'heat of passion' defense to apply, there must be legally adequate provocation leading to a sudden and passionate response, mitigating the malice aforethought required for a murder charge. The jury must consider whether being hit with an umbrella constitutes adequate provocation and if the defendant's response was indeed in the heat of passion.
explanation.Legal_Conclusion: Given that there is some evidence to suggest the defendant's actions could be classified as a 'heat of passion' response to adequate provocation, the jury should be instructed on voluntary manslaughter. Therefore, the defendant's request should be granted, supporting option B.

question: An inventor, believing that a woman suffered from arthritis, told her that for $100 he could cure her with a device he had invented. The device was a large box with a series of electric light bulbs along the sides. The woman, after examining the device, agreed to take the treatment, which consisted of placing her hands inside the box for several ten-minute periods. The woman gave the inventor $100 and went through the treatment. The inventor is charged with obtaining money by false pretenses. Each of the following, if true, will absolve the inventor of guilt for obtaining money by false pretenses EXCEPT:

options.optionA: A. The inventor honestly believed that the device would cure arthritis, but his belief was unreasonable.
options.optionB: B. The woman honestly believed that the device would cure arthritis, but her belief was unreasonable.
options.optionC: C. The inventor was playing a practical joke on the woman and intended to return the money.
options.optionD: D. The woman was an undercover police officer and did not believe that the device would cure arthritis.

explanation.Legal_Concept: False pretenses in criminal law, specifically the elements required to establish guilt, including fraud, misrepresentation, and intent to steal.
explanation.Fact_Analysis: The inventor made a false claim that his device could cure arthritis, and the woman, believing this claim, paid him $100 for the treatment. The question revolves around what circumstances would absolve the inventor of guilt for obtaining money by false pretenses.
explanation.Rule_Application: To establish false pretenses, there must be a false representation of a material fact, made with the intent to defraud, and the victim must have relied on the false representation to their detriment. The victim's belief in the false statement, whether reasonable or unreasonable, does not negate the elements of false pretenses if the other elements are met.
explanation.Legal_Conclusion: Since the woman's unreasonable belief in the inventor's false statement does not negate the elements of false pretenses, answer B is the correct choice that will NOT absolve the inventor of guilt for obtaining money by false pretenses.

question: The defendant was an alcoholic who frequently experienced auditory hallucinations that commanded him to engage in bizarre and sometimes violent behavior. He generally obeyed their commands. The hallucinations appeared more frequently when he was intoxicated, but he sometimes experienced them when he had not been drinking. After the defendant had been drinking continuously for a three-day period, an elderly woman began to reproach him about his drunken condition, slapping him on the face and shoulders as she did so. The defendant believed that he was being unmercifully attacked and heard the hallucinatory voice telling him to strangle his assailant. He did so, and she died. If the defendant is charged with second degree murder, the defendant's best chance of acquittal would be to rely on a defense of

options.optionA: A. intoxication.
options.optionB: B. lack of malice aforethought.
options.optionC: C. self-defense.
options.optionD: D. insanity.

explanation.Legal_Concept: Insanity defense in criminal law, particularly its application to second degree murder charges.
explanation.Fact_Analysis: The defendant, an alcoholic with a history of auditory hallucinations, was reproached by an elderly woman for his drunken state. He believed he was under attack, heard a hallucinatory voice commanding him to strangle his assailant, and acted accordingly, resulting in the woman's death.
explanation.Rule_Application: The insanity defense applies if, at the time of the crime, the defendant suffered from a mental disease or defect that prevented him from knowing the wrongfulness of his actions. The defendant's history of obeying hallucinatory commands, especially when intoxicated, and his belief that he was acting in self-defense, may demonstrate a defect in reasoning due to mental illness.
explanation.Legal_Conclusion: Given the defendant's mental state and actions, his best chance of acquittal for a second degree murder charge would be to rely on an insanity defense, as it directly addresses the issue of criminal responsibility due to mental illness.

question: A husband and wife were walking to their car one evening after having seen a movie. As they were passing a dark alleyway, the defendant leaped out brandishing a gun. He pushed the wife against the wall of a nearby building, held the gun to her head, and demanded money from the husband. The husband handed over his cash. The defendant grabbed the cash and ran away. Which of the following, listed in descending order of seriousness, is the most serious crime for which the defendant may be convicted?

options.optionA: A. Robbery of the husband
options.optionB: B. Larceny from the husband
options.optionC: C. Assault on the husband and wife
options.optionD: D. Assault on the wife

explanation.Legal_Concept: Robbery, specifically the elements of taking personal property by force or threat of force with the intent to permanently deprive the owner.
explanation.Fact_Analysis: The defendant used a gun to threaten the wife, forcing the husband to hand over his cash. The defendant's actions involved both the threat of force against the wife and the taking of the husband's property.
explanation.Rule_Application: Robbery requires the taking of personal property of another by force or threat of force with the intent to permanently deprive the owner. The force or threat of force does not have to be directed at the owner of the property but can be against another person, as seen in this scenario where the threat was against the wife to obtain the husband's money.
explanation.Legal_Conclusion: Given the defendant's actions of using a threat of force against the wife to obtain the husband's money, the most serious crime for which the defendant may be convicted is robbery of the husband, supporting option A.

question: The defendant and her friend went into a drugstore where the defendant reached into the cash register and took out $200. The store owner came out of a back room, saw what had happened, and told the defendant to put the money back. The friend then took a revolver from under his coat and shot and killed the store owner.The defendant claims that the store owner owed her $200 and that she went to the drugstore to try to collect the debt. She said that she asked her friend to come along just in case the store owner made trouble but that she did not plan on using any force and did not know that her friend was armed. If the defendant is prosecuted for murder on the basis of felony murder and the jury believes her claim, she should be found

options.optionA: A. guilty, because her friend committed a homicide in the course of a felony.
options.optionB: B. guilty, because her taking her friend with her to the store created the risk of death that occurred during the commission of a felony.
options.optionC: C. not guilty, because she did not know that her friend was armed and thus did not have the required mental state for felony murder.
options.optionD: D. not guilty, because she believed she was entitled to the money and thus did not intend to steal.

explanation.Legal_Concept: Felony murder rule, specifically the requirement of an underlying dangerous felony for a murder conviction.
explanation.Fact_Analysis: The defendant entered a drugstore with a friend to collect a debt of $200, which she believed was owed to her. The friend, who was armed, shot and killed the store owner after the defendant was confronted. The defendant claims she did not plan to use force and was unaware of her friend's weapon.
explanation.Rule_Application: For a conviction under the felony murder rule, the murder must occur during the commission or attempted commission of a dangerous felony. If the defendant genuinely believed she was collecting a debt owed to her, she was not committing a felony, and thus the felony murder rule does not apply.
explanation.Legal_Conclusion: Given the defendant's belief that she was entitled to the money, she did not have the intent to steal, which is necessary for the underlying felony. Therefore, the correct verdict would be not guilty, supporting option D.

question: The defendant and her friend went into a drugstore, where the defendant reached into the cash register and took out $200. The store owner came out of a back room, saw what had happened, and told the defendant to put the money back. The friend then took a revolver from under his coat and shot and killed the store owner. The defendant claims that the store owner owed her $200 and that she went to the drugstore to try to collect the debt. She said that she asked her friend to come along just in case the store owner made trouble but that she did not plan on using any force and did not know that her friend was armed. If the defendant is prosecuted for murder on the basis of being an accessory to her friend in committing a murder and the jury believes her claim, she should be found

options.optionA: A. guilty, because in firing the shot her friend was trying to help her.
options.optionB: B. guilty, because she and her friend were acting in concert in a dangerous undertaking.
options.optionC: C. not guilty, because she had no idea that her friend was armed and she did not plan to use force.
options.optionD: D. not guilty, because she was exercising self-help and did not intend to steal.

explanation.Legal_Concept: Accessory liability in criminal law, specifically the requirements for intent and aid in the commission of a crime.
explanation.Fact_Analysis: The defendant entered the drugstore with her friend to collect a debt, reaching into the cash register and taking $200. The store owner confronted them, and the friend shot and killed the owner. The defendant claims she did not plan to use force and was unaware her friend was armed.
explanation.Rule_Application: To be considered an accessory, one must have the intent that the crime be committed and must aid, abet, or encourage the offense. Believing the defendant's claim, she lacked the requisite intent for murder and did not aid or encourage her friend's actions, as she was unaware of the friend's weapon and did not plan for force to be used.
explanation.Legal_Conclusion: Given the defendant's lack of intent for murder and her unawareness of her friend's armed status, she cannot be held criminally responsible as an accessory. Therefore, the correct verdict would be not guilty, supporting option C.

question: Damson was short of money. He decided to go into Walters' house to take Walters' silverware and then to sell it. That night, while Walters' was away, Damson entered by picking the lock on the front door. He picked up a chest of silverware from the dining room and went out the front door of the house to his car. As he was putting the chest of silverware into the trunk, he had second thoughts and decided that he did not wish to become a thief. He reentered the house and replaced the chest of silverware where he had found it. As he came out of the house the second time, he was arrested by the police, who had been called by a neighbor. Damson is

options.optionA: A. guilty of burglary and larceny.
options.optionB: B. guilty of burglary and attempted larceny.
options.optionC: C. guilty of burglary but not guilty of any larceny offense.
options.optionD: D. not guilty of burglary or any larceny offense.

explanation.Legal_Concept: Burglary and larceny, specifically the elements required for conviction and the impact of intent and subsequent actions on guilt.
explanation.Fact_Analysis: Damson broke into Walters' house at night with the intent to steal silverware, successfully removing it from the premises before having second thoughts and returning it. He was arrested upon exiting the house the second time.
explanation.Rule_Application: Burglary requires breaking and entering a dwelling at night with the intent to commit a felony, in this case, larceny. Larceny requires taking and carrying away another's property with the intent to permanently deprive the owner. Damson's actions meet both criteria, as he broke into the house with the intent to steal and did indeed take the silverware with that intent, regardless of his later change of heart.
explanation.Legal_Conclusion: Given that Damson committed both burglary by breaking and entering with the intent to commit larceny and the larceny itself by taking the property with the intent to permanently deprive the owner, he is guilty of both offenses. His later reconsideration and return of the property do not negate the crimes already committed, supporting option A.

question: The question was: Which of the following is LEAST likely to be the underlying felony in a prosecution for felony murder?

options.optionA: A. Arson
options.optionB: B. Manslaughter
options.optionC: C. Attempted rape
options.optionD: D. Burglary

explanation.Legal_Concept: Felony murder rule and its application to underlying felonies.
explanation.Fact_Analysis: The felony murder rule applies to situations where a death occurs during the commission of a felony. The underlying felony must be inherently dangerous or risky to support a felony murder charge.
explanation.Rule_Application: Manslaughter is not considered an underlying felony for felony murder because it already involves the unlawful killing of another person. The felony murder rule requires an independent felony that is not inherently homicidal. Arson, attempted rape, and burglary are all inherently dangerous and risky, making them more likely to be considered underlying felonies for felony murder.
explanation.Legal_Conclusion: Given the nature of manslaughter as an unlawful killing, it is the least likely to be considered an underlying felony for a felony murder charge. Therefore, option B, Manslaughter, is the correct answer.

question: A man was a suspect in a homicide committed during a robbery of a liquor store. A barber was a friend of the suspect. The police telephoned the barber and asked if he would help locate the suspect. The barber agreed and met the police officers at headquarters later that night. After a discussion during which police asked questions about the suspect and the homicide, the barber said he wanted to get something "off his chest" and advised the officers that he was in on the robbery but that the suspect had shot the owner of the store without his permission or prior knowledge. The officers then for the first time gave the barber his Miranda warnings. The barber was indicted for felony murder. He moved to prevent the introduction of his statement into evidence. His motion should be

options.optionA: A. granted, because the barber was effectively in custody and entitled to receive Miranda warnings at the beginning of the discussion.
options.optionB: B. granted, because the barber's rights to counsel and to due process were violated by the interrogation at police headquarters.
options.optionC: C. denied, because his statement was freely and voluntarily given, and he was not entitled to Miranda warnings.
options.optionD: D. denied, because by visiting headquarters voluntarily, the barber waived his right to have Miranda warnings at the beginning of the discussion.

explanation.Legal_Concept: The applicability of Miranda warnings to voluntary statements made by an individual not in custody or under interrogation for a crime they are suspected of committing.
explanation.Fact_Analysis: The barber, a friend of the suspect in a homicide, voluntarily met with police officers at headquarters to discuss the suspect's whereabouts. During the conversation, the barber revealed his involvement in the robbery and the suspect's actions. The police did not provide Miranda warnings until after the barber made this statement.
explanation.Rule_Application: Miranda warnings are required only when an individual is subjected to custodial interrogation. Since the barber was not a suspect, was not under arrest, and voluntarily participated in the discussion, the police were not obligated to provide Miranda warnings. The barber's statement was voluntarily given without coercion.
explanation.Legal_Conclusion: Given that the barber's statement was made voluntarily and without police coercion, and he was not in custody or under interrogation, his motion to suppress the statement should be denied, supporting option C.

question: A defendant is indicted in state court for bribing a public official. During the course of the investigation, police had demanded and received from the defendant's bank the records of the defendant's checking account for the preceding two years. The records contained incriminating evidence. On the basis of a claim of violation of his constitutional rights, the defendant moves to prevent the introduction of records in evidence. His motion should be

options.optionA: A. granted, because a search warrant should have been secured for seizure of the records.
options.optionB: B. granted, because the records covered such an extensive period of time that their seizure unreasonably invaded the defendant's right of privacy.
options.optionC: C. denied, because the potential destructibility of the records, coupled with the public interest in proper enforcement of the criminal laws, created an exigent situation justifying the seizure.
options.optionD: D. denied, because the records were business records of the bank in which the defendant had no legitimate expectation of privacy.

explanation.Legal_Concept: Expectation of privacy in bank records under the Fourth Amendment.
explanation.Fact_Analysis: The defendant's bank records, which contained incriminating evidence, were obtained by police without a warrant. The records in question were those of the bank, detailing the defendant's checking account activity over the preceding two years.
explanation.Rule_Application: According to U.S. v. Miller, individuals do not have a reasonable expectation of privacy in their bank records. This is because bank records are considered the property of the bank, not the individual, and thus are not protected by the Fourth Amendment's warrant requirement.
explanation.Legal_Conclusion: Since the defendant had no legitimate expectation of privacy in the bank records, the motion to suppress the evidence should be denied. This aligns with the principle that bank records are not subject to the same privacy protections as personal effects or private communications.

question: A statute in a jurisdiction makes it a crime to sell ammunition to a minor (defined as a person under the age of eighteen). The courts have interpreted this statute as creating a strict liability offense that does not require knowledge of the age of the purchaser and as creating vicarious liability. A minor, who was sixteen years old, but looked four or five years older, entered a store and asked a clerk for a box of .22 caliber shells. The store owner had instructed her employees not to sell ammunition to minors. The clerk asked the minor his age. The minor said he was twenty. The clerk then placed a box of shells on the counter and asked, "Anything else?" The minor said that was all he wanted but then discovered he did not have enough money to pay for the shells, so the clerk put the box back onto the shelf. If the owner of the store is charged with attempting to violate the statute, her best argument would be that

options.optionA: A. it was impossible for the sale to have occurred.
options.optionB: B. she had strictly instructed her employees not to sell ammunition to minors.
options.optionC: C. the minor lied about his age.
options.optionD: D. the clerk did not have the mental state needed for attempt.

explanation.Legal_Concept: Attempt and vicarious liability in the context of a strict liability offense, specifically the sale of ammunition to a minor.
explanation.Fact_Analysis: A minor, appearing older than his actual age, attempted to purchase ammunition from a store clerk, who was instructed by the store owner not to sell to minors. The clerk asked for the minor's age, was lied to, and began the transaction but ultimately did not complete it due to the minor's lack of funds.
explanation.Rule_Application: For a conviction of attempt, there must be both the intent to commit the crime and a substantial step towards its commission. In strict liability offenses, the intent element is crucial for an attempt charge. The store owner, through her employee, did not have the intent to sell ammunition to a minor, as evidenced by her instructions to the contrary.
explanation.Legal_Conclusion: Given that the clerk lacked the requisite intent to commit the crime, and by extension, the store owner as well, the best argument for the store owner is that the clerk did not have the mental state needed for attempt, supporting option D.

question: A husband decided to kill his wife by poisoning her. He asked his friend, a pharmacist, to obtain some Curare, a deadly poison, and to give it to him without recording the transaction. Because the pharmacist suspected the husband's motive, she supplied the husband with a small quantity of Marvane, an antibiotic, instead of Curare. Marvane is harmless if administered in small quantities, except for the less than 1 percent of the population who are allergic to the drug. The husband injected his wife with Marvane while she slept. She was allergic to the drug and died from the injection. The pharmacist was distraught and confessed the entire affair to the police, explaining that she had failed to report the husband's conduct to the authorities because she feared that it would end their friendship if she did. The pharmacist is an accomplice to

options.optionA: A. murder.
options.optionB: B. manslaughter.
options.optionC: C. criminally negligent homicide.
options.optionD: D. no degree of criminal homicide.

explanation.Legal_Concept: Accomplice liability in criminal law, specifically the requirements for intent and aiding in the commission of a crime.
explanation.Fact_Analysis: The pharmacist supplied the husband with Marvane, an antibiotic, instead of Curare, a deadly poison, due to suspicions about the husband's motives. The husband used the Marvane to kill his wife, who was allergic to the drug. The pharmacist did not report the husband's conduct to the authorities due to fear of damaging their friendship.
explanation.Rule_Application: To be considered an accomplice, an individual must have the intent that the crime be committed and aid in the commission of the offense. In this case, the pharmacist lacked the requisite intent, as she intentionally provided a harmless substance to prevent the husband from committing a crime.
explanation.Legal_Conclusion: Given that the pharmacist did not have the intent for the crime to be committed, she cannot be considered an accomplice to any degree of criminal homicide. Therefore, the correct answer is that she is not liable for any degree of criminal homicide, supporting option D.

question: A husband decided to kill his wife by poisoning her. He asked his friend, a pharmacist, to obtain some Curare, a deadly poison, and to give it to him without recording the transaction. Because the pharmacist suspected the husband's motive, she supplied the husband with a small quantity of Marvane, an antibiotic, instead of Curare. Marvane is harmless if administered in small quantities, except for the less than 1 percent of the population who are allergic to the drug. The husband injected his wife with Marvane while she slept. She was allergic to the drug and died from the injection. The pharmacist was distraught and confessed the entire affair to the police, explaining that she had failed to report the husband's conduct to the authorities because she feared that it would end their friendship if she did. In a common-law jurisdiction, the husband is guilty of

options.optionA: A. murder only.
options.optionB: B. murder and conspiracy.
options.optionC: C. attempted murder only.
options.optionD: D. attempted murder and conspiracy.

explanation.Legal_Concept: Murder under common law, specifically the elements of malice aforethought and causation of death.
explanation.Fact_Analysis: The husband intentionally administered what he believed to be a deadly poison to his wife, with the intent to kill her. Unbeknownst to him, the substance was actually an antibiotic, but his wife was allergic to it and died as a result of the injection.
explanation.Rule_Application: To establish murder, it must be proven that the defendant caused the death of another human being with malice aforethought. Malice aforethought can be established through intent to kill, and the husband's actions clearly demonstrate this intent. The fact that the husband did not actually use the poison he intended to does not negate his culpability, as his actions were the direct cause of his wife's death.
explanation.Legal_Conclusion: Given the husband's intent to kill his wife and his actions being the direct cause of her death, he is guilty of murder, regardless of the actual substance used. This supports the conclusion that the husband is guilty of murder only, aligning with option A.

question: During the night, the defendant broke into a house with the intention of stealing a typewriter. On not finding a typewriter, she became angry, poured lighter fluid onto a couch, and set it on fire. The flames destroyed the couch and also burned a portion of the ceiling in the room. In a common-law jurisdiction, the defendant is guilty of

options.optionA: A. burglary only.
options.optionB: B. arson only.
options.optionC: C. burglary and attempted arson.
options.optionD: D. burglary and arson.

explanation.Legal_Concept: Common-law definitions and applications of burglary and arson, particularly in relation to intent and damage to a dwelling.
explanation.Fact_Analysis: The defendant broke into a house at night with the intention of stealing a typewriter. Upon not finding the typewriter, she poured lighter fluid on a couch and set it on fire, resulting in the destruction of the couch and damage to a portion of the ceiling.
explanation.Rule_Application: Burglary is established by the breaking and entering of a dwelling at night with the intent to commit a felony, regardless of whether the felony is actually committed. Arson is established by the malicious or intentional burning of the dwelling of another, with the damage to the structure being a key factor. In this case, the defendant's actions meet the criteria for both burglary, due to her intent to steal, and arson, due to the intentional burning of the dwelling.
explanation.Legal_Conclusion: Given the defendant's actions and the common-law definitions of burglary and arson, she is guilty of both crimes.
