explanation.Legal_Conclusion: Given the enumerated powers of Congress and the need to maintain a unified national stance in foreign affairs, the strongest constitutional ground for the validity of this law is that Congress may legislate to preserve the monopoly of the national government over the conduct of United States foreign affairs, supporting option A.

question: 229 .Congress enacts a law providing that all disagreements between the United States and a state over federal grant-in-aid funds shall be settled by the filing of a suit in the federal district court in the affected state. "The judgment of that federal court shall be transmitted to the head of the federal agency dispensing such funds who, if satisfied that the judgment is fair and lawful, shall execute the judgment according to its terms." This law is

options.optionA: A. constitutional, because disagreements over federal grant-in-aid funds necessarily involve federal questions within the judicial power of the United States.
options.optionB: B. constitutional, because the spending of federal monies necessarily includes the authority to provide for the effective settlement of disputes involving them.
options.optionC: C. unconstitutional, because it vests authority in the federal court to determine a matter prohibited to it by the Eleventh Amendment.
options.optionD: D. unconstitutional, because it vests authority in a federal court to render an advisory opinion.

explanation.Legal_Concept: The constitutionality of a congressional law providing for the settlement of federal grant-in-aid fund disputes in federal district court.
explanation.Fact_Analysis: The law in question requires that disagreements between the United States and a state over federal grant-in-aid funds be settled by a suit in the federal district court in the affected state, with the judgment being executed by the head of the federal agency dispensing the funds.
explanation.Rule_Application: The law is constitutional because it involves federal questions within the judicial power of the United States. The Constitution grants Congress the authority to create lower federal courts and define their jurisdiction, which includes the power to hear cases arising under federal law, such as disputes over federal grant-in-aid funds.
explanation.Legal_Conclusion: Given that the law involves federal questions and is within the judicial power of the United States, it is constitutional. Therefore, the correct answer is A, as it accurately reflects the constitutional basis for the law.

question: A state statute makes fraud for personal financial gain a crime. The defendant was convicted of violating this statute on three separate occasions. Following his most recent conviction, he professed to have undergone a religious conversion and proclaimed himself to be the divine minister of "St. Rockport," an alleged messiah who would shortly be making his appearance on earth. The defendant solicited cash donations from the public to support his efforts to spread the word of St. Rockport and his coming appearance on earth. Following complaints by several contributors who claimed he defrauded them, the defendant was again charged with fraud under this state statute. The charge was that the defendant "should have known that his representations about St. Rockport were false and, therefore, that he made them solely to collect cash donations for his personal gain." A witness for the prosecution in the defendant's trial stated that the defendant had admitted that, at times, he had doubts about the existence of St. Rockport. The defendant was the only religious minister prosecuted for fraud under this state statute. The strongest constitutional defense that the defendant could assert would be that this prosecution

options.optionA: A. deprived him of the equal protection of the laws because other religious ministers have not been charged under this statute.
options.optionB: B. denied him procedural due process because it placed upon the defendant the burden of rebutting evidence, submitted by the state of his bad faith in raising this money.
options.optionC: C. denied him rights conferred by the obligation of contracts clause by preventing him from taking money from persons who wished to contract with him to spread the word of St. Rockport.
options.optionD: D. denied him the free exercise of religion in violation of the First and Fourteenth Amendments because it required the state to determine the truth or falsity of the content of his religious beliefs.

explanation.Legal_Concept: The Free Exercise Clause of the First Amendment and its protection against government interference with religious beliefs and practices.
explanation.Fact_Analysis: The defendant, claiming to be a divine minister, solicited donations for the alleged coming of 'St. Rockport.' He was charged with fraud under a state statute, with the prosecution arguing he should have known his representations were false. The defendant had previously been convicted of fraud and had expressed doubts about the existence of St. Rockport.
explanation.Rule_Application: The Free Exercise Clause prohibits the government from burdening an individual's exercise of their religious beliefs unless it is necessary to serve a compelling government interest. Furthermore, the government cannot assess the validity or sincerity of religious beliefs. The prosecution's case against the defendant requires evaluating the truth of his religious claims, potentially infringing upon his right to free exercise.
explanation.Legal_Conclusion: Given that the prosecution involves the state in determining the validity of the defendant's religious beliefs, the strongest constitutional defense available to the defendant is that the prosecution denies him the free exercise of religion, as protected by the First and Fourteenth Amendments, supporting option D.

question: An ordinance of a particular city requires that its mayor have continuously been a resident of the city for at least five years at the time he or she takes office. A candidate, who is thinking about running for mayor in an election that will take place next year, will have been a resident of the city for only four and one-half years at the time the mayor elected then takes office. Before he decides whether to run for the position of mayor, the candidate wants to know whether he could lawfully assume that position if he were elected. As a result, the candidate files suit in the local federal district court for a declaratory judgment that the city's five-year-residence requirement is unconstitutional and that he is entitled to a place on his political party's primary election ballot for mayor. He names the chairman of his political party as the sole defendant but does not join any election official. The chairman responds by joining the candidate in requesting the court to declare the city's residence requirement invalid. In this case, the court should

options.optionA: A. refuse to determine the merits of this suit, because there is no case or controversy.
options.optionB: B. refuse to issue such a declaratory judgment, because an issue of this kind involving only a local election does not present a substantial federal constitutional question.
options.optionC: C. issue the declaratory judgment, because a residency requirement of this type is a denial of the equal protection of the laws.
options.optionD: D. issue the declaratory judgment, because the candidate will have substantially complied with the residency requirement.

explanation.Legal_Concept: Standing and ripeness in federal court, particularly in the context of declaratory judgments and constitutional challenges to local election laws.
explanation.Fact_Analysis: The candidate seeks a declaratory judgment that the city's five-year-residence requirement for the mayor position is unconstitutional, despite not yet being barred from running or having won the election. The candidate has sued the chairman of his political party, who agrees that the court should declare the requirement invalid.
explanation.Rule_Application: For a federal court to hear a case, there must be a case or controversy, which includes the requirements of standing and ripeness. Standing requires that the plaintiff have suffered or be imminently likely to suffer an injury. Ripeness requires that the issue be ready for review, meaning the injury is not speculative or hypothetical. Additionally, the correct parties must be joined to provide relief that will redress the injury.
explanation.Legal_Conclusion: The candidate lacks standing because the issue is not yet ripe for review, as he has not yet suffered an injury and it is uncertain whether he will be barred from running or taking office. Furthermore, the candidate has not joined the correct party, as the chairman of his political party cannot provide the relief needed to redress the injury. Therefore, the court should refuse to determine the merits of this suit.

question: Radon is a harmful gas found in the soil of certain regions of the United States. A state statute requires occupants of residences with basements susceptible to the intrusion of radon to have their residences tested for the presence of radon and to take specified remedial steps if the test indicates the presence of radon above specified levels. The statute also provides that the testing for radon may be done only by testers licensed by a state agency. According to the statute, a firm may be licensed to test for radon only if it meets specified rigorous standards relating to the accuracy of its testing. These standards may easily be achieved with current technology; but the technology required to meet them is 50% more expensive than the technology required to measure radon accumulations in a slightly less accurate manner. The United States Environmental Protection Agency (EPA) does not license radon testers. However, a federal statute authorizes the EPA to advise on the accuracy of various methods of radon testing and to provide to the general public a list of testers that use methods it believes to be reasonably accurate. A recently established state firm uses a testing method that the EPA has stated is reasonably accurate. The firm is also included by the EPA on a list of testers using methods of testing it believes to be reasonably accurate. The firm applies for a state radon testing license, but its application is denied because the firm cannot demonstrate that the method of testing for radon it uses is sufficiently accurate to meet the rigorous state statutory standards. The firm sues appropriate state officials in federal court claiming that the state may not constitutionally exclude the firm from performing the required radon tests in the state. In this suit, the court will probably rule in favor of

options.optionA: A. the firm, because the full faith and credit clause of the Constitution requires the state to respect and give effect to the action of the EPA in including the firm on its list of testers that use reasonably accurate methods.
options.optionB: B. the firm, because the supremacy clause of the Constitution requires the state to respect and give effect to the action of the EPA in including the firm on its list of testers that use reasonably accurate methods.
options.optionC: C. The state, because the federal statute and the action of the EPA in including the firm on its list of testers that use reasonably accurate methods are not inconsistent with the more rigorous state licensing requirement, and that requirement is reasonably related to a legitimate public interest.
options.optionD: D. The state, because radon exposure is limited to basement areas, which, by their very nature, cannot move in interstate commerce.

explanation.Legal_Concept: The relationship between state and federal law, specifically the supremacy clause and the regulation of radon testing.
explanation.Fact_Analysis: A state statute requires radon testing for residences with basements susceptible to radon intrusion, mandating testing by state-licensed testers who meet rigorous standards. A firm, included on the EPA's list of testers using reasonably accurate methods, applies for a state license but is denied due to not meeting the state's standards.
explanation.Rule_Application: The supremacy clause does not supersede the state's licensing requirement because the federal statute does not directly regulate radon testers to the extent of licensing them, and the state's requirement is reasonably related to a legitimate public interest. The state's more rigorous standards do not conflict with the federal law, allowing the state to maintain its licensing requirement.
explanation.Legal_Conclusion: Given that the state's licensing requirement is reasonably related to a legitimate public interest and does not conflict with the federal law, the court will likely rule in favor of the state, supporting option C.

question: According to a state law, state employees may be fired only "for good cause." A woman who was a resident and an employee of the state was summarily fired on the sole ground that she had notified federal officials that the state was not following federal rules governing the administration of certain federally funded state programs on which she worked. The state denied the woman's request for a hearing to allow her to contest the charge. There is no record of any other state employee having been terminated for this reason. In a suit to enjoin the state from firing her, which of the following claims provides the LEAST support for the woman's suit?\

options.optionA: A. Firing her unconstitutionally abridges her freedom of speech.
options.optionB: B. Firing her unconstitutionally denies her a privilege or immunity of state citizenship protected by Article IV.
options.optionC: C. Firing her violates the supremacy clause of Article VI because it interferes with the enforcement of federal rules.
options.optionD: D. Firing her without affording an opportunity for a hearing is an unconstitutional denial of procedural due process.

explanation.Legal_Concept: The application of the privileges and immunities clause of Article IV, Section 2, Clause 1 of the Constitution in the context of state employment and residency.
explanation.Fact_Analysis: The woman is a resident and employee of the state, and she was fired for notifying federal officials about the state's non-compliance with federal rules. The privileges and immunities clause is considered in relation to her residency status.
explanation.Rule_Application: The privileges and immunities clause of Article IV, Section 2, Clause 1 only applies to actions by a state that discriminate against citizens of other states. Since the woman is a resident of the state that employed her, this clause does not apply to her situation.
explanation.Legal_Conclusion: Given that the woman is a citizen of the state that employed her, the privileges and immunities clause of Article IV does not provide a basis for her claim. Therefore, option B provides the least support for the woman's suit.

question: In response to the need for additional toxic waste landfills in a state, the state's legislature enacted a law authorizing a state agency to establish five new state-owned and state-operated toxic waste landfills. The law provided that the agency would decide the locations and sizes of the landfills after an investigation of all potential sites and a determination that the particular sites chosen would not endanger public health and would be consistent with the public welfare. A community in the state was scheduled for inspection by the agency as a potential toxic waste landfill site. Because the community's residents obtained most of their drinking water from an aquifer that ran under the entire community, a citizens' group, made up of residents of that community, sued the appropriate officials of the agency in federal court. The group sought a declaratory judgment that the selection of the community as the site of a toxic waste landfill would be unconstitutional and an injunction preventing the agency from selecting the community as a site for such a landfill. The agency officials moved to dismiss. Which of the following is the most appropriate basis for the court to dismiss this suit?

options.optionA: A. The case presents a nonjusticiable political question.
options.optionB: B. The interest of the state in obtaining suitable sites for toxic waste landfills is sufficiently compelling to justify the selection of the community as a location for such a facility.
options.optionC: C. The Eleventh Amendment bars suits of this kind in the federal courts.
options.optionD: D. The case is not ripe for a decision on the merits.

explanation.Legal_Concept: Ripeness doctrine in federal courts, specifically the requirement that a case must present a real and immediate controversy to be justiciable.
explanation.Fact_Analysis: The state agency is conducting an inspection of the community as a potential site for a toxic waste landfill, but no decision has been made, and it is unclear whether or when the community would be selected. The residents' risk of harm is contingent on the agency's future decision.
explanation.Rule_Application: For a case to be ripe for adjudication, it must present a real and immediate controversy, rather than a speculative or hypothetical one. The ripeness doctrine requires that the parties' interests be sufficiently direct and immediate, and that the case not be based on uncertain or future events.
explanation.Legal_Conclusion: Given that the agency's inspection does not itself pose an immediate risk of harm to the residents, and the selection of the community as a landfill site is uncertain and contingent on future events, the case is not ripe for a decision on the merits. Therefore, the most appropriate basis for the court to dismiss this suit is that the case is not ripe, supporting option D.

question: National statistics revealed a dramatic increase in the number of elementary and secondary school students bringing controlled substances to school for sale. In response, Congress enacted a statute requiring each state legislature to enact a state law making it a crime for any person to sell, within 1,000 feet of any elementary or secondary school, any controlled substance that had previously been transported in interstate commerce. Is the federal statute constitutional?

options.optionA: A. No, because Congress has no authority to require a state legislature to enact any specified legislation.
options.optionB: B. No, because the sale of a controlled substance in close proximity to a school does not have a sufficiently close nexus to interstate commerce to justify its regulation by Congress.
options.optionC: C. Yes, because it contains a jurisdictional provision that will ensure, on a case-by-case basis, that any particular controlled substance subject to the terms of this statute will, in fact, affect interstate commerce.
options.optionD: D. Yes, because Congress possesses broad authority under both the general welfare clause and the commerce clause to regulate any activities affecting education that also have, in inseverable aggregates, a substantial effect on interstate commerce.

explanation.Legal_Concept: The limits of Congressional power under the Tenth Amendment, specifically the prohibition against compelling states to enact or administer federal law.
explanation.Fact_Analysis: Congress enacted a statute requiring state legislatures to enact a law criminalizing the sale of controlled substances within 1,000 feet of schools, in response to a national increase in such sales. The question is whether this federal statute is constitutional.
explanation.Rule_Application: The Tenth Amendment, as interpreted by the U.S. Supreme Court in New York v. United States, prohibits Congress from requiring states to enact laws or administer federal law. This principle of federalism limits Congressional power to regulate state activities directly.
explanation.Legal_Conclusion: Given the Supreme Court's ruling in New York v. United States, the federal statute requiring states to enact a specific law is unconstitutional. Therefore, the correct answer is that the statute is not constitutional because Congress has no authority to require a state legislature to enact specified legislation.

question: A brother and a sister acquired as joint tenants a twenty-acre parcel of land called Greenacre. They contributed equally to the purchase price. Several years later, the brother proposed that they build an apartment development on Greenacre. The sister rejected the proposal but orally agreed that the brother could go ahead on his own on the northerly half of Greenacre and she could do what she wished with the southerly half of Greenacre. The brother proceeded to build an apartment development on, and generally developed and improved, the northerly ten acres of Greenacre. The sister orally permitted the southerly ten acres of Greenacre to be used by the Audubon Society as a nature preserve. The brother died, leaving his entire estate to his son. The will named the sister as executrix of his will, but she refused to serve. In an appropriate action to determine the respective interests of the sister and the brother's son in Greenacre, if the son is adjudged to be the owner of the northerly ten acres of Greenacre, the most likely reason for the judgment will be that

options.optionA: A. the close blood relationship between the brother and sister removes the necessity to comply with the Statute of Frauds.
options.optionB: B. the sister's conduct during the brother's lifetime estops her from asserting title to the northerly half of Greenacre.
options.optionC: C. the joint tenancy was terminated by the oral agreement of the brother and the sister at the time it was made.
options.optionD: D. the sister had a fiduciary obligation to her nephew by reason of her being named executrix of the brother's will.

explanation.Legal_Concept: Termination of a joint tenancy and the application of estoppel in property law.
explanation.Fact_Analysis: The brother and sister acquired Greenacre as joint tenants, but later orally agreed to divide its use, with the brother developing the northerly half and the sister allowing the southerly half to be used by the Audubon Society as a nature preserve. The sister's actions and declarations may have effectively severed the joint tenancy or estopped her from claiming title to the northerly half.
explanation.Rule_Application: A joint tenancy can be terminated by partition or severance. Severance can occur through an inter vivos conveyance or mortgage by one joint tenant. Additionally, estoppel may apply if one party's actions or declarations induce another party to act in reliance on those representations, to their detriment. In this case, the sister's agreement and subsequent actions may have estopped her from asserting title to the northerly half of Greenacre.
explanation.Legal_Conclusion: Given the sister's conduct and declarations regarding the use of Greenacre, if the brother's son is adjudged to be the owner of the northerly ten acres, it will most likely be because the sister's actions estop her from asserting title to that portion of the property, supporting option B.

question: A brother and sister acquired as joint tenants a twenty-acre parcel of land called Greenacre. They contributed equally to the purchase price. Several years later, the brother proposed that they build an apartment development on Greenacre. The sister rejected the proposal but orally agreed that the brother could go ahead on his own on the northerly half of Greenacre and she could do what she wished with the southerly half of Greenacre. The brother proceeded to build an apartment development on, and generally developed and improved, the northerly ten acres of Greenacre. The sister orally permitted the southerly ten acres of Greenacre to be used by the Audubon Society as a nature preserve. The brother died, leaving his entire estate to his son. The will named the sister as executrix of his will, but she refused to serve. In an appropriate action to determine the respective interests of the sister and the brother's son in Greenacre, if the sister is adjudged to be the owner of all of Greenacre, the most likely reason for the judgment will be that

options.optionA: A. the Statute of Frauds prevents the proof of the sister's oral agreement.
options.optionB: B. the brother could not unilaterally sever the joint tenancy.
options.optionC: C. the sister's nomination as executrix of the brother's estate does not prevent her from asserting her claim against the son.
options.optionD: D. the record title of the joint tenancy in Greenacre can be changed only by a duly recorded instrument.

explanation.Legal_Concept: Joint tenancy, severance, and the Statute of Frauds in the context of real property ownership.
explanation.Fact_Analysis: The brother and sister acquired Greenacre as joint tenants, contributing equally to the purchase price. The sister orally agreed to allow the brother to develop the northerly half, while she permitted the southerly half to be used as a nature preserve by the Audubon Society. The brother died, leaving his estate to his son, and the sister was named executrix but refused to serve.
explanation.Rule_Application: A joint tenancy can be terminated by partition or severance. Severance occurs when one joint tenant makes an inter vivos conveyance of their interest. However, the Statute of Frauds requires that any conveyance of real property must be in writing to be enforceable. In this case, the sister's oral agreement with the Audubon Society does not meet the Statute of Frauds' requirements, and thus does not constitute a valid conveyance that would sever the joint tenancy.
explanation.Legal_Conclusion: Given that the sister's oral agreement does not satisfy the Statute of Frauds, it is likely that the court will find that the joint tenancy was not severed, and the sister will be adjudged the owner of all of Greenacre due to the right of survivorship.

question: In 1960, the owner in fee simple of Barrenacres, a large, undeveloped tract of land, granted an easement to the Water District "to install, inspect, repair, maintain, and replace pipes" within a properly delineated strip of land twenty feet wide across Barrenacres. The easement permitted the Water District to enter Barrenacres for only the stated purposes. The Water District promptly and properly recorded the deed. In 1961, the Water District installed a water main which crossed Barrenacres within the described strip; the Water District has not since entered Barrenacres. In 1965, the landowner sold Barrenacres to a purchaser, but the deed, which was promptly and properly recorded, failed to refer to the Water District easement. The purchaser built his home on Barrenacres in 1965, and since that time he has planted and maintained, at great expense in money, time, and effort, a formal garden area which covers, among other areas, the surface of the twenty-foot easement strip. In 2006, the Water District proposed to excavate the entire length of its main in order to inspect, repair, and replace the main, to the extent necessary. At a public meeting, at which the purchaser was present, the Water District announced its plans and declared its intent to do as little damage as possible to any property involved. The purchaser objected to the Water District plans. Assume that the purchaser reserved his rights and after the Water District completed its work sued for the $5,000 in damages he suffered by reason of the Water District entry. The purchaser's attempt to secure damages probably wil

options.optionA: A. succeed, because his deed from the owner did not mention the easement.
options.optionB: B. succeed, because of an implied obligation imposed on the Water District to restore the surface to its condition prior to entry.
options.optionC: C. fail, because of the public interest in maintaining a continuous water supply.
options.optionD: D. fail, because the Water District acted within its rights.

explanation.Legal_Concept: Easement rights and obligations, particularly the right of the easement holder to enter the land for repairs and maintenance.
explanation.Fact_Analysis: The Water District holds an easement for the purpose of installing, inspecting, repairing, maintaining, and replacing pipes within a twenty-foot wide strip of land across Barrenacres. The purchaser, despite knowledge of the easement, planted and maintained a garden area covering the easement strip. The Water District announced plans to excavate and repair the main, prompting the purchaser's objection.
explanation.Rule_Application: The holder of an easement has the right to enter the land to make repairs, and must reasonably restore the land to its original condition after the repairs. However, this obligation does not extend to restoring alterations or obstructions made by the landowner, such as the purchaser's garden, which unreasonably obstructs the easement.
explanation.Legal_Conclusion: Given that the Water District acted within its easement rights by entering the land to make repairs, and is not obligated to restore the purchaser's garden, the purchaser's attempt to secure damages will likely fail. Therefore, the correct answer is D, as the Water District acted within its rights.

question: In 1990, the owner in fee simple absolute, conveyed Stoneacre, a five-acre tract of land. The relevant, operative words of the deed conveyed to "the church [a duly organized religious body having power to hold property] for the life of my son and from and after the death of my said son to all of my grandchildren and their heirs and assigns in equal shares; provided, the church shall use the premises for church purposes only." In an existing building on Stoneacre, the church immediately began to conduct religious services and other activities normally associated with a church. In 2005, the church granted a neighbor a right to remove sand and gravel from a one-half acre portion of Stoneacre upon the payment of royalty. The neighbor has regularly removed sand and gravel since 2005 and paid royalty to the church. The church has continued to conduct religious services and other church activities on Stoneacre. All four of the living grandchildren of the grantor joined by a guardian ad litem to represent unborn grandchildren, instituted suit against the church and the neighbor seeking damages for the removal of sand and gravel and an injunction preventing further acts of removal. There is no applicable statute. Which of the following best describes the likely disposition of this lawsuit?

options.optionA: A. The plaintiffs should succeed, because the interest of the church terminated with the first removal of sand and gravel.
options.optionB: B. The church and the neighbor should be enjoined, and damages should be recovered but impounded for future distribution.
options.optionC: C. The injunction should be granted, but damages should be denied, because the grantor and his son are not parties to the action.
options.optionD: D. Damages should be awarded, but the injunction should be denied.

explanation.Legal_Concept: Life estates and remainders in property law, specifically the duties of a life tenant and the rights of remaindermen.
explanation.Fact_Analysis: The church holds a life estate in Stoneacre, measured by the life of the grantor's son, with the grandchildren holding remainders. The church has allowed a neighbor to remove sand and gravel from the property and has continued to use the property for church purposes.
explanation.Rule_Application: A life tenant has a duty not to commit voluntary or permissive waste relevant to the property during its life tenancy. Voluntary waste includes affirmative acts that damage the land, such as changing its basic use or allowing the removal of resources. The life tenant is liable to the remaindermen for any waste during their life tenancy.
explanation.Legal_Conclusion: The church's actions constitute voluntary waste, making it liable to the remaindermen (the grandchildren). An injunction is warranted to prevent further waste, and damages should be awarded but impounded for future distribution, supporting option B.

question: By her validly executed will, a woman devised a certain tract of land to her son for his life with remainder to such of his children as should be living at his death, "Provided, however, that no such child of my son shall mortgage or sell, or attempt to mortgage or sell, his or her interest in the property prior to attaining 25 years of age: and, if any such child of my son shall violate this provision, then upon such violation his or her interest shall pass to and become the property of the remaining children of my son then living, share and share alike." The woman's will included an identical provision for each of her four other children concerning four other tracts of land. The residuary clause of the will gave the residuary estate to the woman's five children equally. The woman died and was survived by the five children named in her will and by eleven grandchildren. Several additional grandchildren have since been born. In an action for a declaration of rights, it was claimed that the attempted gifts to the woman's grandchildren were entirely void and that the interests following the life estates to the woman's children passed to the children absolutely by the residuary clause. Assuming that the action was properly brought with all necessary parties and with a guardian ad litem appointed to represent the interests of unborn and infant grandchildren, the decision should be that

options.optionA: A. the attempted gifts to grandchildren are void under the Rule Against Perpetuities.
options.optionB: B. the attempted gifts to grandchildren are void as unlawful restraints on alienation.
options.optionC: C. the provisions concerning grandchildren are valid and will be upheld according to their terms.
options.optionD: D. even if the provisions against sale or mortgage by the grandchildren are void, the remainders to grandchildren are otherwise valid and will be given effect.

explanation.Legal_Concept: The Rule Against Perpetuities (RAP) and its application to testamentary gifts, specifically the validity of remainders and the restraint on alienation.
explanation.Fact_Analysis: The woman's will devises a tract of land to her son for life, with a remainder to his children, subject to a condition that they cannot mortgage or sell their interest before reaching 25 years of age. The will includes an identical provision for each of her four other children concerning four other tracts of land.
explanation.Rule_Application: The RAP requires that an interest must vest, if at all, not later than 21 years after some life in being at the creation of the interest. The devise of a life estate to the son is valid, and the remainder to his children is vested because all his children will have been born within 21 years of his death. However, the clause restricting the grandchildren's ability to sell or mortgage before age 25 violates the RAP, as it may not vest within the required time frame.
explanation.Legal_Conclusion: The attempted gifts to grandchildren are not entirely void, but the provisions against sale or mortgage by the grandchildren are void as a violation of the RAP. The remainders to grandchildren are otherwise valid and will be given effect, supporting option D.

question: The following events took place in a state that does not recognize common-law marriage. The state does recognize the common-law estate of tenancy by the entirety and has no statute on the subject. A man and woman, who were never formally married, lived together over a seven-year period. During this time the woman identified herself using the man's last name with the knowledge and consent of the man. The couple maintained several charge accounts at retail stores under the husband's last name, and they filed joint income tax returns using his last name for both of them. Within this period the man decided to buy a home. The deed was in proper form and identified the grantees as "Mr. and Mrs. [last name], and their heirs and assigns forever as tenants by the entirety." The man made a down payment of $10,000, and gave a note and mortgage for the unpaid balance. The couple signed the note and mortgage as husband and wife. The man made monthly payments as they became due until he and the woman had a disagreement and he abandoned her and the house. The woman then made the payments for three months. She then brought an action against the man for partition of the land in question. The prayer for partition should be

options.optionA: A. denied, because a tenant by the entirety has no right to partition.
options.optionB: B. denied, because the man has absolute title to the property.
options.optionC: C. granted, because the tenancy by the entirety that was created by the deed was severed when the man abandoned the woman.
options.optionD: D. granted, because the estate created by the deed was not a tenancy by the entirety.

explanation.Legal_Concept: Tenancy by the entirety, a form of concurrent estate in real property that requires a marital relationship between the co-owners.
explanation.Fact_Analysis: A man and woman, who were never formally married, lived together for seven years, maintained joint accounts, and filed joint tax returns. They purchased a home with a deed identifying them as 'Mr. and Mrs.' and their heirs and assigns forever as tenants by the entirety. The man made the down payment and initial mortgage payments, but the woman made payments for three months after the man abandoned her.
explanation.Rule_Application: A tenancy by the entirety requires the presence of several unities, including the unity of person, which necessitates that the tenants be married. Since the man and woman were not married, they could not have created a tenancy by the entirety. The woman's interest in the property is not negated by their mistaken assertion of a tenancy by the entirety in the deed.
explanation.Legal_Conclusion: Given that the couple was not married and therefore could not have created a tenancy by the entirety, the woman has a right to seek partition of the property. Thus, the prayer for partition should be granted, supporting option D.

question: A grantor conveyed a farm "to my daughter, her heirs and assigns, so long as the premises are used for residential and farm purposes, then to her son and his heirs and assigns." The jurisdiction in which the farm is located has adopted the common-law Rule Against Perpetuities unmodified by statute. As a consequence of the conveyance, the grantor’s interest in the farm is

options.optionA: A. nothing.
options.optionB: B. a possibility of reverter.
options.optionC: C. a right of entry for condition broken.
options.optionD: D. a reversion in fee simple absolute.

explanation.Legal_Concept: The Rule Against Perpetuities and its impact on the grantor's interest in a conveyance, specifically the distinction between a fee simple determinable and a possibility of reverter.
explanation.Fact_Analysis: The grantor conveyed a farm to her daughter with the condition that it be used for residential and farm purposes, and upon failure of this condition, the farm would pass to her son. The jurisdiction follows the common-law Rule Against Perpetuities without modification.
explanation.Rule_Application: A fee simple determinable is an estate that can run indefinitely but is subject to termination by a later event. The grantor retains a possibility of reverter when granting a fee simple determinable. The Rule Against Perpetuities invalidates the grant to the son, making the grantor's interest a possibility of reverter.
explanation.Legal_Conclusion: Given that the daughter's interest is a fee simple determinable due to the conditional use of the land, and the Rule Against Perpetuities invalidates the subsequent grant to her son, the grantor's interest is a possibility of reverter, supporting option B.

question: A tract of land was conveyed to a woman and a man by a deed which, in the jurisdiction in which the land is situated, created a co-tenancy in equal shares and with the right of survivorship. The jurisdiction has no statute directly applicable to any of the problems posed. The woman, by deed, conveyed "my undivided one-half interest in [the land]" to her friend. The woman has since died. In an appropriate action between the friend and the man in which title to the land is at issue, the man will

options.optionA: A. prevail, because he is the sole owner of the land.
options.optionB: B. prevail if, but only if, the co-tenancy created in the woman and the man was a tenancy by the entirety.
options.optionC: C. not prevail if he had knowledge of the conveyance prior to the woman's death.
options.optionD: D. not prevail, because the friend and the man own the tract of land as tenants in common.

explanation.Legal_Concept: Distinction between a tenancy by the entirety and a joint tenancy, particularly regarding the severance of interests and the right of survivorship.
explanation.Fact_Analysis: A tract of land was conveyed to a woman and a man with the right of survivorship. The woman then conveyed her undivided one-half interest to her friend. The woman has since died, and the man's claim to the land is at issue.
explanation.Rule_Application: A tenancy by the entirety can only be severed by divorce, death of one spouse, a creditor of both spouses, or mutual agreement. In contrast, a joint tenancy can be severed by one tenant making an inter vivos conveyance, resulting in the transferred interest becoming that of a tenant in common.
explanation.Legal_Conclusion: The man will prevail if, but only if, the co-tenancy created in the woman and the man was a tenancy by the entirety, as this would prevent the woman from severing the tenancy through her conveyance to her friend, supporting option B.

question: Meadowview is a large tract of undeveloped land. The man who owns Meadowview prepared a development plan creating 200 house lots in Meadowview with the necessary streets and public areas. The plan was fully approved and duly recorded. However, construction of the streets has not yet begun, and none of the streets can be opened as public ways until they are completed in accordance with the applicable ordinances. College Avenue, a street in the Meadowview development, abuts a parcel of land that is adjacent to Meadowview and owned by a pharmacist. This parcel has no access to any public way except a poorly developed road that is inconvenient and cannot be used without great expense. The pharmacist sold the parcel to a friend. The description used in the deed was the same as that used in prior deeds except that the portion of the description which formerly said, "thence by land of Meadowview, north-easterly a distance of 200 feet, more or less," was changed to "thence by College Avenue as laid out on the Plan of Meadowview," with full reference to the plan and its recording data. The friend now seeks a building permit that shows she intends to use College Avenue for access to her parcel of land. The man objects to the granting of a building permit on the grounds that he has never granted any right to the pharmacist or her friend to use College Avenue. There are no governing statutes or ordinances relating to the problem. The man brings an appropriate action in which the right of the friend to use College Avenue without an express grant from the man is at issue. The best argument for the man in this action is that

options.optionA: A. the friend’s right must await the action of appropriate public authorities to open College Avenue as a public street, since no private easements arose by implication.
options.optionB: B. the Statute of Frauds prevents the introduction of evidence which might prove the necessity for the friend to use College Avenue.
options.optionC: C. the friend’s right to use College Avenue is restricted to the assertion of a way by necessity, and the facts preclude the success of such a claim.
options.optionD: D. the friend would be unjustly enriched if he were permitted to use College Avenue.

explanation.Legal_Concept: Easements by implication, specifically the requirements for establishing an easement by necessity or previous use by a common owner.
explanation.Fact_Analysis: The parcel of land in question has access to a poorly developed road, which, although inconvenient, constitutes a means of access. The development plan for Meadowview, including College Avenue, has been approved and recorded, but construction has not begun, and the streets cannot be opened as public ways until completed in accordance with applicable ordinances.
explanation.Rule_Application: An easement by necessity arises when a property is landlocked, requiring access across another's land. However, if any means of access exists, even if inconvenient, there is no necessity, and no easement will be implied. Since the parcel has access via the poorly developed road, an easement by necessity cannot be implied. Additionally, an easement by previous use requires a common owner who used an apparent, continuous, and reasonably necessary route across the plots, which is not indicated in the facts.
explanation.Legal_Conclusion: Given that the parcel is not landlocked and has an existing, albeit inconvenient, means of access, and that the requirements for an easement by previous use are not met, the man's best argument is that the friend has not obtained an easement by implication, supporting answer A.

question: The owner in fee simple of Highacre, an apartment house property, entered into an enforceable written agreement to sell Highacre to a buyer. The agreement provided that a good and marketable title was to be conveyed free and clear of all encumbrances. However, the agreement was silent as to the risk of fire prior to closing, and there is no applicable statute in the state where the land is located. The premises were not insured. The day before the scheduled closing date, Highacre was wholly destroyed by fire. When the buyer refused to close, the seller brought an action for specific performance. If the seller prevails, the most likely reason will be that

options.optionA: A. the failure of the buyer to insure his interest as the purchaser of Highacre precludes any relief for him.
options.optionB: B. the remedy at law is inadequate in actions concerning real estate contracts, and either party is entitled to specific performance.
options.optionC: C. equity does not permit consideration of surrounding circumstances in actions concerning real estate contracts.
options.optionD: D. the doctrine of equitable conversion applies.

explanation.Legal_Concept: The doctrine of equitable conversion in real estate transactions, specifically the allocation of risk of loss prior to closing.
explanation.Fact_Analysis: The seller and buyer entered into a written agreement for the sale of Highacre, an apartment house property, with the agreement silent on the risk of fire prior to closing and no applicable state statute. The premises were uninsured and were wholly destroyed by fire the day before the scheduled closing date.
explanation.Rule_Application: Under the doctrine of equitable conversion, once a real estate contract is signed, the risk of loss for any damage to the property that occurs before closing and is not the seller's fault falls on the buyer. This principle applies regardless of the seller's physical possession of the land, as title is considered 'converted' to the buyer through equitable principles.
explanation.Legal_Conclusion: Given that the buyer bears the risk of loss after contracting and the facts do not indicate the seller was responsible for the fire damage, the seller will most likely prevail due to the application of the doctrine of equitable conversion, supporting answer D.

question: A landlord, the owner in fee simple of a small farm consisting of thirty acres of land improved with a house and several outbuildings, leased the same to a tenant for a ten-year period. After two years had expired, the government condemned twenty acres of the property and allocated the compensation award to the landlord and tenant according to their respective interest so taken. It so happened, however, that the twenty acres taken embraced all of the farm's tillable land, leaving only the house, outbuildings, and a small woodlot. There is no applicable statute in the jurisdiction where the property is located nor any provision in the lease relating to condemnation. The tenant quit possession, and the landlord brought suit against him to recover rent. The landlord will

options.optionA: A. lose, because there has been a frustration of purpose which excuses the tenant from further performance of his contract to pay rent.
options.optionB: B. lose, because there has been a breach of the implied covenant of quiet enjoyment by the landlord's inability to provide the tenant with possession of the whole of the property for the entire term.
options.optionC: C. win, because of the implied warranty on the part of the tenant to return the demised premises in the same condition at the end of the term as they were at the beginning.
options.optionD: D. win, because the relationship of landlord and tenant was unaffected by the condemnation, thus leaving the tenant still obligated to pay rent.

explanation.Legal_Concept: The effect of government condemnation on a lease agreement, specifically the distinction between partial and complete takings.
explanation.Fact_Analysis: The government condemned twenty acres of a thirty-acre farm, leaving the house, outbuildings, and a small woodlot. The tenant had leased the property for ten years but quit possession after the condemnation. The landlord seeks to recover rent from the tenant.
explanation.Rule_Application: In the event of a partial taking, where only part of the leased property is condemned, the tenant remains responsible for paying rent but only in proportion to the land not taken. The tenant also shares in the government's compensation for the taken land to the extent of their rent liability. Since only twenty acres were taken, leaving ten acres, the lease remains in effect, and the tenant's obligation to pay rent continues.
explanation.Legal_Conclusion: Given that the condemnation was a partial taking and the lease agreement did not address condemnation, the tenant's lease is still in effect. Therefore, the landlord will win the suit to recover rent, supporting option D.

question: A diner containing a drive-in hamburger and ice cream stand recently opened for business in a suburban town. The diner's business hours are from 9:00 a.m. to midnight. It is in an area that for fifteen years has been zoned for small retail businesses, apartment buildings, and one-and two-family residences. The zoning code specifies that "small retail business" includes "businesses where food and drink are dispensed for consumption on the premises." The diner was the first drive-in in the town. For seven years, a husband and wife have owned and lived in their single-family residence, which is across the street from the diner. The diner is heavily patronized during the day and night by high school students. The noise and lights of the cars, the lights illuminating the diner's parking lot, and the noise from the loudspeaker of the ordering system prevented the homeowners from sleeping before midnight. Paper cups, napkins, and other items from the drive-in are regularly blown into the homeowners' front yard by the prevailing wind. The traffic to and from the diner is so heavy on the street in front of their house that the homeowners are afraid to allow their small children to play in the front yard. The homeowners have asserted a claim against the diner based on private nuisance. The most likely effect of the fact that the homeowners were in the area before the diner is that it

options.optionA: A. requires that the homeowners' interest be given priority.
options.optionB: B. is irrelevant because of the zoning ordinance.
options.optionC: C. is irrelevant because conforming economic uses are given priority.
options.optionD: D. is some, but not controlling, evidence.

explanation.Legal_Concept: Private nuisance, specifically the determination of whether a defendant's use of neighboring land substantially and unreasonably interferes with the use and enjoyment of the plaintiff's property.
explanation.Fact_Analysis: The homeowners have lived in their single-family residence for seven years, across the street from a newly opened diner that operates as a drive-in. The diner's operation causes noise, light, and litter disturbances that affect the homeowners' ability to sleep and use their front yard, prompting a claim of private nuisance.
explanation.Rule_Application: In determining a private nuisance claim, factors such as the character of the locality, the nature, extent, and frequency of the harm, and the utility and social value of the activity involved are considered. Priority of occupation is not controlling, and zoning ordinances, while relevant, do not necessarily determine the appropriateness of an activity in a nuisance claim.
explanation.Legal_Conclusion: The fact that the homeowners were in the area before the diner is some, but not controlling, evidence in determining whether the diner's operation constitutes a private nuisance. This consideration is one of several factors to be weighed in deciding whether the defendant's use of neighboring land substantially and unreasonably interferes with the plaintiff's property use and enjoyment.

question: The following facts concern a tract of land in a state which follows general United States law. Each instrument is in proper form, recorded, marital property rights were waived when necessary, and each person named was adult and competent at the time of the transaction. I. In 1970 Oleg, the owner, conveyed his interest in fee simple "to my brothers Bob and Bill, their heirs and assigns as joint tenants with the right of survivorship." II. In 1980 Bob died, devising his interest to his only child, "Charles, for life, and then to Charles' son, Sam, for life, and then to Sam's children, their heirs and assigns." III. In 2000 Bill died, devising his interest "to my friend, Frank, his heirs and assigns." IV. In 2002 Frank conveyed by quitclaim deed "to Paul, his heirs and assigns whatever right, title and interest I own." Paul has never married. Paul has contracted to convey marketable record title in the land to Patrick. Can Paul do so?

options.optionA: A. Yes, without joinder of any other person in the conveyance.
options.optionB: B. Yes, if Charles, Sam, and Sam's only child (Gene, aged 25) will join in the conveyance.
options.optionC: C. No, regardless of who joins in the conveyance, because Sam may have additional children whose interests cannot be defeated.
options.optionD: D. No, regardless of who joins in the conveyance, because a title acquired by quitclaim deed is impliedly unmerchantable.

explanation.Legal_Concept: Joint tenancy, right of survivorship, and the implications of conveyances and devises on property interests.
explanation.Fact_Analysis: Oleg conveyed the property to Bob and Bill as joint tenants with the right of survivorship. Upon Bob's death, his interest automatically passed to Bill due to the joint tenancy. Bill then devised his entire interest to Frank, who later conveyed it to Paul.
explanation.Rule_Application: In a joint tenancy with the right of survivorship, when one joint tenant dies, their interest automatically passes to the remaining joint tenant(s), regardless of any provisions in their will. Once Bill became the sole owner, he was free to devise his entire interest to Frank, and subsequently, Frank could convey the property to Paul without any restrictions.
explanation.Legal_Conclusion: Given that Paul is now the sole owner of the property, having acquired it through a valid conveyance from Frank, he can transfer his interest without needing to join any other parties in the conveyance, making option A the correct answer.

question: Homer conveyed his home to wife, Wanda, for life, remainder to his daughter, Dixie. There was a $20,000 mortgage on the home, requiring monthly payment covering interest to date plus a portion of the principal. Which of the following statements about the monthly payment is correct?`

options.optionA: A. Wanda must pay the full monthly payment.
options.optionB: B. Wanda must pay a portion of the monthly payment based on an apportionment of the value between Wanda's life estate and Dixie's remainder.
options.optionC: C. Wanda must pay the portion of the monthly payment which represents interest.
options.optionD: D. Dixie must pay the full monthly payment.

explanation.Legal_Concept: Life estates and remainders in property law, specifically the duties of a life tenant regarding mortgage payments.
explanation.Fact_Analysis: Homer conveyed his home to Wanda for life, with a remainder to his daughter Dixie. The home has a $20,000 mortgage requiring monthly payments covering interest and principal.
explanation.Rule_Application: A life tenant has a duty not to commit permissive waste, which includes paying interest on any mortgage. However, the life tenant is not obligated to pay the principal portion of the mortgage payments. In contrast, the holder of the remainder is responsible for the principal portion.
explanation.Legal_Conclusion: Given Wanda's life estate and the duty not to commit permissive waste, she is only obligated to pay the interest portion of the monthly mortgage payments, making option C the correct answer.

question: Assume for the purposes of these questions that you are counsel to the state legislative committee that is responsible for real estate laws in your state. The committee wants you to draft a statute governing the recording of deeds that fixes priorities of title, as reflected on the public record, as definitely as possible. Which of the following, divorced from other policy considerations, would best accomplish this particular result?

options.optionA: A. Eliminate the requirement of witnesses to deeds
options.optionB: B. Make time of recording the controlling factor
options.optionC: C. Make irrebuttable the declarations in the deeds that valuable consideration was paid
options.optionD: D. Make the protection of bona fide purchasers the controlling factor

explanation.Legal_Concept: Priorities of title in real estate law, specifically the role of recording statutes in determining title priority.
explanation.Fact_Analysis: The state legislative committee seeks to draft a statute governing the recording of deeds to fix priorities of title as definitely as possible. The goal is to minimize ambiguity in determining title priority based on the public record.
explanation.Rule_Application: Recording statutes can be categorized as race (time-based), notice (based on knowledge of previous purchasers), or race-notice (a combination of the two). A time-based approach, where priority is determined solely by the time of recording, eliminates the need for extrinsic evidence and provides a clear, objective standard for fixing priorities.
explanation.Legal_Conclusion: Given the objective of fixing priorities as definitely as possible, making time of recording the controlling factor is the most effective approach. This method simplifies the determination of title priority, reducing the need for consideration of additional factual evidence. Therefore, option B is the correct answer.

question: A seller and a buyer execute an agreement for the sale of real property on September 1, 2001. The jurisdiction in which the property is located recognized the principle of equitable conversion and has no statute pertinent to this problem. Assume for this question only that the seller dies before closing and his will leaves his personal property to a friend and his real property to his sister. There being no breach of the agreement by either party, which of the following is correct?

options.optionA: A. Death, an eventuality for which the parties could have provided, terminates the agreement if they did not so provide.
options.optionB: B. The sister is entitled to the proceeds of the sale when it closes, because the doctrine of equitable conversion does not apply to these circumstances.
options.optionC: C. The friend is entitled to the proceeds of the sale when it closes.
options.optionD: D. Title was rendered unmarketable by the seller's death.

explanation.Legal_Concept: The doctrine of equitable conversion in real estate transactions, specifically its application to the distribution of sale proceeds upon the seller's death before closing.
explanation.Fact_Analysis: The seller and buyer executed a sale agreement for real property, and before closing, the seller died, leaving his real property to his sister and personal property to a friend. The jurisdiction recognizes the principle of equitable conversion.
explanation.Rule_Application: Under the doctrine of equitable conversion, once the contract is signed, the risk of loss for any damage to the property falls on the buyer, and title to the property is equitably converted to the buyer. Upon the seller's death, the estate has no interest in the real property but retains an interest in the sale proceeds, which are considered personal property.
explanation.Legal_Conclusion: Given that the seller's personal property, including the right to payment for the contracted property, was left to the friend, the friend is entitled to the sale proceeds at closing, supporting option C.

question: A landowner holds title in fee simple to a tract of 1,500 acres. He desires to develop the entire tract as a golf course, country club, and residential subdivision. He contemplates forming a corporation to own and to operate the golf course and country club; the stock in the corporation will be distributed to the owners of lots in the residential portions of the subdivision, but no obligation to issue the stock is to ripen until all the residential lots are sold. The price of the lots is intended to return enough money to compensate the landowner for the raw land, development costs (including the building of the golf course and the country club facilities), and developer's profit, if all of the lots are sold. The landowner's market analyses indicate that he must create a scheme of development that will offer prospective purchasers (and their lawyers) a very high order of assurance that several aspects will be clearly established: I. Aside from the country club and golf course, there will be no land use other than for residential use and occupancy in the 1,500 acres. II. The residents of the subdivision will have unambiguous rights and access to the club and golf course facilities. III. Each lot owner must have an unambiguous right to transfer his lot to a purchaser with all original benefits. IV. Each lot owner must be obligated to pay annual dues to a pro rata share (based on the number of lots) of the club's annual operating deficit (whether or not such owner desires to make use of club and course facilities). In the context of all aspects of the scheme, which of the following will offer the best chance of implementing the requirement that each lot owner pay annual dues to support the club and golf course?

options.optionA: A. Covenant
options.optionB: B. Easement
options.optionC: C. Mortgage
options.optionD: D. Personal contractual obligation by each purchaser

explanation.Legal_Concept: The implementation of a scheme for a residential subdivision and country club development, specifically focusing on the mechanism for ensuring lot owners' payment of annual dues to support the club and golf course.
explanation.Fact_Analysis: The landowner aims to develop 1,500 acres into a golf course, country club, and residential subdivision, with the intention of distributing corporation stock to lot owners once all lots are sold. The development requires a high level of assurance for prospective purchasers regarding aspects such as land use, access to facilities, transfer of benefits, and payment of annual dues.
explanation.Rule_Application: A covenant is the most suitable mechanism for implementing the requirement that each lot owner pay annual dues. Unlike a mortgage, which is a financial agreement that does not run with the land, a covenant can run with the land and bind future owners. Additionally, a covenant can require the burdened party to perform affirmative acts, such as paying dues, and can be used to establish a scheme of development that offers a high level of assurance to prospective purchasers.
explanation.Legal_Conclusion: Given the need for a mechanism that can run with the land, bind future owners, and require affirmative acts, a covenant is the best option for implementing the requirement that each lot owner pay annual dues to support the club and golf course, supporting option A.

question: Two neighbors are equal tenants in common of a strip of land 10 feet wide and 100 feet deep which lies between the lots on which their respective homes are situated. Both neighbors need the use of the 10-foot strip as a driveway; and each fears that a new neighbor might seek partition and leave him with an unusable 5-foot strip. The best advice about how to solve their problem is

options.optionA: A. a covenant against partition.
options.optionB: B. an indenture granting cross easements in the undivided half interest of each.
options.optionC: C. partition into two separate 5-foot wide strips and an indenture granting cross easements.
options.optionD: D. a trust to hold the strip in perpetuity.

explanation.Legal_Concept: Co-ownership and partition of property, specifically addressing the issue of maintaining shared use of a driveway by co-tenants.
explanation.Fact_Analysis: Two neighbors are co-tenants in common of a 10-foot wide strip of land used as a shared driveway. Both need the use of the entire strip and fear that partition by a new neighbor could leave them with an unusable 5-foot strip.
explanation.Rule_Application: Partition of the property into two separate 5-foot wide strips, combined with an indenture granting cross easements, would allow both neighbors to maintain their use of the driveway. This approach respects the inherent right of tenants to seek partition while ensuring continued shared use through easements.
explanation.Legal_Conclusion: Partitioning the driveway into two separate strips and granting cross easements is the most effective solution, as it balances the right to partition with the need for continued shared use, making option C the correct answer.

question: By way of a gift, a father executed a deed naming his daughter as grantee. The deed contained descriptions as follows: (I) All of my land and dwelling known as 44 Main Street, Midtown, United States, being one acre. (II) All that part of my farm, being a square with 200-foot sides, the southeast corner of which is in the north line of my neighbor. The deed contained covenants of general warranty, quiet enjoyment, and right to convey. The father handed the deed to his daughter who immediately returned it to her father for safekeeping. Her father kept it in his safe deposit box. The deed was not recorded. The property at 44 Main Street covered 7/8 of an acre of land, had a dwelling and a garage situated thereon, and was subject to a right of way, described in prior deeds, in favor of a second neighbor. The father owned no other land on Main Street. This neighbor had not used the right of way for ten years and it was not visible on inspection of the property. The description of 44 Main Street was

options.optionA: A. sufficient, because the discrepancy in area is not fatal.
options.optionB: B. not sufficient, because it contained no metes and bounds.
options.optionC: C. not sufficient, because the acreage given was not correct.
options.optionD: D. not sufficient, because a deed purporting to convey more than a grantor owns is void ab initio.

explanation.Legal_Concept: The requirements for a valid description of land in a deed, specifically the need for specificity to identify and locate the property.
explanation.Fact_Analysis: The deed contained two descriptions: one for 44 Main Street, Midtown, United States, being one acre, and another for a part of the farm. However, the property at 44 Main Street actually covered 7/8 of an acre and was subject to a right of way. The deed was not recorded and had discrepancies in the acreage.
explanation.Rule_Application: A description of land in a deed must be specific enough to allow a party to identify and locate the property. Minor discrepancies in the description are permissible, but the description must not be so vague that it fails to identify the property. Metes and bounds are not required, but if used, they will be given effect.
explanation.Legal_Conclusion: Given that the description of 44 Main Street, despite the minor discrepancy in acreage, is sufficient to identify and locate the property, the correct answer is A. The description is not void for vagueness, and the transfer of rights is valid.

question: An owner owned in fee simple three adjoining vacant lots fronting on a common street in a primarily residential section of a city which had no zoning laws. The lots were identified as Lots 1, 2, and 3. The owner conveyed Lot 1 to a man and Lot 2 to a woman. The owner retained Lot 3, which consisted of three acres of woodland. The woman, whose lot was between the other two, built a house on her lot. The man erected a house on his lot. The owner made no complaint to either the man or woman concerning the houses they built. After both the man and woman had completed their houses, the two of them agreed to and did build a common driveway running from the street to the rear of their respective lots. The driveway was built on the line between the two houses so that one-half of the way was located on each lot. The man and woman exchanged right-of-way deeds by which each of them conveyed to the other, his heirs and assigns, an easement to continue the right of way. Both deeds were properly recorded. After the man and woman had lived in their respective houses for thirty years, a new public street was built bordering on the rear of Lots 1, 2, and 3. The man informed the woman that, since the new street removed the need for their common driveway, he considered the right-of-way terminated; therefore, he intended to discontinue its use and expected the woman to do the same. In an action brought by the woman to enjoin the man from interfering with her continued use of the common driveway between the two lots, the decision should be for

options.optionA: A. the man, because the termination of the necessity for the easement terminated the easement.
options.optionB: B. the man, because the continuation of the easement after the change of circumstances would adversely affect the marketability of both lots without adding any commensurate value to either.
options.optionC: C. the woman, because an incorporeal hereditament lies in grant and cannot be terminated without a writing.
options.optionD: D. the woman, because the removal of the need for the easement created by express grant does not affect the right to the easement.

explanation.Legal_Concept: Express easements in property law, specifically the creation, continuation, and termination of easements by express grant.
explanation.Fact_Analysis: The man and woman, owners of adjacent lots, created a common driveway by exchanging right-of-way deeds, which were properly recorded. The driveway was built on the line between their houses, with each owner conveying an easement to the other. After thirty years, a new public street was built, prompting the man to claim the easement was terminated due to the removal of its necessity.
explanation.Rule_Application: An express easement is created by a writing, such as a deed, and is not dependent on a necessity. Unlike an easement by necessity, which is terminated by the removal of the necessity that created it, an express easement continues unaffected by changes in circumstances. The man and woman's easement was created by express grant, as evidenced by the recorded deeds, and its continuation is not contingent on the original motivation for its creation.
explanation.Legal_Conclusion: Given that the easement was created by express grant and not by necessity, the removal of the need for the easement does not affect the right to the easement. Therefore, the man does not have the power to interfere with the woman's use of the easement, and the decision should be for the woman, supporting option D.

question: The owner of Newacre executed and delivered to a power company a right-of-way deed for the building and maintenance of an overhead power line across Newacre. The deed was properly recorded. Newacre then passed through several intermediate conveyances until it was conveyed to a new owner about ten years after the date of the right-of-way deed. All the intermediate deeds were properly recorded, but none of them mentioned the right-of-way. The new owner entered into a written contract to sell Newacre to a developer. By the terms of the contract, the new owner promised to furnish an abstract of title to the developer. The new owner contracted directly with an abstract company to prepare and deliver an abstract to the developer, and the abstract company did so. The abstract omitted the right-of-way deed. The developer delivered the abstract to his attorney and asked the attorney for an opinion as to title. The attorney signed and delivered to the developer a letter stating that, from the attorney's examination of the abstract, it was his "opinion that the new owner had a free and unencumbered marketable title to Newacre." The new owner conveyed Newacre to the developer by a deed which included covenants of general warranty and against encumbrances. The developer paid the full purchase price. After the developer had been in possession of Newacre for more than a year, he learned about the right-of-way deed. The new owner, the developer, the abstract company, and the developer's attorney were all without actual knowledge of the existence of the right-of-way to the conveyance from the new owner to the developer. If the developer sues the abstract company for damages caused to the developer by the presence of the right-of-way, the most likely result will be a decision for

options.optionA: A. the developer, because the developer was a third-party creditor beneficiary of the contract between the new owner and the abstract company.
options.optionB: B. the developer, because the abstract prepared by the abstract company constitutes a guarantee of the developer's title to Newacre.
options.optionC: C. the abstract company, because the abstract company had no knowledge of the existence of the right-of-way.
options.optionD: D. the abstract company, because there was no showing that any fraud was practiced upon the developer.

explanation.Legal_Concept: Professional negligence in the context of abstract companies and their duty to exercise competence in creating accurate title reports.
explanation.Fact_Analysis: The abstract company was contracted by the new owner to prepare and deliver an abstract of title to the developer, but the abstract omitted the right-of-way deed. The developer relied on this abstract in accepting the property and paying the full purchase price, and later discovered the right-of-way deed after being in possession for over a year.
explanation.Rule_Application: An abstract company has a duty to exercise competence in its creation of an abstract. The developer, as a third-party creditor beneficiary of the contract between the new owner and the abstract company, can sue the abstract company for damages caused by the presence of the right-of-way, which was not disclosed in the abstract.
explanation.Legal_Conclusion: Given the abstract company's professional negligence in failing to include the right-of-way deed in the abstract, and the developer's reliance on the abstract in purchasing the property, the most likely result will be a decision for the developer, supporting option A.

question: The owner of Newacre executed and delivered to a power company a right-of-way deed for the building and maintenance of an overhead power line across Newacre. The deed was properly recorded. Newacre then passed through several intermediate conveyances until it was conveyed to a new owner about ten years after the date of the right-of-way deed. All the intermediate deeds were properly recorded, but none of them mentioned the right-of-way. The new owner entered into a written contract to sell Newacre to a developer. By the terms of the contract, the new owner promised to furnish an abstract of title to the developer. The new owner contracted directly with an abstract company to prepare and deliver an abstract to the developer, and the abstract company did so. The abstract omitted the right-of-way deed. The developer delivered the abstract to his attorney and asked the attorney for an opinion as to title. The attorney signed and delivered to the developer a letter stating that, from the attorney's examination of the abstract, it was his "opinion that the new owner had a free and unencumbered marketable title to Newacre." The new owner conveyed Newacre to the developer by a deed which included covenants of general warranty and against encumbrances. The developer paid the full purchase price. After the developer had been in possession of Newacre for more than a year, he learned about the right-of-way deed. The new owner, the developer, the abstract company, and the developer's attorney were all without actual knowledge of the existence of the right-of-way to the conveyance from the new owner to the developer. If the developer sues the new owner because of the presence of the right-of-way, the most likely result will be a decision for

options.optionA: A. the developer, because the new owner is liable for his negligent misrepresentation.
options.optionB: B. the developer, because the covenants in the new owner's deed to the developer have been breached.
options.optionC: C. the new owner, because the developer relied upon the abstract company, not the new owner, for information concerning title.
options.optionD: D. the new owner, because the new owner was without knowledge of any defects in the title to Newacre.

explanation.Legal_Concept: Title covenants in real estate transactions, specifically the covenant against encumbrances and the covenant of warranty.
explanation.Fact_Analysis: The new owner conveyed Newacre to the developer with covenants of general warranty and against encumbrances, guaranteeing that the title was free from defects. The developer relied on an abstract of title that omitted the right-of-way deed, which was recorded but not mentioned in intermediate conveyances. Neither the new owner nor the developer had actual knowledge of the right-of-way deed at the time of conveyance.
explanation.Rule_Application: A covenant against encumbrances guarantees that there are no easements or other interests in third parties that diminish the grantee's ownership rights. A covenant of warranty guarantees that the grantor's title is good and that the grantor will assist in defending that title against claims by third parties.
