The new owner's warranties are breached by the existence of the recorded right-of-way deed, regardless of whether the new owner had actual knowledge of it.
explanation.Legal_Conclusion: Given the new owner's guarantees and the breach of those guarantees by the existence of the right-of-way deed, the most likely result is a decision for the developer, supporting option B.

question: In 1995 a man executed his will which in pertinent part provided, "I hereby give, devise, and bequeath Greenvale to my surviving widow for life, remainder to such of my children as shall live to attain the age of 30, but if any child who dies under the age of 30 is survived by a child or children, such child or children shall take and receive the share which his, her, or their parent would have received had such parent lived to attain the age of 30." At the date of writing of his will, the man was married and had two sons. The man's wife died in 2000, and the man remarried in 2002 and had a third child in 2004--a daughter. At his death in 2010, the man was survived by his second wife and three children. In a jurisdiction which recognizes the common law Rule Against Perpetuities unmodified by statute, the result of the application of the rule is that the

options.optionA: A. remainder to the children and to the grandchildren is void because the man could have subsequently married a person who was unborn at the time the man executed his will.
options.optionB: B. remainder to the children is valid, but the substitutionary gift to the grandchildren is void because the man could have subsequently married a person who was unborn at the time the man executed his will.
options.optionC: C. gift in remainder to the sons or their children is valid, but the gift to the daughter or her children is void.
options.optionD: D. remainder to the children and the substitutionary gift to the grandchildren are valid.

explanation.Legal_Concept: The Rule Against Perpetuities (RAP) in the context of wills and estates, specifically the vesting of interests and the validity of substitutionary gifts to grandchildren.
explanation.Fact_Analysis: The man's will provided a life estate to his surviving widow, with a remainder to his children who reach the age of 30, and a substitutionary gift to any grandchildren of deceased offspring under 30. The man had two sons at the time of writing the will, but later remarried and had a daughter. At his death, he was survived by his second wife and three children.
explanation.Rule_Application: The RAP is not violated because the class of children will be closed at the man's death, and their remainder interests will vest at that time. The creation of the children's interest occurred at the man's death, not at the time the will was written. The substitutionary gift to grandchildren is also valid because the interests are vested, and no requirement of survival is necessary for the gift to vest.
explanation.Legal_Conclusion: Given that the interests are vested and the RAP is not violated, the remainder to the children and the substitutionary gift to the grandchildren are valid. Therefore, the correct answer is option D.

question: At a time when an owner held Lot 1 in the Fairoaks subdivision in fee simple, the owner's son executed a warranty deed that recited that the owner's son conveyed Lot 1, Fairoaks, to his girlfriend. The deed was promptly and duly recorded. After the recording of the deed from the owner's son to his girlfriend, the owner conveyed Lot 1 to his son by a warranty deed that was promptly and duly recorded. Later, the owner's son conveyed the property to a buyer by warranty deed, and the deed was promptly and duly recorded. The buyer paid the fair market value of Lot 1 and had no knowledge of any claim of the girlfriend. In an appropriate action, the buyer and the girlfriend contest title to Lot 1. In this action, judgment should be for

options.optionA: A. the girlfriend, because the girlfriend's deed is senior to the buyer's.
options.optionB: B. the buyer, because the buyer paid value without notice of the girlfriend's claim.
options.optionC: C. the girlfriend or the buyer, depending on whether a subsequent grantee is bound, at common law, by the doctrine of estoppel by deed.
options.optionD: D. the girlfriend or the buyer, depending on whether the girlfriend's deed is deemed recorded in the buyer's chain of title.

explanation.Legal_Concept: The impact of recording acts on the priority of title in real property transactions, specifically the distinction between notice and race-notice statutes.
explanation.Fact_Analysis: The owner's son conveyed Lot 1 to his girlfriend by a recorded warranty deed. Subsequently, the owner conveyed Lot 1 to his son by a recorded warranty deed, and the son then conveyed the property to the buyer by a recorded warranty deed. The buyer paid fair market value and had no knowledge of the girlfriend's claim.
explanation.Rule_Application: The type of recording act in effect in the jurisdiction will determine the priority of title. If the jurisdiction has a notice statute, the buyer's lack of notice of the girlfriend's claim would be determinative. If the jurisdiction has a race-notice statute, the buyer's status as a bona fide purchaser would depend on whether the girlfriend's deed is deemed recorded in the buyer's chain of title.
explanation.Legal_Conclusion: Because the type of recording act in effect is unknown, the outcome depends on whether the girlfriend's deed is deemed recorded in the buyer's chain of title, making option D the correct answer.

question: A widower owns in fee simple a ranch, Ranchacre. The widower has one child, a son, who is married. The widower has one grandchild, who is also married but has no children. In an effort to dispose of Ranchacre to his descendants and to honor a request by the grandchild that she be skipped in any disposition, the widower conveys Ranchacre to his son for life with the remainder to the grandchild's children in fee simple. What interest, if any, is created in favor of the grandchild's unborn children at the time of the conveyance?

options.optionA: A. A contingent remainder
options.optionB: B. A vested remainder subject to divestment
options.optionC: C. A springing use
options.optionD: D. None

explanation.Legal_Concept: Types of remainders in property law, specifically the distinction between vested and contingent remainders.
explanation.Fact_Analysis: The widower conveyed Ranchacre to his son for life, with the remainder to the grandchild's children in fee simple. At the time of the conveyance, the grandchild had no children.
explanation.Rule_Application: A contingent remainder is a future interest that is dependent on the occurrence of a later event or the satisfaction of a condition before it becomes a possessory interest. In contrast, a vested remainder is guaranteed to become possessory without any conditions. Since the grant to the grandchild's children is contingent upon their birth, it falls into the category of a contingent remainder.
explanation.Legal_Conclusion: Given that the interest created in favor of the grandchild's unborn children is dependent on their future birth, it is classified as a contingent remainder, supporting option A.

question: A seller agreed to sell and a buyer agreed to buy a described lot on which a single-family residence had been built. Under the contract, the seller agreed to convey marketable title subject only to conditions, covenants, and restrictions of record and all applicable zoning laws and ordinances. The lot was subject to a 10-foot side line setback originally set forth in the developer's duly recorded subdivision plot. The applicable zoning ordinance zones that property for single-family units and requires an 8.5-foot side line setback. Prior to closing, a survey of the property was made. It revealed that a portion of the seller's house was 8.4 feet from the side line. The buyer refused to consummate the transaction on the ground that the seller's title is not marketable. In an appropriate action, the seller seeks specific performance. Who will prevail in such an action?

options.optionA: A. The seller, because any suit against the buyer concerning the setback would be frivolous.
options.optionB: B. The seller, because the setback violation falls within the doctrine de minimis non curat lex.
options.optionC: C. The buyer, because any variation, however small, amounts to a breach of contract.
options.optionD: D. The buyer, because the fact that the buyer may be exposed to litigation is sufficient to make the title unmarketable.

explanation.Legal_Concept: The warranty of marketable title in land sale contracts, specifically the impact of zoning law violations on marketability.
explanation.Fact_Analysis: The seller's house is in violation of the zoning ordinance's 8.5-foot side line setback requirement, with a portion of the house being only 8.4 feet from the side line. The contract requires the seller to convey marketable title, subject only to conditions, covenants, and restrictions of record and all applicable zoning laws and ordinances.
explanation.Rule_Application: A title is considered unmarketable if it is subject to encumbrances such as zoning law violations. The buyer will not be expected to perform on the contract if doing so will require them to immediately enter a dispute over whether they hold good title. In this case, the zoning law violation constitutes an encumbrance, making the title unmarketable.
explanation.Legal_Conclusion: Given that the seller's title is not marketable due to the zoning law violation, the buyer is justified in refusing to consummate the transaction. Therefore, the buyer will prevail in the action, supporting option D.

question: For valuable consideration, the owner of Riveracre signed and gave to the grantee a duly executed instrument that provided as follows: "The grantor may or may not sell Riveracre during her lifetime, but at her death, or if she earlier decides to sell, the property will be offered to [the grantee] at $500 per acre. [The grantee] shall exercise this right, if at all, within sixty days of receipt of said offer to sell." The grantee recorded the instrument. The instrument was not valid as a will. Is the grantee's right under the instrument valid?

options.optionA: A. Yes, because the instrument is recorded.
options.optionB: B. Yes, because the grantee's right to purchase will vest or fail within the period prescribed by the Rule Against Perpetuities.
options.optionC: C. No, because the grantee's right to purchase is a restraint on the owner's power to make a testamentary disposition.
options.optionD: D. No, because the grantee's right to purchase is an unreasonable restraint on alienation.

explanation.Legal_Concept: The rule against perpetuities (RAP) and its application to interests in land, specifically the validity of a right of first refusal.
explanation.Fact_Analysis: The owner of Riveracre granted the grantee a right of first refusal to purchase the property at a specified price upon the owner's death or decision to sell, with the grantee required to exercise this right within sixty days of receiving the offer to sell.
explanation.Rule_Application: The RAP dictates that interests in land must vest or fail within a life-in-being plus 21 years. In this scenario, the grantee's right of first refusal must be exercised within sixty days after the owner decides to sell or within sixty days after her death, whichever comes first, thereby falling within the owner's life plus sixty days and satisfying the RAP's requirement.
explanation.Legal_Conclusion: Given that the grantee's right of first refusal will vest or fail within the period prescribed by the RAP, the grantee's right under the instrument is valid, supporting option B.

question: A ten-lot subdivision was approved by the proper governmental authority. The authority's action was pursuant to a map filed by a developer, which included an undesignated parcel in addition to the ten numbered lots. The shape of the undesignated parcel is different and somewhat larger than any one of the numbered lots. Subdivision building restrictions were imposed on "all the lots shown on said map." The developer contracts to sell the unnumbered lot, described by metes and bounds, to a buyer. Is title to the parcel marketable?

options.optionA: A. Yes, because the undesignated parcel is not a lot to which the subdivision building restrictions apply.
options.optionB: B. Yes, because the undesignated parcel is not part of the subdivision.
options.optionC: C. No, because the undesignated parcel has never been approved by the proper governmental authority.
options.optionD: D. No, because the map leaves it uncertain whether the unnumbered lot is subject to the building restrictions.

explanation.Legal_Concept: The warranty of marketable title in land sales contracts, specifically the requirement that title be free of encumbrances such as restrictions and covenants.
explanation.Fact_Analysis: A developer's map for a ten-lot subdivision included an undesignated parcel in addition to the numbered lots. The subdivision building restrictions were imposed on 'all the lots shown on said map.' The developer contracts to sell the unnumbered lot, described by metes and bounds, to a buyer.
explanation.Rule_Application: For title to be considered marketable, it must be free of encumbrances such as mortgages, restrictions, covenants, easements, or other limiting provisions not explicitly identified in the contract. The subdivision building restrictions could potentially apply to the unnumbered parcel, which would constitute an encumbrance on the title.
explanation.Legal_Conclusion: Because it is uncertain whether the subdivision restrictions apply to the unnumbered parcel, and if they do, they would be an encumbrance on the title, the title to the parcel is not marketable. Therefore, answer D is correct.

question: A man owned Blackacre in fee simple and by his will specifically devised Blackacre as follows: "To my daughter, her heirs and assigns, but if my daughter dies survived by a husband and a child or children, then to my daughter's husband during his lifetime with remainder to my daughter's children, their heirs and assigns. Specifically provided, however, that if my daughter dies survived by a husband and no child, Blackacre is specifically devised to my nephew, his heirs and assigns." While the man's will was in probate, the nephew quitclaimed all interest in Blackacre to the daughter's husband. Three years later, the daughter died, survived by her husband but no children. The daughter left a will devising her interest in Blackacre to her husband. The only applicable statute provides that any interest in land is freely alienable. The nephew instituted an appropriate action against the husband to establish title to Blackacre. Judgment should be for

options.optionA: A. the nephew, because his quitclaim deed did not transfer his after acquired title.
options.optionB: B. the nephew, because the husband took nothing under the man's will.
options.optionC: C. the husband, because the nephew had effectively conveyed his interest to the husband.
options.optionD: D. the husband, because the doctrine of after acquired title applies to a devise by will.

explanation.Legal_Concept: The application of a will's specific devises and the effect of quitclaiming an interest in land, particularly in relation to after-acquired title.
explanation.Fact_Analysis: The man's will devised Blackacre to his daughter with specific conditions affecting the interest of her husband and children upon her death. The daughter died survived by her husband but no children, triggering the devise to the nephew in fee simple. However, before this event, the nephew quitclaimed his interest in Blackacre to the husband.
explanation.Rule_Application: A quitclaim deed transfers the grantor's entire interest in the property at the time of the conveyance. Since the nephew's interest in Blackacre was contingent upon the daughter's death without children, his quitclaim to the husband effectively conveyed this future interest. The applicable statute allowing for the free alienability of interests in land supports this transfer.
explanation.Legal_Conclusion: Given that the nephew's quitclaim deed effectively conveyed his interest in Blackacre to the husband, and considering the conditions of the man's will were met upon the daughter's death, the husband has acquired the nephew's interest in the land. Therefore, judgment should be for the husband, supporting option C.

question: An unmarried couple purchased a condominium as tenants in common and lived in the condominium for three years. Subsequently, they made a verbal agreement that, on the death of either of them, the survivor would own the entire condominium, and, as a result, they decided they did not need wills. Two years later, the couple was involved in the same automobile accident. The woman was killed immediately. The man died one week later. Both died intestate. The woman's sole heir is her brother. The man's sole heir is his mother. The brother claimed one-half of the condominium, and the mother claimed all of it. The jurisdiction has no applicable statute except for the Statute of Frauds; nor does it recognize common-law marriages. In an appropriate action by the mother claiming the entire ownership of the condominium, the court will find that

options.optionA: A. The mother owns the entire interest because the couple did not make wills in reliance upon their oral agreement.
options.optionB: B. The mother owns the entire interest because she is entitled to reformation of the deed to reflect the verbal agreement.
options.optionC: C. The brother and the mother each own an undivided one-half interest because the couple each died as the result of the same accident.
options.optionD: D. The brother and the mother each own an undivided one-half interest because the Statute of Frauds applies.

explanation.Legal_Concept: The application of the Statute of Frauds to contracts regarding the sale or conveyance of land, specifically the requirement for such agreements to be in writing and signed.
explanation.Fact_Analysis: An unmarried couple, owning a condominium as tenants in common, made a verbal agreement that upon the death of one, the survivor would own the entire condominium. However, both died intestate, with the woman's brother and the man's mother as their respective sole heirs.
explanation.Rule_Application: The Statute of Frauds renders the couple's verbal agreement void because it pertains to the conveyance of land and was not in writing. As a result, each member of the couple retained their one-half interest in the condominium at the time of their death, which they could pass on to their heirs.
explanation.Legal_Conclusion: Given the Statute of Frauds' requirement for a written agreement to convey land, the couple's verbal agreement is unenforceable. Therefore, the brother and the mother each inherit a one-half interest in the condominium, supporting answer D.

question: In 1986, a cement company constructed a plant for manufacturing ready-mix concrete in Lakeville. At the time, the company was using bagged cement, which caused little or no dust. In 2000, the plaintiff bought a home approximately 1,800 feet from the cement plant. One year ago, the cement company stopped using bagged cement and began to receive cement in bulk shipments. Since then, at least five truckloads of cement have passed the plaintiff's house daily. Cement blows off the trucks and into the the plaintiff's house. When the cement arrives at the cement plant, it is blown by forced air from the trucks into the storage bin. As a consequence cement dust fills the air surrounding the plant to a distance of 2,000 feet. The plaintiff's house is the only residence within 2,000 feet of the plant. If the plaintiff asserts a claim against the cemente company based on nuisance, will the plaintiff prevail?

options.optionA: A. Yes, unless using bagged cement would substantially increase the cement company's costs.
options.optionB: B. Yes, if the cement dust interfered unreasonably with the use and enjoyment of the plaintiff's property.
options.optionC: C. No, because the cement company is not required to change its industrial methods to accommodate the needs of one individual.
options.optionD: D. No, if the cement company's methods are in conformity with those in general use in the industry.

explanation.Legal_Concept: Nuisance in property law, specifically the concept of unreasonable interference with the use and enjoyment of one's property.
explanation.Fact_Analysis: The cement company's change from using bagged cement to bulk shipments has resulted in significant cement dust affecting the plaintiff's property, located 1,800 feet from the plant. The dust interferes with the plaintiff's use and enjoyment of her land, which is the only residence within 2,000 feet of the plant.
explanation.Rule_Application: To prevail in a nuisance claim, the plaintiff must show that the defendant's use of their property constitutes an unreasonable interference with the plaintiff's use and enjoyment of their own property. This requires a balancing of the parties' respective rights, considering the reasonableness of the defendant's actions and the impact on the plaintiff's property.
explanation.Legal_Conclusion: Given the significant impact of the cement dust on the plaintiff's property and the fact that it is the only residence affected within a 2,000-foot radius, the plaintiff can establish that the cement company's actions constitute an unreasonable interference with her use and enjoyment of her property. Therefore, the correct answer is B, as the plaintiff will prevail if she can show that the cement dust interfered unreasonably with her property use and enjoyment.

question: Two adjacent, two-story, commercial buildings were owned by a businessman. The first floors of both buildings were occupied by various retail establishments. The second floors were rented to various other tenants. Access to the second floor of each building was reached by a common stairway located entirely in Building 1. While the buildings were being used in this manner, the businessman sold Building 1 to a friend by warranty deed which made no mention of any rights concerning the stairway. About two years later the businessman sold Building 2 to a co-worker. The stairway continued to be used by the occupants of both buildings. The stairway became unsafe as a consequence of regular wear and tear. The owner of Building 2 entered upon Building 1 and began the work of repairing the stairway. The owner of Building 1 demanded that the owner of Building 2 discontinue the repair work and vacate Building 1. When the owner of Building 2 refused, the owner of Building 1 brought an action to enjoin the owner of Building 2 from continuing the work. Judgment should be for

options.optionA: A. the owner of Building 1, because the owner of Building 2 has no rights in the stairway.
options.optionB: B. the owner of Building 1, because the owner of Building 2's rights in the stairway do not extend beyond the normal life of the existing structure.
options.optionC: C. the owner of Building 2, because he has an easement in the stairway and an implied right to keep the stairway in repair.
options.optionD: D. the owner of Building 2, because he has a right to take whatever action is necessary to protect himself from possible tort liability to persons using the stairway.

explanation.Legal_Concept: Implied easement by necessity in property law, particularly the rights and responsibilities associated with such easements.
explanation.Fact_Analysis: The second floor of Building 2 is only accessible via the stairway located entirely in Building 1, indicating a necessary dependency for access. The businessman sold Building 1 without mentioning any rights concerning the stairway, but the occupants of both buildings continued to use it.
explanation.Rule_Application: An implied easement by necessity arises when a property is landlocked and requires access through another property to be usable. The holder of such an easement has the right to enter the land to make repairs necessary for the continued use of the easement. In this scenario, the owner of Building 2 has an implied easement by necessity for the stairway and thus has the right to repair it.
explanation.Legal_Conclusion: Given the necessary dependency of Building 2's accessibility on the stairway in Building 1 and the continued use of the stairway by both buildings' occupants, the owner of Building 2 has an implied easement in the stairway and an implied right to keep it in repair. Therefore, judgment should be for the owner of Building 2, supporting option C.

question: A father owned two adjoining parcels known as Lot 1 and Lot 2. Both parcels fronted on Main Street and abutted a public alley in the rear. Lot 1 was improved with a commercial building that covered all of the Main Street frontage of Lot 1; there was a large parking lot on the rear of Lot 1 with access from the alley only. Fifteen years ago, the father leased Lot 1 to his son for 15 years. The son has continuously occupied Lot 1 since that time. Thirteen years ago, without his father's permission, the son began to use a driveway on Lot 2 as a better access between Main Street and the parking lot than the alley. Eight years ago, the father conveyed Lot 2 to his daughter and, five years ago, the father conveyed Lot 1 to his son by a deed that recited "together with all the appurtenances." Until last week, the son continuously used the driveway over Lot 2 to the son's parking lot in the rear of Lot 1. Last week the daughter commenced construction of a building on Lot 2 and blocked the driveway used by the son. The son has commenced an action against the daughter to restrain her from blocking the driveway from Main Street to the parking lot at the rear of Lot 1. The period of time to acquire rights by prescription in the jurisdiction is ten years. If the son loses, it will be because

options.optionA: A. the father owned both Lot 1 and Lot 2 until eight years ago.
options.optionB: B. the son has access to the parking lot from the alley.
options.optionC: C. mere use of an easement is not adverse possession.
options.optionD: D. no easement was mentioned in the deed from the father to his daughter.

explanation.Legal_Concept: Creation of an easement appurtenant, specifically the requirements for establishing a dominant and servient estate.
explanation.Fact_Analysis: The son used a driveway on Lot 2 for access between Main Street and the parking lot on Lot 1 for thirteen years without the father's permission. The father later conveyed Lot 2 to the daughter and Lot 1 to the son, with the deed to the son including 'all the appurtenances.' The son continued to use the driveway until the daughter blocked it to construct a building.
explanation.Rule_Application: An easement appurtenant requires two pieces of property: a dominant estate (the land benefited by the easement) and a servient estate (the land burdened by the easement). The creation of an easement appurtenant also requires that the two pieces of property be owned by the same person at the time of the easement's creation. In this case, the father owned both Lot 1 and Lot 2 until eight years ago, which is a critical factor in determining the validity of the easement.
explanation.Legal_Conclusion: Given that the father owned both lots until eight years ago, the son cannot claim an easement by prescription or adverse possession because the use of the driveway was permissive, not adverse. Therefore, the correct answer is A, as the father's ownership of both lots until eight years ago is the reason the son would lose his claim to the easement.

question: Two friends, a man and a woman, owned a large tract of land, Blackacre, in fee simple as joint tenants with right of survivorship. While the woman was on an extended safari in Kenya, the man learned that there were very valuable coal deposits within Blackacre, but he made no attempt to inform the woman. Thereupon, the man conveyed his interest in Blackacre to his wife who immediately reconveyed that interest to the man. The common-law joint tenancy is unmodified by statute. Shortly thereafter, the man was killed in an automobile accident. His will, which was duly probated, specifically devised his one-half interest in Blackacre to his wife. The woman then returned from Kenya and learned what had happened. The woman brought an appropriate action against the wife, who claimed a one-half interest in Blackacre, seeking a declaratory judgment that she, the woman, was the sole owner of Blackacre. In this action, who should prevail?

options.optionA: A. The wife, because the man and the woman were tenants in common at the time of the man's death.
options.optionB: B. The wife, because the man's will severed the joint tenancy.
options.optionC: C. The woman, because the joint tenancy was reestablished by the wife's reconveyance to the man.
options.optionD: D. The woman, because the man breached his fiduciary duty as her joint tenant.

explanation.Legal_Concept: Termination of a joint tenancy through severance, specifically the effect of an inter vivos conveyance on the joint tenancy.
explanation.Fact_Analysis: The man and the woman initially held Blackacre in joint tenancy. The man then conveyed his interest to his wife, who immediately reconveyed it back to him. The man subsequently died, devising his interest in Blackacre to his wife. The woman claims she is the sole owner of Blackacre.
explanation.Rule_Application: A joint tenancy is terminated by severance when one joint tenant makes an inter vivos conveyance of their interest. This severance results in the transferred interest being that of a tenant in common. The reconveyance of the interest back to the original joint tenant does not reestablish the joint tenancy because the 'four unities' are no longer present. Therefore, upon the man's death, his interest in Blackacre was that of a tenant in common, which could be devised by his will.
explanation.Legal_Conclusion: Given that the joint tenancy was severed by the man's inter vivos conveyance, and the property was subsequently held as a tenancy in common, the woman's claim to be the sole owner of Blackacre fails. The wife, as the devisee of the man's interest, has a valid claim to a one-half interest in Blackacre, supporting option A.

question: At the time of his death last week, the testator owned Blackacre, a small farm. By his duly probated will, drawn five years ago, the testator did the following: (I) devised Blackacre "to Arthur for the life of Baker, then to Casper"; (II) gave "all the rest, residue and remainder of my Estate, both real and personal, to my friend Fanny." At his death, the testator was survived by Arthur, Casper, Sonny (the testator's son and sole heir), and Fanny. Baker had died a week before the testator. Title to Blackacre is now in

options.optionA: A. Arthur for life, remainder to Casper.
options.optionB: B. Casper, in fee simple.
options.optionC: C. Sonny, in fee simple.
options.optionD: D. Fanny, in fee simple.

explanation.Legal_Concept: The determination of property rights following the death of a testator, specifically the interpretation of a will's devises and the impact of the death of a measuring life.
explanation.Fact_Analysis: The testator devised Blackacre to Arthur for the life of Baker, then to Casper. However, Baker predeceased the testator, which affects the duration of Arthur's life estate and the timing of the remainder to Casper.
explanation.Rule_Application: In a devise such as this, the death of the measuring life (Baker) before the testator accelerates the remainder to Casper, as the condition (Baker's life) that was to govern the duration of Arthur's life estate is no longer present. Therefore, Arthur's interest does not take effect, and the property goes directly to Casper in fee simple.
explanation.Legal_Conclusion: Given that Baker predeceased the testator, the remainder to Casper is accelerated, and Casper takes Blackacre in fee simple. Thus, the correct answer is option B.

question: A businessman owned two adjacent parcels, Blackacre and Whiteacre. Blackacre fronts on a poor unpaved public road, while Whiteacre fronts on Route 20, a paved major highway. Fifteen years ago, the businessman conveyed to his son Blackacre "together with a right-of-way 25 feet wide over the east side of Whiteacre to Route 20." At that time, Blackacre was improved with a ten-unit motel. Ten years ago, the businessman died. His will devised Whiteacre "to my son for life, remainder to my daughter." Five years ago, the son executed an instrument in the proper form of a deed, purporting to convey Blackacre and Whiteacre to a friend in fee simple. The friend then enlarged the motel to 12 units. Six months ago, the son died and the daughter took possession of Whiteacre. She brought an appropriate action to enjoin the friend from using the right-of-way. In this action, who should prevail?

options.optionA: A. the daughter, because merger extinguished the easement.
options.optionB: B. the daughter, because the friend has overburdened the easement.
options.optionC: C. The friend, because he has an easement by necessity.
options.optionD: D. The friend, because he has the easement granted by the businessman to the son.

explanation.Legal_Concept: Easements in property law, specifically the creation, transfer, and termination of easements.
explanation.Fact_Analysis: The businessman conveyed Blackacre to his son with a 25-foot wide right-of-way over Whiteacre to Route 20. The son was a life tenant in Whiteacre, having received it from the businessman's will. The son then conveyed both Blackacre and Whiteacre to a friend, who enlarged a motel on Blackacre. After the son's death, the daughter, as the remainderman of Whiteacre, sought to enjoin the friend's use of the right-of-way.
explanation.Rule_Application: An easement is a non-possessory interest in land that gives one party the right to use another's property for a specific purpose. In this case, the easement was created when the businessman conveyed Blackacre to the son with the right-of-way. The easement was not terminated by merger because the son did not have unity of ownership in both Blackacre and Whiteacre. The son's conveyance of both parcels to the friend transferred the easement to the friend, who has the right to use the right-of-way.
explanation.Legal_Conclusion: The friend has the easement granted by the businessman to the son, and the daughter's attempt to enjoin the friend's use of the right-of-way should fail. Therefore, the correct answer is option D.

question: Twenty-five years ago, a seller conveyed Blackacre to a buyer by a warranty deed. The seller at that time also executed and delivered an instrument in the proper form of a deed, purporting to convey Whiteacre to the buyer. The seller thought she had title to Whiteacre but did not; therefore, no titled passed by virtue of the Whiteacre deed. Whiteacre consisted of three acres of brushland adjoining the west boundary of Blackacre. The buyer has occasionally hunted rabbits on Whiteacre, but less often than annually. No one else came on Whiteacre except occasional rabbit hunters. Twenty years ago, the buyer planted a row of evergreens in the vicinity of the opposite (east) boundary of Blackacre and erected a fence just beyond the evergreens to the east. In fact both the trees and the fence were placed on Greenacre, owned by a neighbor, which bordered the east boundary of Blackacre. The buyer was unsure of the exact boundary, and placed the trees and the fence in order to establish his rights up to the fence. The fence is located ten feet within Greenacre. Now, the buyer has had his property surveyed and the title checked and has learned the facts. The period of time to acquire title by adverse possession in the jurisdiction is 15 years. The buyer consulted his lawyer, who properly advised that, in an appropriate action, the buyer would probably obtain title to

options.optionA: A. Whiteacre but not the the ten-foot strip of Greenacre.
options.optionB: B. the ten-foot strip of Greenacre but not to Whiteacre.
options.optionC: C. both Whiteacre and the ten-foot strip of Greenacre.
options.optionD: D. neither Whiteacre nor the ten-foot strip of Greenacre.

explanation.Legal_Concept: Adverse possession, specifically the requirements for obtaining title to land through continuous, exclusive, hostile, and open and notorious possession.
explanation.Fact_Analysis: The buyer received a deed for Whiteacre 25 years ago but the seller had no title to convey. The buyer occasionally hunted on Whiteacre but did not exclude others. The buyer also planted trees and erected a fence on Greenacre, 10 feet beyond the boundary of Blackacre, without knowing the exact boundary, and maintained possession of that strip for 15 years.
explanation.Rule_Application: To acquire land through adverse possession, one must have actual physical possession, maintain it continuously and without interruption, exclude others, have hostile possession, and maintain open and notorious possession. The buyer failed to meet these requirements for Whiteacre but did so for the 10-foot strip of Greenacre by erecting a fence and planting trees without permission and maintaining possession for the statutory period.
explanation.Legal_Conclusion: Given the buyer's failure to meet the requirements for adverse possession of Whiteacre and his successful possession of the 10-foot strip of Greenacre, the buyer will probably obtain title to the strip of Greenacre but not to Whiteacre, supporting option B.

question: A leasing company owned Blackacre, a tract of 100 acres. Six years ago, the leasing company leased a one-acre parcel, located in the northeasterly corner of Blackacre, for a term of 30 years, to a restaurant. The restaurant intended to and did construct a fast-food restaurant on the one-acre parcel. The lease provided that: I. The restaurant was to maintain the one-acre parcel and improvements thereon, to maintain full insurance coverage on the one-acre parcel, and to pay all taxes assessed against the one-acre parcel. II. The leasing company was to maintain the access roads and the parking lot areas platted on those portions of Blackacre that adjoined the one-acre parcel and to permit the customers of the restaurant to use them in common with the customers of the other commercial users of the remainder of Blackacre. III. The restaurant was to pay its share of the expenses for the off-site improvements according to a stated formula. Five years ago, the leasing company sold the one-acre parcel to an investor; the conveyance was made subject to the lease to the restaurant. However, the investor did not assume the obligations of the lease and the leasing company retained the remainder of Blackacre. Since that conveyance five years ago, the restaurant has paid rent to the investor. The restaurant refused to pay its formula share of the off-site improvement costs as provided in the lease. The leasing company brought an appropriate action against the restaurant to recover such costs. The most likely outcome would be in favor of

options.optionA: A. the leasing company, because the use of the improvements by the customers of the restaurant imposes an implied obligation on the restaurant.
options.optionB: B. the leasing company, because the conveyance of the one-acre parcel to the investor did not terminate the restaurant's covenant to contribute.
options.optionC: C. the restaurant, because the conveyance of the one-acre parcel to the investor terminated the privity of estate between the leasing company and the restaurant.
options.optionD: D. the restaurant, because the investor, as the restaurant's landlord, has the obligation to pay the maintenance costs by necessary implication.

explanation.Legal_Concept: Contractual obligations and privity of estate in the context of a leasehold agreement, specifically the continuation of obligations despite a change in ownership.
explanation.Fact_Analysis: The leasing company leased a one-acre parcel to a restaurant for 30 years, with specific obligations for both parties, including the restaurant's responsibility to pay its share of off-site improvement costs. The leasing company later sold the parcel to an investor, but the investor did not assume the leasing company's obligations under the lease.
explanation.Rule_Application: In a leasehold agreement, the obligations of the parties are contractual and can continue despite changes in ownership, unless explicitly assumed by the new owner. Since the investor did not assume the leasing company's obligations, the restaurant's obligations, including the payment of off-site improvement costs, remain unaffected.
explanation.Legal_Conclusion: Given that the restaurant's obligations under the lease were not terminated by the sale of the one-acre parcel to the investor, the leasing company can still enforce the restaurant's contractual obligation to pay its share of the off-site improvement costs, supporting option B.

question: A brother and sister owned Blackacre as joint tenants, upon which was situated a two-family house. The brother lived in one of the two apartments and rented the other apartment to a tenant. The brother got in a fight with the tenant and injured him. The tenant obtained and properly filed a judgment for $10,000 against the brother. The statute in the jurisdiction reads: Any judgment properly filed shall, for ten years from filing, be a lien on the real property then owned or subsequently acquired by any person against whom the judgment is rendered. The sister, who lived in a distant city, knew nothing of the tenant's judgment. Before the tenant took any further action, the brother died. The common-law joint tenancy is unmodified by statute. The sister then learned the facts and brought an appropriate action against the tenant to quiet title to Blackacre. The court should hold that the tenant has

options.optionA: A. a lien against the whole of Blackacre, because he was a tenant of both the brother and the sister at the time of the judgment.
options.optionB: B. a lien against the brother's undivided one-half interest in Blackacre, because his judgment was filed prior to the brother's death.
options.optionC: C. no lien, because the sister had no actual notice of the tenant's judgment until after the brother's death.
options.optionD: D. no lien, because the brother's death terminated the interest to which the tenant's lien attached.

explanation.Legal_Concept: The effect of a joint tenant's death on a judgment lien against the joint tenancy property.
explanation.Fact_Analysis: The brother and sister owned Blackacre as joint tenants. The brother was found liable to the tenant for $10,000 and a judgment was properly filed. Before the tenant could take further action, the brother died, triggering the right of survivorship, which increased the sister's interest in Blackacre to 100%.
explanation.Rule_Application: A judgment lien attaches to the interest of the judgment debtor in the property at the time the lien is filed. However, in a joint tenancy, the death of one joint tenant terminates their interest in the property, and the survivor's interest increases to 100%. Therefore, the interest to which the tenant's lien was attached (the brother's interest) ceased to exist upon the brother's death.
explanation.Legal_Conclusion: Since the brother's death terminated the interest to which the tenant's lien was attached, the tenant no longer has a valid lien against any part of Blackacre. Thus, the correct answer is that the tenant has no lien, supporting option D.

question: A decedent owned in fee simple Blueacre, a farm of 300 acres. He died and by will, duly admitted to probate, devised Blueacre to his surviving widow for life with remainder in fee simple to his three children, Anne, Betty, and Carter. All three children survived the decedent. At the time of the decedent's death, there existed a mortgage on Blueacre that the decedent had given ten years earlier to secure a loan for the purchase of the farm. At his death, there remained $40,000 in unpaid principal, payable in installments of $4,000 per year for the next ten years. In addition, there was interest due at the rate of 10% per annum, payable annually with the principal installment. The widow took possession and, out of a gross income of $50,000 per year, realized $25,000 net income after paying all expenses and charges except the principal installment and interest due on the mortgage. Carter and Anne wanted the three children, including Betty, to each contribute one-third of the amount needed to pay the mortgage installments. Betty objected, contending that the widow should pay all of these amounts out of the profits she had made in operation of the farm. When foreclosure of the mortgage seemed imminent, Betty sought legal advice. If Betty obtained sound advice relating to her rights, she was told that

options.optionA: A. her only protection would lie in instituting an action for partition to compel the sale of the life estate of the widow and to obtain the value of Betty's one-third interest in remainder.
options.optionB: B. she could obtain appropriate relief to compel the widow personally to pay the sums due because the income is more than adequate to cover these amounts.
options.optionC: C. she could be compelled personally to pay her share of the amounts due because discharge of the mortgage enhances the principal.
options.optionD: D. she could not be held personally liable for any amount, but her share in remainder could be lost if the mortgage installments were not paid.

explanation.Legal_Concept: Life estates and remainders in real property law, specifically the duties of a life tenant and the rights of remaindermen regarding mortgage payments.
explanation.Fact_Analysis: A decedent devised a farm, Blueacre, to his widow for life with a remainder in fee simple to his three children. A mortgage on the farm existed at the time of the decedent's death, with $40,000 in unpaid principal and annual interest due. The widow took possession and generated net income from the farm but did not pay the mortgage installments or interest.
explanation.Rule_Application: A life tenant has a duty not to commit permissive waste, which includes paying interest on any mortgage but not the principal. Remaindermen are not personally liable for the life tenant's failure to pay interest or for the principal payments. However, if the mortgage is not paid and the property is foreclosed, the remaindermen risk losing their interest in the property.
explanation.Legal_Conclusion: Betty, as a remainderman, cannot be held personally liable for the mortgage payments or interest. However, she risks losing her share of the remainder in Blueacre if the mortgage is not paid and the property is foreclosed. Therefore, the correct answer is that she cannot be held personally liable, but her share in remainder could be lost if the mortgage installments are not paid.

question: A man executed and delivered a promissory note and a mortgage securing the note to a mortgage company, which was named as payee in the note and as mortgagee in the mortgage. The note included a statement that the indebtedness evidenced by the note was "subject to the terms of a contract between the maker and the payee of the note executed on the same day" and that the note was "secured by a mortgage of even date." The mortgage was promptly and properly recorded. Subsequently, the mortgage company sold the man's note and mortgage to a bank and delivered to the bank a written assignment of the man's note and mortgage. The assignment was promptly and properly recorded. The mortgage company retained possession of both the note and the mortgage in order to act as collecting agent. Later, being short of funds, the mortgage company sold the note and mortgage to a woman at a substantial discount. The mortgage company executed a written assignment of the note and mortgage to the woman and delivered to him the note, the mortgage, and the assignment. The woman paid value for the assignment without actual knowledge of the prior assignment to the bank and promptly and properly recorded her assignment. The principal of the note was not then due, and there had been no default in payment of either interest or principal. If the issue of ownership of the man's note and mortgage is subsequently raised in an appropriate action by the bank to foreclose, the court should hold that

options.optionA: A. The woman owns both the note and the mortgage.
options.optionB: B. The bank owns both the note and the mortgage.
options.optionC: C. The woman owns the note, and the bank owns the mortgage.
options.optionD: D. The bank owns the note, and the woman owns the mortgage.

explanation.Legal_Concept: The priority of ownership and recording of assignments in the context of promissory notes and mortgages.
explanation.Fact_Analysis: The mortgage company initially sold the man's note and mortgage to the bank, delivering a written assignment that was promptly and properly recorded. Later, the mortgage company sold the same note and mortgage to the woman, who paid value without actual knowledge of the prior assignment and recorded her assignment.
explanation.Rule_Application: In the context of assignments of notes and mortgages, the first to record an assignment generally has priority over subsequent assignees. The bank's prompt and proper recording of the assignment secured its ownership, putting subsequent purchasers, including the woman, on notice of the prior sale.
explanation.Legal_Conclusion: Given the bank's prior recording of the assignment, it holds priority over the woman's subsequent purchase. Therefore, the bank owns both the note and the mortgage, supporting option B.

question: The owner of Blackacre in fee simple mortgaged Blackacre to a man to secure a loan of $100,000. The mortgage was promptly and properly recorded. The owner later mortgaged Blackacre to a woman to secure a loan of $50,000. The mortgage was promptly and properly recorded. Subsequently, the owner conveyed Blackacre to a businessman. About a year later, the businessman borrowed $100,000 from an elderly widow and gave her a mortgage on Blackacre to secure repayment of the loan. The elderly widow did not know about the mortgage held by the woman. The understanding between the businessman and the elderly widow was that the businessman would use the $100,000 to pay off the mortgage held by the man and that the elderly widow would, therefore, have a first mortgage on Blackacre. The elderly widow's mortgage was promptly and properly recorded. The businessman paid the $100,000 received from the elderly widow to the man and obtained and recorded a release of the the man's mortgage. The $50,000 debt secured by the woman's mortgage was not paid when it was due, and the woman brought an appropriate action to foreclose, joining the owner, the businessman, and the elderly widow as defendants and alleging that the woman's mortgage was senior to the elderly widow's mortgage on Blackacre. If the court rules that the elderly widow's mortgage is entitled priority over the woman's mortgage, which of the following determinations are necessary to support that ruling? I. The man's mortgage was originally senior to the woman's mortgage. II. The elderly widow is entitled to have the man's mortgage revived for her benefit, and the elderly widow is entitled to be subrogated to the man's original position as senior mortgagee. III. There are no countervailing equities in favor of the woman.

options.optionA: A. I and II only.
options.optionB: B. I and III only.
options.optionC: C. II and III only.
options.optionD: D. I, II, and III.

explanation.Legal_Concept: Priority of mortgages in real property law, specifically the determination of seniority based on the timing of mortgage creation and the concept of subrogation.
explanation.Fact_Analysis: The man's mortgage was created first, followed by the woman's, and then the businessman's. The elderly widow later paid off the man's mortgage and obtained it, thereby becoming the senior mortgagee. The woman's mortgage was not paid off when due, leading to a foreclosure action.
explanation.Rule_Application: In the absence of a purchase money mortgage, priority among mortgages is determined by the order in which they were created. Subrogation allows a party who pays off a senior mortgage to step into the shoes of the original senior mortgagee, thereby gaining priority. Here, the elderly widow paid off the man's mortgage and is entitled to be subrogated to the man's original position as senior mortgagee.
explanation.Legal_Conclusion: For the elderly widow's mortgage to be entitled to priority over the woman's mortgage, it must be determined that the man's mortgage was originally senior to the woman's (I), the elderly widow is entitled to subrogation to the man's original position (II), and there are no countervailing equities in favor of the woman (III). Therefore, answer D is correct.

question: A landowner owned Blueacre, a valuable tract of land located in York County. The owner executed a document in the form of a warranty deed of Blueacre, which was regular in all respects except that the only language designating the grantees in each of the granting and habendum clauses was: "The leaders of all the Protestant Churches in York County." The instrument was acknowledged as required by statute and promptly and properly recorded. The owner told his lawyer, but no one else, that he had made the conveyance as he did because he abhorred sectarianism in the Protestant movement and because he thought that the leaders would devote the asset to lessening sectarianism. The owner died suddenly and unexpectedly a week later, leaving a will that bequeathed and devised his entire estate to a friend. After probate of the will became final and the administration on the owner's estate was closed, the friend instituted an appropriate action to quiet title to Blueacre and properly served as defendant each Protestant church situated in the county. The only evidence introduced consisted of the chain of title under which the owner held, the probated will, the recorded deed, the fact that no person knew about the deed except the owner and his lawyer, and the conversation the owner had with his lawyer described above. In such action, judgment should be for

options.optionA: A. the friend, because there is inadequate identification of the grantees in the deed.
options.optionB: B. the friend, because the state of the evidence would not support a finding of delivery of the deed.
options.optionC: C. the defendants, because a deed is prima facie valid until rebutted.
options.optionD: D. the defendants, because recording established prima facie delivery until rebutted.

explanation.Legal_Concept: The requirements for a valid deed, specifically the necessity of adequately identifying the grantees.
explanation.Fact_Analysis: A landowner executed a warranty deed for Blueacre, naming the grantees as 'The leaders of all the Protestant Churches in York County.' The deed was acknowledged, recorded, and the owner's intent was to convey the property to lessen sectarianism. However, the owner died suddenly, and his will bequeathed his entire estate to a friend, who then sought to quiet title to Blueacre.
explanation.Rule_Application: For a deed to be valid, it must adequately identify the grantees. A grant to a vague or overly broad group, such as 'the leaders of all the Protestant Churches in York County,' does not sufficiently identify the intended grantees. Delivery of a deed requires establishing an intent to pass title, but this is irrelevant if the deed itself is defective due to inadequate identification of the grantees.
explanation.Legal_Conclusion: Given the deed's failure to adequately identify the grantees, it is invalid, and title to Blueacre was not effectively transferred. Therefore, judgment should be for the friend, supporting option A.

question: A businessman who owned Blackacre and Whiteacre, two adjoining parcels, conveyed Whiteacre to a gas company owner and covenanted in the deed to the gas company owner that when he, the businessman, sold Blackacre he would impose restrictive covenants to prohibit uses that would compete with the filling station that the gas company owner intended to construct and operate on Whiteacre. The deed was not recorded. The gas company owner constructed and operated a filling station on Whiteacre and then conveyed Whiteacre to his nephew, who continued the filling station use. The deed did not refer to the restrictive covenant and was promptly and properly recorded. The businessman then conveyed Blackacre to a man, who knew about the businessman's covenant prohibiting the filling station use but nonetheless completed the transaction when he noted that no such covenant was contained in the businessman's deed to him. The man began to construct a filling station on Blackacre. The nephew brought an appropriate action to enjoin the man from using Blackacre for filling station purposes. If the nephew prevails, it will be because

options.optionA: A. The man had actual knowledge of the covenant to impose restrictions.
options.optionB: B. The man is bound by the covenant because of the doctrine of negative reciprocal covenants.
options.optionC: C. business-related restrictive covenants are favored in the law.
options.optionD: D. The man has constructive notice of the possibility of the covenant resulting from circumstances.

explanation.Legal_Concept: Restrictive covenants in real property law, specifically the conditions under which a covenant can run with the land.
explanation.Fact_Analysis: A businessman conveyed Whiteacre to a gas company owner with a covenant to impose restrictive covenants on Blackacre when sold, to prevent competing uses with the filling station on Whiteacre. The gas company owner then conveyed Whiteacre to his nephew, who continued the filling station use. The businessman later conveyed Blackacre to a man who knew about the covenant but found no such covenant in the deed.
explanation.Rule_Application: For a restrictive covenant to run with the land, four elements must be met: intent for it to run with the land, notice, 'touch and concern' of the covenant to the land, and privity of estate. A covenant not to compete is considered to 'touch and concern' the land. The man's actual knowledge of the covenant to impose restrictions fulfills the notice requirement, allowing the covenant to run with the land.
explanation.Legal_Conclusion: Given the man's actual knowledge of the covenant, the covenant will run with the land, supporting the nephew's action to enjoin the man from using Blackacre for filling station purposes, making option A the correct answer.

question: A landowner owned and occupied Blackacre, which was a tract of land improved with a one-family house. His friend orally offered him $50,000 for Blackacre, the fair market value, and he accepted. Because they were friends, they saw no need for attorneys or written contracts and shook hands on the deal. The friend paid the landowner $5,000 down in cash and agreed to pay the balance of $45,000 at an agreed closing time and place. Before the closing, the friend inherited another home and asked the landowner to return his $5,000. The landowner refused, and, at the time set for the closing, the landowner tendered a good deed to the friend and declared his intention to vacate Blackacre the next day. The landowner demanded that the friend complete the purchase. The friend refused. The fair market value of Blackacre has remained $50,000. In an appropriate action brought by the landowner against the friend for specific performance, if the landowner loses, the most likely reason will be that

options.optionA: A. the agreement was oral.
options.optionB: B. keeping the $5,000 is the landowner's exclusive remedy.
options.optionC: C. The friend had a valid reason for not closing.
options.optionD: D. The landowner remained in possession on the day set for the closing.

explanation.Legal_Concept: The Statute of Frauds requirement for contracts for the sale of land to be in writing and signed by the party to be charged.
explanation.Fact_Analysis: The landowner and his friend entered into an oral agreement for the sale of Blackacre, with the friend paying $5,000 down and agreeing to pay the balance at closing. The friend later refused to complete the purchase, and the landowner sought specific performance.
explanation.Rule_Application: The Statute of Frauds requires that contracts for the sale of land be in writing and signed by the party to be charged. Since the agreement between the landowner and his friend was oral, it does not meet this requirement, rendering it unenforceable.
explanation.Legal_Conclusion: Given that the contract for the sale of Blackacre was not memorialized in a writing as required by the Statute of Frauds, the landowner's action for specific performance will likely fail, making answer A the correct choice.

question: The owner of Whiteacre in fee simple leased Whiteacre to a tenant for a term of ten years by properly executed written instrument. The lease was promptly and properly recorded. It contained an option for the tenant to purchase Whiteacre by tendering $250,000 as a purchase price any time "during the term of this lease." One year later, the tenant, by a properly executed written instrument, purported to assign the option to his brother, expressly retaining all of the remaining terms of the lease. The instrument of assignment was promptly and properly recorded. Two years later, the owner contracted to sell Whiteacre to his friend and to convey a marketable title "subject to rights of the tenant under her lease." The friend refused to close because of the outstanding option assigned to the brother. The owner brought an appropriate action against the friend for specific performance. If judgment is rendered in favor of the owner, it will be because the relevant jurisdiction has adopted a rule on a key issue as to which various state courts have split. Which of the following identifies the determinative rule or doctrine upon which the split occurs, and states the position favorable to the owner.

options.optionA: A. In a contract to buy, any form of "subject to a lease" clause that fails to mention expressly an existing option means that the seller is agreeing to sell free and clear of any option originally included in the lease.
options.optionB: B. Marketable title can be conveyed so long as any outstanding option not mentioned in the purchase contract has not yet been exercised.
options.optionC: C. Options to purchase by lessees are subject to the Rule Against Perpetuities.
options.optionD: D. Options to purchase contained in a lease cannot be assigned separately from the lease.

explanation.Legal_Concept: Assignment of options to purchase in a lease, specifically whether such options can be assigned separately from the lease itself.
explanation.Fact_Analysis: The tenant had a lease for years with an option to purchase Whiteacre during the term of the lease. The tenant attempted to assign the option to his brother while retaining the remaining terms of the lease. The issue arises in the context of a contract for the sale of Whiteacre, where the buyer is concerned about the outstanding option.
explanation.Rule_Application: The key issue is whether the tenant, as a lessee, can assign the option to purchase separately from the lease. The relevant rule is that options to purchase contained in a lease for years cannot be assigned separately from the lease. This is because the tenant only has an alienable interest in the leasehold itself, not in the option to purchase as a separate property interest.
explanation.Legal_Conclusion: Given that the tenant attempted to assign the option to purchase while retaining the lease, and considering the rule that options to purchase in a lease cannot be assigned separately, the correct answer is D. This conclusion supports the owner's position in the specific performance action, as the outstanding option would not be a valid concern for the buyer.

question: Blackacre is a large tract of land owned by a religious group. On Blackacre, the religious group erected a large residential building where its members reside. Blackacre is surrounded by rural residential properties and its only access to a public way is afforded by an easement over a strip of land 30 feet wide. The easement was granted to the religious group by deed from a businesswoman, the owner of one of the adjacent residential properties. The religious group built a driveway on the strip, and the easement was used for 20 years without incident or objection. Last year, as permitted by the applicable zoning ordinance, the religious group constructed a 200-bed nursing home and a parking lot on Blackacre, using all of Blackacre that was available for such development. The nursing home was very successful, and on Sundays visitors to the nursing home overflowed the parking facilities on Blackacre and parked all along the driveway from early in the morning through the evening hours. After two Sundays of the resulting congestion and inconvenience, the businesswoman erected a barrier across the driveway on Sundays preventing any use of the driveway by anyone seeking access to Blackacre. The religious group objected. The businesswoman brought an appropriate action to terminate the easement. The most likely result in this action is that the court will hold for

options.optionA: A. The businesswoman, because the religious group excessively expanded the use of the dominant tenement.
options.optionB: B. The businesswoman, because the parking on the driveway exceeded the scope of the easement.
options.optionC: C. The religious group, because expanded use of the easement does not terminate the easement.
options.optionD: D. The religious group, because the businesswoman's use of self-help denies her the right to equitable relief.

explanation.Legal_Concept: The scope and permanence of easements, particularly in relation to the reasonable development of the dominant estate.
explanation.Fact_Analysis: The religious group owns Blackacre, a large tract of land with a residential building and a recently constructed nursing home. The group has an easement over a 30-foot wide strip of land for access to a public way, granted by a businesswoman who owns an adjacent property. The easement has been used without incident for 20 years, but its use has increased with the success of the nursing home, leading to congestion on Sundays.
explanation.Rule_Application: Easements are generally considered permanent and are assumed to accommodate the reasonable development of the dominant estate. The increased use of the easement due to the nursing home's success is likely within the scope of what was reasonably contemplated by the parties when the easement was granted, particularly given the religious group's nature and the fact that the increased use occurs on Sundays.
explanation.Legal_Conclusion: Given that the increased use of the easement is likely within its intended scope and does not constitute an excessive expansion of the dominant tenement, the court will most likely hold for the religious group, supporting option C.

question: A farmer leased a barn to his neighbor for a term of three years. The neighbor took possession of the barn and used it for his farming purposes. The lease made the farmer responsible for structural repairs to the barn, unless they were made necessary by actions of the neighbor. One year later, the farmer conveyed the barn and its associated land to a buyer "subject to the lease to [the neighbor]." The neighbor paid the next month's rent to the buyer. The next day a portion of an exterior wall of the barn collapsed because of rot in the interior structure of the wall. The wall had appeared to be sound, but a competent engineer, on inspection, would have discovered its condition. Neither the buyer nor the neighbor had the barn inspected by an engineer. The neighbor was injured as a result of the collapse of the wall. The farmer had known that the wall was dangerously weakened by rot and needed immediate repairs, but had not told the neighbor or the buyer. There is no applicable statute. The neighbor brought an appropriate action against the farmer to recover damages for the injuries he sustained. The buyer was not a party. Which of the following is the most appropriate comment concerning the outcome of this action?

options.optionA: A. The neighbor should lose, because the buyer assumed all of the farmer's obligations by reason of the neighbor's assignment to her.
options.optionB: B. The neighbor should recover, because there is privity between lessor and lessee and it cannot be broken unilaterally.
options.optionC: C. The neighbor should recover, because the farmer knew of the danger but did not warn the neighbor.
options.optionD: D. The neighbor should lose, because he failed to inspect the barn.

explanation.Legal_Concept: Landlord's liability for concealed dangerous conditions on leased premises, particularly the duty to disclose known hazards to tenants.
explanation.Fact_Analysis: The farmer leased a barn to the neighbor and was responsible for structural repairs unless caused by the neighbor's actions. The farmer conveyed the barn to a buyer, subject to the lease, and the neighbor paid rent to the buyer. A portion of the barn's exterior wall collapsed due to hidden rot, injuring the neighbor. The farmer knew of the weakened wall but did not inform the neighbor or the buyer.
explanation.Rule_Application: A landlord has a duty to disclose known hazards on the leased premises to the tenant. This duty is especially relevant when the landlord is aware of a hidden defect that could cause harm. In this case, the farmer's concealment of the dangerously weakened wall, which he knew needed immediate repairs, rendered him liable for the neighbor's damages.
explanation.Legal_Conclusion: Given the farmer's knowledge of the hidden defect and his failure to warn the neighbor, the farmer is liable for the damages resulting from the wall's collapse. Therefore, the correct outcome is that the neighbor should recover, supporting option C.

question: An owner conveyed Blackacre to a buyer by a warranty deed. The buyer recorded the deed four days later. After the conveyance but prior to the buyer's recording of the deed, a lender properly filed a judgment against the owner. The two pertinent statutes in the jurisdiction provide the following: 1) any judgment properly filed shall, for ten years from filing, be a lien on the real property then owned or subsequently acquired by any person against whom the judgment is rendered, and 2) no conveyance or mortgage of real property shall be good against subsequent purchasers for value and without notice unless the same be recorded according to law.The recording act has no provision for a grace period. The lender joined both the owner and the buyer in an appropriate action to foreclose the judgment lien against Blackacre.If the lender is unsuccessful, it will be because

options.optionA: A. the owner's warranty of title to the buyer defeats the lender's claim.
options.optionB: B. the lender is not a purchaser for value.
options.optionC: C. any deed is superior to a judgment lien.
options.optionD: D. four days is not an unreasonable delay in recording a deed.

explanation.Legal_Concept: The protection afforded by a notice-type recording statute to bona fide purchasers for value and without notice, particularly in relation to judgment liens.
explanation.Fact_Analysis: The owner conveyed Blackacre to the buyer via a warranty deed, which was recorded four days later. Before the recording, a lender filed a judgment against the owner, creating a lien on the owner's real property. The jurisdiction's statutes provide that a judgment lien is effective for ten years and that a conveyance is only valid against subsequent purchasers if recorded according to law.
explanation.Rule_Application: Under a notice act, a party must be a bona fide purchaser who recorded their deed without notice of earlier purchasers and gave value for their interest. The lender's interest arises from a judgment lien rather than payment of valuable consideration, so the lender is not a bona fide purchaser and is not protected by the recording statute. In contrast, the buyer is protected as a bona fide purchaser, and the owner no longer holds an interest in Blackacre.
explanation.Legal_Conclusion: Because the lender is not a bona fide purchaser and did not give value for the interest, the lender's judgment lien does not prevail against the buyer's recorded deed. Therefore, the lender will be unsuccessful in foreclosing the judgment lien against Blackacre, supporting option B.

question: Sixty years ago by a properly executed and recorded deed, a grandfather conveyed Greenacre, a tract of land: "To my grandson for life, then to my grandson's widow for her life, then to my grandson's child or children in equal shares." At that time, the grandson was six years old. Shortly thereafter, the grandfather died testate. His grandson was his only heir at law. The grandfather's will left his entire estate to First Church. Twenty-five years ago, when he was 41, the grandson married Maria who was then 20 years old; they had one child. Maria and the child were killed in an automobile accident three years ago when the child was 21. The child died testate, leaving his entire estate to the American Red Cross. His father (the grandson) was the child's sole heir at law. Two years ago, the grandson married Zelda. They had no children. This year, the grandson died testate, survived by his widow, Zelda, to whom he left his entire estate. The common-law Rule Against Perpetuities is unchanged by statute in the jurisdiction. In an appropriate action to determine the ownership of Greenacre, the court should find that title is vested in

options.optionA: A. First Church, because the widow of the grandson was unborn at the time of conveyance and, hence, the remainder violated the Rule Against Perpetuities.
options.optionB: B. Zelda, because her life estate and her inheritance from the grandson (who was the grandfather's sole heir at law and who was the child's sole heir at law) merged the entire title in her.
options.optionC: C. the American Red Cross, because the child had a vested remaider interest (as the only child of the grandson) that he inherited, the life estate to the grandson's widow being of no force and effect.
options.optionD: D. Zelda for life under the terms of the grandfather's deed, with the remainder to the American Red Cross as the successor in interest to the grandson's only child.

explanation.Legal_Concept: The Rule Against Perpetuities (RAP) in the context of vested and contingent remainders, and its application to a multi-generational conveyance of real property.
explanation.Fact_Analysis: The grandfather conveyed Greenacre to his grandson for life, then to the grandson's widow for life, and finally to the grandson's child or children. The grandson was six years old at the time, and the conveyance occurred sixty years ago. The grandson married Maria, had a child, and after Maria's death, married Zelda. The child died, leaving the estate to the American Red Cross. The grandson died, leaving his estate to Zelda.
explanation.Rule_Application: The RAP requires that all interests must vest, if at all, within 21 years after the death of a life in being at the creation of the interest. However, vested interests are not subject to the RAP. Interests are vested if there is no condition attached, and the holder has a present or certain right to take possession when prior estates terminate. The grandfather conveyed his entire interest, leaving no reversion or contingent remainder, making all interests vested or failed within the grandson's life.
explanation.Legal_Conclusion: Given that all interests vested or failed within the grandson's life, and the grandson's child's interest vested upon birth and was devisable, the correct answer is D. Zelda holds a vested life estate, and the remainder goes to the American Red Cross as the successor in interest to the grandson's only child.

question: A man owned Blackacre, a tract of undeveloped land. Blackacre abuts Whiteacre, a tract of land owned by the state's governmental energy agency. At Whiteacre, the agency has operated a waste-to-electricity recycling facility for 12 years. Blackacre and Whiteacre are in a remote area and Whiteacre is the only developed parcel of real estate within a ten-mile radius. The boundary line between Blackacre and Whiteacre had never been surveyed or marked on the face of the earth. During the past 12 years, some of the trucks bringing waste to the agency facility have dumped their loads so that the piles of waste extend from Whiteacre onto a portion of Blackacre. However, prior to the four-week period during each calendar year when the agency facility is closed for inspection and repairs, the waste piles are reduced to minimal levels so that during each of the four-week closures no waste was, in fact, piled on Blackacre. Neither the man nor any representative of the agency knew the facts about the relation of the boundary line to the waste piles. The time for acquiring title by adverse possession in the jurisdiction is ten years. Last year, the man died, and his son succeeded him as the owner of Blackacre. The son became aware of the facts, demanded that the agency stop using Blackacre for the piling of waste, and, when the agency refused his demand, brought an appropriate action to enjoin any such use of Blackacre in the future. If the agency prevails in that action, it will be because

options.optionA: A. the facts constitute adverse possession and title to the portion of Blackacre concerned has vested in the agency.
options.optionB: B. The man's failure to keep himself informed as to the agency's use of Blackacre and his failure to object constituted implied consent to the continuation of that use.
options.optionC: C. the interest of the public in the conversion of waste to energy overrides any entitlement of the son to equitable remedies.
options.optionD: D. the power of eminent domain of the state makes the claim of the son moot.

explanation.Legal_Concept: Adverse possession, specifically the requirements for obtaining title to land through continuous, uninterrupted, and hostile possession.
explanation.Fact_Analysis: The agency has been operating a waste-to-electricity recycling facility on Whiteacre for 12 years, with waste piles occasionally extending onto Blackacre, which is owned by the man and later his son. The boundary line was never surveyed or marked, and neither party was aware of the exact boundary. The agency would reduce waste piles to minimal levels during the facility's annual four-week closure.
explanation.Rule_Application: To establish adverse possession, the agency must demonstrate actual physical possession, continuous and uninterrupted possession, exclusion of others, hostile possession, and open and notorious possession. The agency's actions, including the annual cleanup, are consistent with the type of possession a usual owner of an undeveloped tract like Blackacre would make.
