explanation.Legal_Conclusion: Given that the agency has met the requirements for adverse possession, having possessed the land for the statutory period of ten years, title to the portion of Blackacre concerned has vested in the agency. Therefore, the agency will prevail in the action, supporting option A.

question: The owner of Greenacre, a tract of land, owned it in fee simple. Five years ago, he executed and delivered to a woman an instrument in the proper form of a warranty deed that conveyed Greenacre to the woman "for and during the term of her natural life." No other estate or interest or person taking an interest was mentioned. The woman took possession of Greenacre and has remained in possession. Fifteen months ago, the owner died, leaving a will that has been duly admitted to probate. The will, inter alia had the following provision: "I devise Greenacre to my best friend for her natural life and from and after her death to my second best friend, his heirs and assigns, forever." Administration of the owner's estate has been completed. The best friend claims the immediate right to possession of Greenacre. The second best friend also asserts a right to immediate possession. In an appropriate lawsuit to which the woman, the best friend, and the second best friend are parties, who should be adjudged to have the right to immediate possession?

options.optionA: A. The woman, because no subsequent act of the owner would affect her life estate.
options.optionB: B. The best friend, because the owner's will was the final and definitive expression of his intent.
options.optionC: C. The best friend, because the woman's estate terminated with the death of the owner.
options.optionD: D. The second best friend, because the woman's estate terminated with the owner's death and all that the owner had was the right to transfer his reversion in fee simple.

explanation.Legal_Concept: Life estates and future interests in real property, specifically the rules governing the creation, duration, and transfer of life estates.
explanation.Fact_Analysis: The owner of Greenacre conveyed a life estate to the woman, measured by her natural life, and later devised a life estate to the best friend in his will, with a vested remainder to the second best friend. The woman has been in possession of Greenacre for five years, and the owner has since died.
explanation.Rule_Application: A life estate is unaffected by any action the grantor takes after conveying it, and its duration is measured by the life of the grantee. In this case, the woman's life estate was conveyed to her for the term of her natural life, and the owner's subsequent will does not alter her interest. The best friend's life estate and the second best friend's vested remainder will take effect only after the woman's death.
explanation.Legal_Conclusion: Given that the woman's life estate is unaffected by the owner's subsequent actions, including his will, she retains the right to immediate possession of Greenacre. Therefore, the correct answer is A, the woman, because no subsequent act of the owner would affect her life estate.

question: An owner owned in fee simple two adjoining lots, Lot 1 and 2. He conveyed in fee simple Lot 1 to a veterinarian. The deed was in usual form of a warranty deed with the following provision inserted in the appropriate place: "Grantor, for himself, his heirs and assigns, does covenant and agree that any reasonable expense incurred by grantee, his heirs and assigns, as the result of having to repair the retaining wall presently situated on Lot 1 at the common boundary with Lot 2, shall be reimbursed one-half the costs of repairs; and by this provision the parties intend a covenant running with the land." The veterinarian conveyed Lot 1 in fee simple to a woman by warranty deed in usual and regular form. The deed omitted any reference to the retaining wall or any covenant. Fifty years after the owner's conveyance to the veterinarian, the woman conveyed Lot 1 in fee simple to a man by warranty deed in usual form; this deed omitted any reference to the retaining wall or the covenant. There is no statute that applies to any aspect of the problems presented except a recording act and a statute providing for acquisition of title after ten years of adverse possession. All conveyances by deeds were for a consideration equal to fair market value. The deed from the owner to the veterinarian was never recorded. All other deeds were promptly and properly recorded. Lot 2 is now owned by a businessman, who took by intestate succession from the owner, now dead. The man expended $3,500 on the retaining wall. Then he obtained all of the original deeds in the chain from the owner to him. Shortly thereafter, the man discovered the covenant in the owner's deed to the veterinarian. He demanded that the businessman pay $1,750, and when the businessman refused, the man instituted an appropriate action to recover that sum from the businessman. In such action, the businessman asserted all defenses available to him. If judgment is for the businessman, it will be because

options.optionA: A. The man is barred by adverse possession.
options.optionB: B. The veterinarian's deed from the owner was never recorded.
options.optionC: C. The man did not know about the covenant until after he had incurred the expenses and, hence, could not have relied on it.
options.optionD: D. The man's expenditures were not proved to be reasonable and customary.

explanation.Legal_Concept: Covenants running with the land, specifically the requirements for such covenants to be enforceable and the implications of their terms on subsequent landowners.
explanation.Fact_Analysis: The original owner conveyed Lot 1 to a veterinarian with a covenant requiring reimbursement of half the costs for repairing the retaining wall on the common boundary with Lot 2. The covenant was intended to run with the land but was not mentioned in subsequent deeds. The man, who later purchased Lot 1, discovered the covenant after incurring $3,500 in expenses for the retaining wall and sought reimbursement from the businessman, who inherited Lot 2.
explanation.Rule_Application: For a covenant to run with the land, it must meet four elements: intent for it to run with the land, notice (if the successor is a bona fide purchaser), it must 'touch and concern' the land, and privity of estate. In this case, the covenant meets these requirements. However, its terms specify that only 'reasonable' expenditures are reimbursable, which becomes a critical factor in determining the enforceability of the covenant against the businessman.
explanation.Legal_Conclusion: Given that the covenant runs with the land and its terms require expenditures to be 'reasonable' for reimbursement, the judgment in favor of the businessman would be based on the man's expenditures not being proved to be reasonable and customary, supporting option D.

question: A woman entered into a valid written contract to purchase Blackacre, a large tract of land, from its owner for its fair market value of $50,000. The contract was assignable by the woman. The woman duly notified the owner to convey title to the woman and a friend of the woman whom the woman had not seen for many years. When the woman learned that the friend would have to sign certain documents in connection with the closing, she asked her brother to attend the closing and pretend to be the friend. The woman and her brother attended the closing, and the owner executed an instrument in the proper form of a deed, purporting to convey Blackacre to the woman and the friend, as tenants in common. The brother pretended that he was the friend, and he signed the friend's name to all the required documents. The woman provided the entire $50,000 consideration for the transaction. The deed was promptly and properly recorded. Unknown to the woman or her brother, the friend had died several months before the closing. The friend's will, which was duly probated, devised "All my real estate to my nephew" and the residue of his estate to the woman. The woman and the nephew have been unable to agree as to the status or disposition of Blackacre. The nephew brought an appropriate action against the owner and the woman to quiet title to an undivided one-half interest in Blackacre. The court should hold that legal title to Blackacre is vested

options.optionA: A. all in the owner.
options.optionB: B. all in the woman.
options.optionC: C. one-half in the woman and one-half in the owner.
options.optionD: D. one-half in the woman and one-half in the nephew.

explanation.Legal_Concept: The validity of a deed and the conveyance of property title, particularly in the context of a forged signature and the death of the intended grantee.
explanation.Fact_Analysis: The woman entered into a contract to purchase Blackacre and attempted to convey a one-half interest to a friend by having her brother forge the friend's signature at the closing. However, the friend had died several months prior to the closing, and the woman was unaware of this fact.
explanation.Rule_Application: A deed to a dead person cannot convey good title. Therefore, the interest that the woman attempted to convey to the friend was never passed, and the owner retained that interest. The woman, however, did obtain a valid interest in the property for herself.
explanation.Legal_Conclusion: Given that the execution of the contract was only valid with regard to the woman, and the attempted conveyance to the friend was invalid due to the friend's death, the woman and the owner both hold a one-half interest in the property. Therefore, the correct answer is C, one-half in the woman and one-half in the owner.

question: The owner of Blackacre, a residential lot improved with a dwelling, conveyed it for a valuable consideration to an investor. The dwelling had been constructed by a prior owner. The investor had inspected Blackacre prior to the purchase and discovered no defects. After moving in, the investor became aware that sewage seeped into the basement when the toilets were flushed. The owner said that this defect had been present for years and that he had taken no steps to hide the facts from the investor. The investor paid for the necessary repairs and brought an appropriate action against the owner to recover his cost of repair. If the investor wins, it will be because

options.optionA: A. the owner failed to disclose a latent defect.
options.optionB: B. the investor made a proper inspection.
options.optionC: C. the situation constitutes a health hazard.
options.optionD: D. the owner breached the implied warranty of habitability and fitness for purpose.

explanation.Legal_Concept: Disclosure of latent defects in real property transactions, specifically the seller's obligation to inform the buyer of hidden defects.
explanation.Fact_Analysis: The owner of Blackacre conveyed the property to the investor, who had inspected the property prior to purchase but discovered no defects. After moving in, the investor found that sewage seeped into the basement when toilets were flushed, a defect the owner was aware of but did not disclose.
explanation.Rule_Application: Sellers are required to disclose all known defects that are not open and obvious to a buyer and are prohibited from concealing such defects. Since the sewage issue was not apparent during the investor's inspection and the owner knew about it, the owner had an obligation to disclose this latent defect.
explanation.Legal_Conclusion: The investor's success in recovering the cost of repairs hinges on the owner's failure to disclose a known latent defect, making option A the correct answer.

question: The owner of Blackacre needed money. Blackacre was fairly worth $100,000, so the owner tried to borrow $60,000 from a lender on the security of Blackacre. The lender agreed, but only if the owner would convey Blackacre to the lender outright by warranty deed, with the lender agreeing orally to reconvey to the owner once the loan was paid according to its terms. The owner agreed, conveyed Blackacre to the lender by warranty deed, and the lender paid the owner $60,000 cash. The lender promptly and properly recorded the the owner's deed. Now, the owner has defaulted on repayment with $55,000 still due on the loan. The owner is still in possession. Which of the following best states the parties' rights in Blackacre?

options.optionA: A. The lender's oral agreement to reconvey is invalid under the Statute of Frauds, so the lender owns Blackacre outright.
options.optionB: B. The owner, having defaulted, has no further rights in Blackacre, so the lender may obtain summary eviction.
options.optionC: C. The attempted security arrangement is a creature unknown to the law, hence a nullity; the lender has only a personal right to $55,000 from the owner.
options.optionD: D. The lender may bring whatever foreclosure proceeding is appropriate under the laws of the jurisdiction.

explanation.Legal_Concept: Equitable mortgage and its implications on property rights and foreclosure proceedings.
explanation.Fact_Analysis: The owner conveyed Blackacre to the lender by warranty deed as security for a $60,000 loan, with the lender agreeing orally to reconvey the property once the loan was paid. The lender recorded the deed and the owner defaulted on $55,000 of the loan.
explanation.Rule_Application: An equitable mortgage is created when an absolute deed is conveyed as security for a loan with a promise to reconvey upon loan repayment. This arrangement is not subject to the Statute of Frauds, as it is not a land sale contract. Following default, the lender's remedy is foreclosure of the property, not eviction or claiming outright ownership.
explanation.Legal_Conclusion: Given the creation of an equitable mortgage, the lender's rights are those of a mortgagee, and upon the owner's default, the lender's appropriate remedy is to bring a foreclosure proceeding, as stated in option D.

question: The owner of Greenacre, conveyed Greenacre by quitclaim deed as a gift to a woman, who did not then record her deed. Later, the owner conveyed Greenacre by warranty deed to a neighbor, who paid valuable consideration, knew nothing of the woman's claim, and promptly and properly recorded. Next, the woman recorded her deed. Then the neighbor conveyed Greenacre by quitclaim deed to her son as a gift. When the possible conflict with the woman was discovered, the son recorded his deed. Greenacre at all relevant times has been vacant unoccupied land. The recording act of the jurisdiction provides: "No unrecorded conveyance or mortgage of real property shall be good against subsequent purchasers for value without notice, who shall first record." No other statute is applicable. The son has sued the woman to establish who owns Greenacre. The court will hold for

options.optionA: A. The son, because the woman was a donee.
options.optionB: B. The son, because the neighbor's purchase cut off the woman's rights.
options.optionC: C. The woman, because she recorded before the son.
options.optionD: D. The woman, because the son was a subsequent donee.

explanation.Legal_Concept: The application of a race-notice recording act in determining the priority of property interests, specifically the requirements for a bona fide purchaser to prevail under such an act.
explanation.Fact_Analysis: The owner of Greenacre conveyed the property to a woman by quitclaim deed as a gift, which she did not record. Subsequently, the owner conveyed Greenacre to a neighbor by warranty deed for valuable consideration, who then recorded the deed. The woman later recorded her deed, and the neighbor conveyed Greenacre to her son by quitclaim deed as a gift, who then recorded his deed.
explanation.Rule_Application: Under a race-notice act, a party must be a bona fide purchaser who records their deed first and acquires the land without notice of earlier purchasers. To be a bona fide purchaser, a party must give value for their interest in the land. The neighbor, having given value and recorded first, is protected by the recording act, and her purchase cut off any rights the woman may have had. The woman, having received the property as a gift and not being a bona fide purchaser, is not protected by the act.
explanation.Legal_Conclusion: Given that the neighbor was the first bona fide purchaser to record and her purchase cut off the woman's rights, the son, who received the property from the neighbor, has the better title. Therefore, the court will hold for the son, supporting option B.

question: A banker owned a commercial property, Eastgate, consisting of a one-story building rented to various retail stores and a very large parking lot. Two years ago, the banker died and left Eastgate to her nephew for life, with remainder to her godson, his heirs and assigns. The nephew was 30 years old and the godson was 20 years old when the banker died. The devise of Eastgate was made subject to any mortgage on Eastgate in effect at the time of the banker's death. When the banker executed her will, the balance of the mortgage debt on Eastgate was less than $5,000. A year before her death, the banker suffered financial reverses; and in order to meet her debts, she had mortgaged Eastgate to secure a loan of $150,000. The entire principal of the mortgage remained outstanding when she died. As a result, the net annual income from Eastgate was reduced not only by real estate taxes and regular maintenance costs, but also by the substantial mortgage interest payments that were due each month. The nephew was very dissatisfied with the limited benefit that he was receiving from the life estate. When, earlier this year, Acme, Inc., proposed to purchase Eastgate, demolish the building, pay off the mortgage, and construct a 30-story office building, the nephew was willing to accept Acme's offer. However, the godson adamantly refused the offer, even though he, as the remainderman, paid the principal portion of each monthly mortgage amortization payment. The godson was independently wealthy and wanted to convert Eastgate into a public park when he became entitled to possession. When Acme realized that the godson would not change his mind, Acme modified its proposal to a purchase of the life estate of the nephew. Acme was ready to go ahead with its building plans, relying upon a large life insurance policy on the nephew's life to protect it against the economic risk of his death. The nephew's life expectancy was 45 years. When the godson learned that the nephew had agreed to Acme's modified proposal, the godson brought an appropriate action against them to enjoin their carrying it out. There is no applicable statute. The best argument for the godson is that

options.optionA: A. Acme cannot purchase the nephew's life estate, because life estates are not assignable.
options.optionB: B. the proposed demolition of the building constitutes waste.
options.optionC: C. the godson's payment of the mortgage principal has subrogated him to the nephew's rights as a life tenant and bars the nephew's assignment of the life estate without the godson's consent.
options.optionD: D. continued existence of the one-story building is more in harmony with the ultimate use as a park than the proposed change in use.

explanation.Legal_Concept: Voluntary waste in the context of a life estate, specifically the duty of a life tenant not to make affirmative changes to the property that alter its basic use.
explanation.Fact_Analysis: The nephew, as a life tenant, and the godson, as a remainderman, have respective interests in the Eastgate property. The nephew agreed to sell his life estate to Acme, Inc., which plans to demolish the existing building and construct a 30-story office building. The godson, who pays the principal portion of the mortgage and intends to convert the property into a public park in the future, opposes the plan.
explanation.Rule_Application: A life tenant has a duty not to commit voluntary waste, which includes affirmative acts that damage the land by changing its basic use. This duty is owed to the remainderman, who has a vested interest in the property. In this case, the proposed demolition and construction of a new building would constitute a change in use, potentially amounting to voluntary waste.
explanation.Legal_Conclusion: Given the life tenant's duty to avoid voluntary waste and the remainderman's vested interest in the property, the best argument for the godson is that the proposed demolition and construction would indeed constitute waste, supporting option B.

question: A farmer owned Purpleacre, a tract of land, in fee simple. By will duly admitted to probate after his death, the farmer devised Purpleacre to "any wife who survives me with remainder to such of my children as are living at her death." The farmer was survived by his wife and by three adult children. Thereafter, one of the children died and by will duly admitted to probate devised his entire estate to a friend. The remaining two siblings were the deceased sibling's heirs at law. Later the wife died. In an appropriate lawsuit to which the two remaining siblings and the friend are parties, title to Purpleacre is at issue. In such lawsuit, judgment should be that title to Purpleacre is in

options.optionA: A. The two siblings and the friend, because the earliest vesting of remainders is favored and reference to the wife's death should be construed as relating to time of taking possession.
options.optionB: B. The two siblings and the friend, because the provision requiring survival of children violates the Rule Against Perpetuities since the surviving wife might have been a person unborn at the time of writing of the will.
options.optionC: C. The two remaining siblings, because the deceased sibling's remainder must descend by intestacy and is not devisable.
options.optionD: D. The two remaining siblings, because the remainders were contingent upon surviving the life tenant.

explanation.Legal_Concept: The Rule of Remainders in Estates, specifically contingent remainders and their vesting requirements.
explanation.Fact_Analysis: The farmer devised Purpleacre to his surviving wife with a remainder to his children living at her death. One of the children died before the wife, devising their estate to a friend, while the two remaining siblings were the deceased sibling's heirs at law.
explanation.Rule_Application: A contingent remainder must vest at the end of the preceding estate, in this case, the wife's life estate. Since the remainder is contingent upon the children surviving the wife, only those children alive at her death can inherit. The deceased sibling's estate did not include a remainder in Purpleacre because he predeceased the wife, and thus had no interest to bequeath to his friend.
explanation.Legal_Conclusion: Given that the remainder was contingent upon surviving the life tenant (the wife), only the two remaining siblings held a valid remainder in Purpleacre. Therefore, judgment should be that title to Purpleacre is in the two remaining siblings, supporting option D.

question: A woman owned Goldacre, a tract of land, in fee simple. By warranty deed, she conveyed Goldacre in fee simple to her brother for a recited consideration of "$10 and other valuable consideration." The deed was promptly and properly recorded. One week later, the woman and her brother executed a written document that stated that the conveyance of Goldacre was for the purpose of establishing a trust for the benefit of the woman's son. Her brother expressly accepted the trust and signed the document with the woman. This written agreement was not authenticated to be eligible for recordation and there never was an attempt to record it. The brother entered into possession of Goldacre and distributed the net income from Goldacre to his sister's son at appropriate intervals. Five years later, the brother conveyed Goldacre in fee simple to a friend by warranty deed. The friend paid the fair market value of Goldacre, had no knowledge of the written agreement between the brother and sister, and entered into possession of Goldacre. The woman's son made demand upon the friend for distribution of income at the next usual time income from the trust would have distributed. The friend refused. The son brought an appropriate action against the friend for a decree requiring her to perform the trust the brother had theretofore recognized. In such action, judgment should be for

options.optionA: A. The son, because a successor in title to the trustee takes title subject to the grantor's trust.
options.optionB: B. The son, because equitable interests are not subject to the recording act.
options.optionC: C. The friend, because, as a bona fide purchaser, she took free of the trust encumbering the brother's title.
options.optionD: D. The friend, because no trust was ever created since the woman had no title at the time of the purported creation.

explanation.Legal_Concept: Trust law, specifically the rights and obligations of a trustee and the protection afforded to bona fide purchasers.
explanation.Fact_Analysis: The woman conveyed Goldacre to her brother in fee simple, who then accepted a trust for the benefit of the woman's son. The brother later sold Goldacre to a friend, who purchased for value without knowledge of the trust. The son seeks a decree requiring the friend to perform the trust.
explanation.Rule_Application: A trust is valid even if not written or recorded, and its creation does not need to be contemporaneous with the transaction of land. However, a bona fide purchaser, who buys for value without notice of any encumbrances, takes title free of any trust. The friend, as a bona fide purchaser, did not assume the duties of the trustee and is not bound by the trust.
explanation.Legal_Conclusion: The son's claim should be against the brother for breach of fiduciary duty, not against the friend. Therefore, judgment should be for the friend, supporting option C.

question: A doctor owned Blackacre, which was improved with a dwelling. Her neighbor owned Whiteacre, an adjoining unimproved lot suitable for constructing a dwelling. The neighbor executed and delivered a deed granting to the doctor an easement over the westerly 15 feet of Whiteacre for convenient ingress and egress to a public street, although the doctor's lot did abut another public street. The doctor did not then record the neighbor's deed. After the doctor constructed and started using a driveway within the described 15-foot string in a clearly visible manner, the neighbor borrowed $10,000 cash from a bank and gave the bank a mortgage on Whiteacre. The mortgage was promptly and properly recorded. The doctor then recorded the neighbor's deed granting the easement. The neighbor subsequently defaulted on her loan payments to the bank. The recording act of the jurisdiction provides: "No conveyance or mortgage of real property shall be good against subsequent purchasers for value and without notice unless the same be recorded according to law." In an appropriate foreclosure action as to Whiteacre, brought against the doctor and the neighbor, the bank seeks, among other things, to have the doctor's easement declared subordinate to the bank's mortgage, so that the easement will be terminated by completion of the foreclosure. If the doctor's easement is NOT terminated, it will be because

options.optionA: A. the recording of the deed granting the easement prior to the foreclosure action protects the doctor's rights.
options.optionB: B. the easement provides access from Blackacre to a public street.
options.optionC: C. the doctor's easement is appurtenant to Blackacre and thus cannot be separated from Blackacre.
options.optionD: D. visible use of the easement by the doctor put the bank on notice of the easement.

explanation.Legal_Concept: The protection of easement rights under a notice-type recording statute, specifically the impact of notice on the priority of interests in real property.
explanation.Fact_Analysis: The doctor was granted an easement over the neighbor's property for ingress and egress, which was not initially recorded but was visibly used and developed by the doctor. The neighbor then mortgaged the property to the bank, which was recorded. The doctor subsequently recorded the easement deed.
explanation.Rule_Application: Under a notice-type recording statute, a party must be a bona fide purchaser who recorded their deed without notice of earlier purchasers to prevail. Notice can be either record notice or inquiry notice, which arises from open and obvious use of the property. The bank's status as a bona fide purchaser is compromised if it had notice of the easement, either through record or inquiry notice.
explanation.Legal_Conclusion: Given that the doctor's use and development of the easement were open and obvious, the bank arguably had inquiry notice of the easement. This notice would prevent the bank from prevailing under the recording statute, making the doctor's easement rights superior to the bank's mortgage interest. Therefore, the easement would not be terminated by the foreclosure, supporting answer D.

question: A hockey fan had a season ticket for her home team's hockey games at the local arena(Section B, Row 12, Seat 16). During the intermission between the first and second periods of a game, the hockey fan solicited signatures for a petition urging that the coach of the hockey team be fired. The local arena and hockey team are owned by a privately owned entity. As evidenced by many prominently displayed signs, this entity prohibits all solicitations anywhere within the arena at any time and in any manner. The privately owned entity notified the hockey fan to cease her solicitation of signatures. The hockey fan continued to seek signatures on her petition during the hockey team's next three home games at the arena. Each time, the entity notified the hockey fan to cease such solicitation. The hockey fan announced her intention to seek signatures on her petition again during the hockey team's next home game at the arena. The entity wrote a letter informing her that her season ticket was canceled and tendered a refund for the unused portion. The hockey fan refused the tender and brought an appropriate action to establish the right to attend all home games. In this action, the court will decide for

options.optionA: A. the privately owned entity, because it has a right and obligation to control activities on realty it owns and has invited the public to visit.
options.optionB: B. the privately owned entity, because the hockey fan's ticket to hockey games created only a license.
options.optionC: C. the hockey fan, because, having paid value for the ticket, her right to be present cannot be revoked.
options.optionD: D. the hockey fan, because she was not committing a nuisance by her activities.

explanation.Legal_Concept: The distinction between a property interest and a license in the context of a ticket to a private event or venue.
explanation.Fact_Analysis: The hockey fan purchased a season ticket to attend hockey games at a privately owned arena, where the entity prohibited all solicitations. Despite being notified multiple times, the hockey fan continued to solicit signatures for a petition, leading the entity to cancel her season ticket and offer a refund.
explanation.Rule_Application: A ticket is considered a mere license rather than a property interest, granting the holder a contractual right to use a portion of the issuer's property for a fixed period. The issuer retains the right to revoke the license, with potential liability for damages if done wrongfully. The ticket holder's remedy for wrongful revocation lies in contract law, not property law.
explanation.Legal_Conclusion: Given that the hockey fan's ticket was a license, the privately owned entity had the right to revoke it, especially considering the fan's repeated disregard for the entity's rules. Therefore, the correct decision would be in favor of the privately owned entity, supporting option B.

question: A corporation owned Blackacre in fee simple, as the real estate records showed. The corporation entered into a valid written contract to convey Blackacre to an individual buyer. At closing, the buyer paid the price in full and received an instrument in the proper form of a deed, signed by duly authorized corporate officers on behalf of the corporation, purporting to convey Blackacre to the buyer. The buyer did not then record the deed or take possession of Blackacre. Next, a man (who had no knowledge of the contract or the deed) obtained a substantial money judgment against the corporation. Then, the buyer recorded the deed from the corporation. Thereafter, the man properly filed the judgment against the corporation. A statute of the jurisdiction provides: "Any judgment properly filed shall, for ten years from filing, be a lien on the real property then owned or subsequently acquired by any person against whom the judgment is rendered." Afterward, the buyer entered into a written contract to convey Blackacre to a developer. The developer objected to the buyer's title and refused to close. The recording act of the jurisdiction provides: "Unless the same be recorded according to law, no conveyance shall be good against subsequent purchasers for value and without notice." The buyer brought an appropriate action to require the developer to complete the purchase contract. The court should decide for

options.optionA: A. the developer, because the man's judgment was obtained before the buyer recorded the deed from the corporation.
options.optionB: B. the developer, because even though the corporation's deed to the buyer prevented the man's judgment from being a lien on Blackacre, the man's filed judgment poses a threat of litigation.
options.optionC: C. the buyer, because she recorded her deed before the man filed his judgment.
options.optionD: D. the buyer, because she received the deed from the corporation before the man filed his judgment.

explanation.Legal_Concept: The protection afforded by a notice-type recording act to a bona fide purchaser for value who records their deed without notice of earlier purchasers.
explanation.Fact_Analysis: The buyer received the deed from the corporation before the judgment was filed against the corporation, indicating she had no notice of it. She then recorded her deed, still without notice of any judgments. The man's judgment was filed after the buyer recorded her deed.
explanation.Rule_Application: Under a notice act, a bona fide purchaser who records their deed without notice of earlier purchasers is protected against subsequent claims. To be a bona fide purchaser, one must give value for their interest in the land. The buyer gave value and had no notice of the judgment when she received and recorded her deed, thus she is protected against the man's claim.
explanation.Legal_Conclusion: Given that the buyer is a protected bona fide purchaser under the recording act, she will be able to provide good title to the developer at closing. Therefore, she may compel the developer to make the purchase, supporting answer D.

question: A man's estate plan included a revocable trust established 35 years ago with a bank as trustee. The principal asset of the trust has always been Blackacre, a very profitable, debt-free office building. The trust instrument instructs the trustee to pay the net income to the man for life, and, after the death of the man, to pay the net income to his wife for life; and, after her death, to distribute the net trust estate as she may appoint by will, or in default of her exercise of this power of appointment, to the man's son (the wife's stepson). The man died 30 years ago survived by his wife and son. The man had not revoked or amended the trust agreement. A few years after the man's death, his wife remarried. She then had a daughter, was widowed for a second time, and then died last year. Her will contained only one dispositive provision: "I give my entire estate to my daughter, and I intentionally make no provision for my stepson." The daughter is now 22 years old. The common-law Rule Against Perpetuities is unmodified by statute in the jurisdiction. There are no other applicable statutes. The stepson brought an appropriate action against the daughter to determine who was entitled to the net trust estate and thus to Blackacre. If the court rules for the daughter, it will be because

options.optionA: A. the wife's life estate and general power of appointment merge into complete ownership in the wife.
options.optionB: B. the Rule Against Perpetuities does not apply to general powers of appointment.
options.optionC: C. the jurisdiction deems "entire estate" to be a reference to Blackacre or to the wife's general power of appointment.
options.optionD: D. the wife intended that her stepson should not benefit by reason of her death.

explanation.Legal_Concept: The Rule Against Perpetuities and the exercise of a general power of testamentary appointment in a trust.
explanation.Fact_Analysis: The wife was given a general power of testamentary appointment over the net trust estate of Blackacre, which she could exercise in her will. The wife's will contains a provision leaving her entire estate to her daughter, without explicitly referencing the power of appointment or Blackacre.
explanation.Rule_Application: The Rule Against Perpetuities does not directly apply to the exercise of a general power of appointment. However, the key issue is whether the wife's will effectively exercises the power of appointment. Most jurisdictions require specific language in the will to exercise the power, but the court may interpret the wife's reference to her 'entire estate' as an exercise of the power if it deems it to include Blackacre or the power of appointment.
explanation.Legal_Conclusion: If the court rules for the daughter, it will be because the court interprets the wife's will as exercising the power of appointment through the reference to her 'entire estate', which the court deems to include Blackacre or the power of appointment, supporting option C.

question: A landlord owned Blackacre in fee simple. Three years ago, the landlord and a tenant agreed to a month-to-month tenancy with the tenant paying the landlord rent each month. After six months of the tenant's occupancy, the landlord suggested to the tenant that she could buy Blackacre for a monthly payment of no more than her rent. The landlord and the tenant orally agreed that the tenant would pay $25,000 in cash, the annual real estate taxes, the annual fire insurance premiums, and the costs of maintaining Blackacre, plus the monthly mortgage payments that the landlord owed on Blackacre. They further orally agreed that within six years the tenant could pay whatever mortgage balances were then due and the landlord would give her a warranty deed to the property. The tenant's average monthly payments did turn out to be the same as her monthly rent. The tenant fully complied with all of the obligations she had undertaken. She made some structural modifications to Blackacre. Blackacre is now worth 50% more than it was when the landlord and the tenant made their oral agreement. The tenant made her financing arrangements and was ready to complete the purchase of Blackacre, but the landlord refused to close. The tenant brought an appropriate action for specific performance against the landlord to enforce the agreement. The court should rule for

options.optionA: A. The landlord, because the agreements were oral and violated the statute of frauds.
options.optionB: B. The landlord, subject to the return of the $25,000, because the arrangement was still a tenancy.
options.optionC: C. The tenant, because the doctrine of part performance applies.
options.optionD: D. The tenant, because the statute of frauds does not apply to oral purchase and sale agreements between landlords and tenants in possession.

explanation.Legal_Concept: The doctrine of part performance as an exception to the statute of frauds in contracts for the sale of land.
explanation.Fact_Analysis: The landlord and tenant entered into an oral agreement where the tenant would pay various costs and mortgage payments with the option to purchase the property within six years. The tenant fully complied with the agreement, made structural modifications to the property, and was ready to complete the purchase, but the landlord refused to close.
explanation.Rule_Application: The doctrine of part performance allows for the enforcement of an oral contract for the sale of land if there is a definite and unambiguous oral contract and a performance by the buyer that clearly indicates a contract existed, such as making improvements to the property or taking possession of it. In this case, the tenant's possession of and improvements to the property, along with the clear terms of the oral contract, establish a contract through part performance.
explanation.Legal_Conclusion: Given the tenant's performances and the clear terms of the oral contract, the doctrine of part performance applies, and the court should rule in favor of the tenant for specific performance, supporting option C.

question: By a writing, an owner leased his home, Blackacre, to a tenant for a term of three years, ending December 31 of last year, at a rent of $1,000 per month. The lease provided that the tenant could sublet and assign. The tenant lived in Blackacre for one year and paid the rent promptly. After one year, the tenant leased Blackacre to a friend for one year at a rent of $1,000 per month. The friend took possession of Blackcare and lived there for six months but, because of her unemployment, paid no rent. After six months, on June 30 the friend abandoned Blackacre, which remained vacant for the balance of that year. The tenant again took possession of Blackacre at the beginning of the third and final year of the term but paid the owner no rent. At the end of the lease term, the owner brought an appropriate action against both the tenant and the friend to recover $24,000, the unpaid rent. In such action the owner is entitled to a judgment

options.optionA: A. against the tenant individually for $24,000, and no judgment against the friend.
options.optionB: B. against the tenant individually for $18,000, and against the friend individually for $6,000.
options.optionC: C. against the tenant for $12,000, and against the tenant and the friend jointly and severally for $12,000.
options.optionD: D. against the tenant individually for $18,000, and against the tenant and the friend jointly and severally for $6,000.

explanation.Legal_Concept: Distinction between assignment and sublease in landlord-tenant law, specifically the liability implications for the original tenant and the sublessee or assignee.
explanation.Fact_Analysis: The tenant leased Blackacre for three years and then subleased it to a friend for one year. The friend paid no rent and abandoned the property after six months. The tenant retook possession for the final year but paid no rent. The owner seeks $24,000 in unpaid rent from both the tenant and the friend.
explanation.Rule_Application: A sublessee has no liability to the original landlord due to the lack of privity of contract or privity of estate. In contrast, an assignee would assume all rights and duties under the original lease. Since the tenant only transferred the property to the friend for a limited time, the friend is a sublessee, and only the tenant is liable for the unpaid rent.
explanation.Legal_Conclusion: Given that the friend was merely a sublessee and not an assignee, the tenant bears sole liability for the entire term of the lease. Therefore, the owner is entitled to a judgment against the tenant individually for the full $24,000 in unpaid rent, supporting option A.

question: A landowner owned Lot 1 in fee simple in a properly approved subdivision, designed and zoned for industrial use. His neighbor owned the adjoining Lot 2 in the same subdivision. The plat of the subdivision was recorded as authorized by statute. Twelve years ago, the landowner erected an industrial building wholly situated on Lot 1 but with one wall along the boundary common with Lot 2. The construction was done as authorized by a building permit, validly obtained under applicable statutes, ordinances, and regulations. Further, the construction was regularly inspected and passed as being in compliance with all building code requirements. Lot 2 remained vacant until six months ago, when the neighbor began excavation pursuant to a building permit authorizing the erection of an industrial building situated on Lot 2 but with one wall along the boundary common with Lot 1. The excavation caused subsidence of a portion of Lot 1 that resulted in injury to the landowner's building. The excavation was not done negligently or with any malicious intent to injure. In the jurisdiction, the time to acquire title by adverse possession or rights by prescription is 10 years. The landowner brought an appropriate action against the neighbor to recover damages resulting from the injuries in the building on Lot 1. In such lawsuit, judgment should be for

options.optionA: A. The landowner, if, but only if, the subsidence would have occurred without the weight of the building on Lot 1.
options.optionB: B. The landowner, because a right for support, appurtenant to Lot 1, had been acquired by adverse possession or prescription.
options.optionC: C. The neighbor, because Lots 1 and 2 are urban land, as distinguished from rural land and, therefore, under the circumstances the landowner had the duty to protect any improvements on Lot 1.
options.optionD: D. The neighbor, because the construction and the use to be made of the building were both authorized by the applicable law.

explanation.Legal_Concept: The right to lateral (side) support of land from neighboring parcels, and the extent of this right to structures built upon the land.
explanation.Fact_Analysis: The landowner's building on Lot 1 was constructed 12 years ago, with a wall along the boundary with Lot 2, and was done in compliance with all statutes, ordinances, and regulations. The neighbor's excavation on Lot 2, done 6 months ago, caused subsidence on Lot 1, injuring the landowner's building. The excavation was not done negligently or with malicious intent.
explanation.Rule_Application: A landowner has the right to lateral support of its land from neighboring parcels, but this right extends only to the land itself, not the structures built upon it. The excavating landowner is liable only if the neighboring land would have collapsed even without the weight of the structure.
explanation.Legal_Conclusion: Judgment should be for the landowner only if the subsidence on Lot 1 would have occurred even without the weight of the landowner's building, as the right to lateral support does not extend to structures built on the land.

question: The owner of Blackacre, a single-family residence, conveyed a life estate in Blackacre to a landlord fifteen years ago. Fourteen years ago, the landlord, who had taken possession of Blackacre, leased Blackacre to a tenant for a term of 15 years at the monthly rent of $500. Eleven years ago, the landlord died intestate leaving her son as her sole heir. The tenant regularly paid rent to the landlord and, after the landlord's death, to the son until last month. The period in which to acquire title by adverse possession in the jurisdiction is 10 years. In an appropriate action, the tenant, the original owner, and the son each asserted ownership of Blackacre. The court should hold that title in fee simple is in

options.optionA: A. the original owner, because the owner held a reversion and the landlord has died.
options.optionB: B. the son, because the landlord asserted a claim adverse to the owner when the landlord executed a lease to the tenant.
options.optionC: C. the son, because the tenant's occupation was attributable to the son, and the landlord died 11 years ago.
options.optionD: D. the tenant, because of the tenant's physical occupancy and because the tenant's term ended with the landlord's death.

explanation.Legal_Concept: Adverse possession and its requirements for obtaining title to real property, specifically in the context of a life estate and leasehold interests.
explanation.Fact_Analysis: The landlord held a life estate in Blackacre, which ended upon her death. The son, as her sole heir, collected rent from the tenant for eleven years without the original owner's permission, maintaining exclusive, open, and notorious possession of the property.
explanation.Rule_Application: To acquire title by adverse possession, one must have actual physical possession, maintain it continuously and without interruption, exclude others, have hostile possession, and maintain open and notorious possession for the statutory period. The son's actions meet these requirements, having collected rent and allowed the tenant to occupy the property exclusively for eleven years, exceeding the ten-year statutory period.
explanation.Legal_Conclusion: Given that the son has fulfilled the requirements for adverse possession, the court should hold that title in fee simple is in the son, supporting option C.

question: A landowner owned Greenacre, a tract of land, in fee simple. The landowner executed an instrument in the proper form of a deed, purporting to convey Greenacre to a purchaser in fee simple. The instrument recited that the conveyance was in consideration of "$5 in hand paid and for other good and valuable consideration." The landowner handed the instrument to the purchaser and the purchaser promptly and properly recorded it. Two months later, the landowner brought an appropriate action against the purchaser to cancel the instrument and to quiet title. In support, the landowner proved that no money in fact had been paid by the purchaser, notwithstanding the recitation, and that no other consideration of any kind had been supplied by the purchaser. In such action, landowner should

options.optionA: A. lose, because any remedy the landowner might have had was lost when the instrument was recorded.
options.optionB: B. lose, because the validity of conveyance of land does not depend upon consideration being paid, whether recited or not.
options.optionC: C. prevail, because the recitation of consideration paid may be contradicted by parol evidence.
options.optionD: D. prevail, because recordation does not make a void instrument effective.

explanation.Legal_Concept: The requirements for a valid conveyance of land, specifically the role of consideration and the effect of recording a deed.
explanation.Fact_Analysis: The landowner executed a deed in the proper form, purporting to convey Greenacre to the purchaser in fee simple, with a recitation of consideration. However, the landowner later claimed that no money or other consideration was actually paid by the purchaser. The purchaser recorded the deed, and the landowner sought to cancel the instrument and quiet title.
explanation.Rule_Application: For a conveyance of land to be valid, only execution and delivery of the deed are required. Execution is satisfied by the signature of the party to be charged, and delivery is established by a proven intent to pass title. The presence or absence of consideration does not affect the validity of the conveyance. In this case, the landowner's signature and physical delivery of the deed demonstrate the necessary intent to pass title.
explanation.Legal_Conclusion: Given that the landowner executed and delivered the deed, the conveyance is valid regardless of the absence of consideration. Therefore, the landowner should lose the action to cancel the instrument and quiet title, supporting option B.

question: A banker owned Goldacre, a tract of land, in fee simple. The banker and a buyer entered into a written agreement under which the buyer agreed to buy Goldacre for $100,000, its fair market value. The agreement contained all the essential terms of a real estate contract to sell and buy, including a date for closing. The required $50,000 down payment was made. The contract provided that in the event of the buyer's breach, the banker could retain the $50,000 deposit as liquidated damages. Before the date set for the closing in the contract, the buyer died. On the day that the administratrix of the buyer's estate was duly qualified, which was after the closing date, the administratrix made demand for return of the $50,000 deposit. The banker responded by stating that she took such demand to be a declaration that the administratrix did not intend to complete the contract and that the banker considered the contract at an end. The banker further asserted that she was entitled to retain, as liquidated damages, the $50,000. The reasonable market value of Goldacre had increased to $110,000 at that time. The administratrix brought an appropriate action against the banker to recover $50,000. In answer, the banker made no affirmative claim but asserted that she was entitled to retain the $50,000 as liquidated damages as provided in the contract. In such lawsuit, judgment should be for

options.optionA: A. the administratrix, because the provision relied upon by the banker is unenforceable.
options.optionB: B. the administratrix, because the death of the buyer terminated the contract as a matter of law.
options.optionC: C. the banker, because the court should enforce the express agreement of the contracting parties.
options.optionD: D. the banker, because the doctrine of equitable conversion prevents termination of the contract upon the death of a party.

explanation.Legal_Concept: Liquidated damages in real estate contracts, specifically the enforceability of a liquidated damages clause in the event of a buyer's breach.
explanation.Fact_Analysis: The buyer died before the closing date, and the administratrix of the buyer's estate demanded the return of the $50,000 deposit. The banker claimed the right to retain the deposit as liquidated damages, as per the contract. The market value of the property had increased from $100,000 to $110,000 by the time of the closing.
explanation.Rule_Application: A liquidated damages clause is enforceable if the amount appears reasonable in light of the seller's anticipated and actual damages. In this case, the seller's actual damages are limited to the difference between the original sale price and the increased market value, which is $10,000. Therefore, the liquidated damages clause for $50,000 is unenforceable.
explanation.Legal_Conclusion: Given that the liquidated damages clause is unenforceable due to its excessive amount compared to the seller's actual damages, the administratrix is entitled to recover the $50,000 deposit, supporting option A.

question: A landowner owned Blackacre in fee simple, as the land records showed, when he contracted to sell Blackacre to a buyer. Two weeks later, the buyer paid the agreed price and received a warranty deed. A week thereafter, when neither contract nor deed had been recorded and while the owner remained in possession of Blackacre, a creditor properly filed a money judgment against the owner. She knew nothing of the buyer's interest. A statute in the jurisdiction provides: "Any judgment properly filed shall, for ten years from filing, be a lien on the real property then owned or subsequently acquired by any person against whom the judgment is rendered."\ The recording act of the jurisdiction provides: "No conveyance or mortgage of real property shall be good against subsequent purchasers for value and without notice unless the same be recorded according to law." The creditor brought an appropriate action to enforce her lien against Blackacre in the buyer's hands. If the court decides for the buyer, it will most probably be because

options.optionA: A. the doctrine of equitable conversion applies.
options.optionB: B. the jurisdiction's recording act does not protect creditors.
options.optionC: C. The owner's possession gave the creditor constructive notice of the buyer's interest.
options.optionD: D. The buyer was a purchaser without notice.

explanation.Legal_Concept: The protection afforded by a notice-type recording act to bona fide purchasers for value and the distinction between such purchasers and judgment lien creditors.
explanation.Fact_Analysis: The buyer purchased Blackacre from the landowner and received a warranty deed, but neither the contract nor the deed was recorded at the time a creditor filed a money judgment against the landowner. The creditor had no actual or record notice of the conveyance to the buyer.
explanation.Rule_Application: A notice-type recording act protects bona fide purchasers for value who record their deeds without notice of earlier purchasers. To be a bona fide purchaser, one must give value for their interest in the land. The creditor, having filed a judgment lien, did not give value for the land and thus is not a bona fide purchaser.
explanation.Legal_Conclusion: Given that the creditor is not a bona fide purchaser for value, the jurisdiction's recording act does not protect the creditor's interest. Therefore, the court will most likely decide for the buyer because the jurisdiction's recording act does not protect creditors, supporting option B.

question: A woman owned several vacant lots in a subdivision. She obtained a $50,000 loan from a bank and executed and delivered to the bank a promissory note and mortgage describing Lots 1, 2, 3, 4, and 5. The mortgage was promptly and properly recorded. Upon payment of $10,000, the woman obtained a release of Lot 2 duly executed by the bank. She altered the instrument of release to include Lot 5 as well as Lot 2 and recorded it. The woman thereafter sold Lot 5 to an innocent purchaser for value. The bank discovered that the instrument of release had been altered and brought an appropriate action against the woman and the purchaser to set aside the release as it applied to Lot 5. The woman did not defend against the action, but the purchaser did. The recording act of the jurisdiction provides: "No unrecorded conveyance or mortgage of real property shall be good against subsequent purchasers for value without notice, who shall first record." The court should rule for

options.optionA: A. the purchaser, because the bank was negligent in failing to check the recordation of the release.
options.optionB: B. the purchaser, because she was entitled to rely on the recorded release.
options.optionC: C. the bank, because he purchaser could have discovered the alteration by reasonable inquiry.
options.optionD: D. the bank, because the alteration of the release was ineffective.

explanation.Legal_Concept: The effect of a forged deed under a race-notice recording act in real property law.
explanation.Fact_Analysis: A woman obtained a loan from a bank and executed a mortgage on several lots. After paying $10,000, she received a release for one lot, altered it to include another lot, and recorded it. She then sold the altered lot to an innocent purchaser, who was unaware of the alteration.
explanation.Rule_Application: Under a race-notice act, recording a deed provides notice but does not affect its validity. An invalid deed, such as one that has been forged, is ineffective regardless of whether it was recorded or if a subsequent purchaser had notice of it.
explanation.Legal_Conclusion: Since the alteration of the release was a forgery, making the deed invalid, it is ineffective. Therefore, the correct ruling should be in favor of the bank, as the alteration of the release was ineffective, supporting option D.

question: Thirty years ago, the original owner of Greenacre, a lot contiguous to Blueacre, in fee simple, executed and delivered to his neighbor an instrument in writing which was denominated "Deed of Conveyance." In pertinent part it read, "[The owner] does grant to [the neighbor] and her heirs and assigns a right-of-way for egress and ingress to Blueacre." If the quoted provision was sufficient to create an interest in land, the instrument met all other requirements for a valid grant. The neighbor held record title in fee simple to Blueacre, which adjoined Greenacre. Twelve years ago the owner's son succeeded to the original owner's title in fee simple in Greenacre and seven years ago the neighbor's daughter succeeded to the neighbor's title in fee simple to Blueacre by a deed which made no mention of a right-of-way or driveway. At the time the neighbor's daughter took title, there existed a driveway across Greenacre which showed evidence that it had been used regularly to travel between the main roadand Blueacre. Blueacre did have frontage on a side road, but this means of access was seldom used because it was not as convenient to the dwelling situated on Blueacre as was the main road. The driveway originally was established by the neighbor. The neighbor's daughter has regularly used the driveway since acquiring title. The period of time required to acquire rights by prescription in the jurisdiction is ten years. Six months ago the son notified the neighbor's daughter that the son planned to develop a portion of Greenacre as a residential subdivision and that the daughter should cease any use of the driveway. After some negotiations, the son offered to permit the daughter to construct another driveway to connect with the streets of the proposed subdivision. The daughter declined this offer on the ground that travel from Blueacre to the main road would be more circuitous. The neighbor's daughter brought an appropriate action against the son to obtain a definitive adjudication of the respective rights of the daughter and the son. In such lawsuit the son relied upon the defense that the location of the easement created by the grant from the original owner to the neighbor was governed by reasonableness and that the son's proposed solution was reasonable. The son's defense should

options.optionA: A. fail, because the location had been established by the acts of the neighbor and the original owner.
options.optionB: B. fail, because the location of the easement had been fixed by prescription.
options.optionC: C. prevail, because the reasonableness of the son's proposal was established by the neighbor's daughter's refusal to suggest any alternative location.
options.optionD: D. prevail, because the servient owner is entitled to select the location of a right-of-way if the grant fails to identify its location.

explanation.Legal_Concept: Easements appurtenant, specifically the creation, characteristics, and limitations of easements that benefit a specific piece of land.
explanation.Fact_Analysis: The original owner of Greenacre granted a right-of-way for egress and ingress to the neighbor, who owned Blueacre. The easement was used regularly for twelve years before the neighbor's daughter took title to Blueacre. The driveway's location was established by the neighbor and the original owner, and its use continued under the neighbor's daughter.
explanation.Rule_Application: An easement appurtenant automatically runs with the land and does not need to be re-identified in later deeds. The owner of the servient estate has the right to select the location of the easement, but this selection must be reasonable. Once a reasonable location is chosen, the servient estate does not have the inherent right to relocate the easement.
explanation.Legal_Conclusion: The son's defense should fail because the location of the easement had already been established by the acts of the neighbor and the original owner, and the servient estate does not possess any inherent right to relocate it. Therefore, the correct answer is A.

question: Three years ago a landowner conveyed Blackacre to his niece for $50,000 by a deed that provided: "By accepting this deed, [the niece] covenants for herself, her heirs and assigns, that the premises herein conveyed shall be used solely for residential purposes and, if the premises are used for nonresidential purposes, the landowner, his heirs and assigns, shall have the right to repurchase the premises for the sum of one thousand dollars ($1,000)." In order to pay the $50,000 purchase price for Blackacre, the niece obtained a $35,000 mortgage loan from the bank. The landowner had full knowledge of the mortgage transaction. The deed and mortgage were promptly and properly recorded in proper sequence. The mortgage, however, made no reference to the quoted language in the deed. Two years ago the niece converted her use of Blackacre from residential to commerical without the knowledge or consent of the landowner or of the bank. The niece's commercial venture failed, and the niece defaulted on her mortgage payments to the bank. Blackacre now has a fair market value of $25,000. The bank began appropriate foreclosure proceedings against the niece. The landowner properly intervened, tendered $1,000, and sought judgment that the niece and the bank be ordered to convey Blackacre to the landowner, free and clear of the mortgage. The common law Rule Against Perpetuities is unmodified by statute. If the court rules against the landowner, it will be because

options.optionA: A. the provision quoted from the deed violates the Rule Against Perpetuities.
options.optionB: B. the bank had no actual knowledge of, and did not consent to, the violation of the covenant.
options.optionC: C. the rights reserved by the landowner were subordinated, by necessary implication, to the rights of the bank as the lender of the purchase money.
options.optionD: D. the consideration of $1,000 was inadequate.

explanation.Legal_Concept: The Rule Against Perpetuities (RAP) in property law, specifically its application to contingent remainders and the requirement that interests must vest within a life in being plus 21 years.
explanation.Fact_Analysis: The landowner conveyed Blackacre to his niece with a deed that included a covenant restricting the property's use to residential purposes and granting the landowner a right to repurchase if the property is used for nonresidential purposes. The niece obtained a mortgage loan from the bank, and the deed and mortgage were recorded. The niece later converted the property's use to commercial without the knowledge or consent of the landowner or the bank, leading to a default on mortgage payments and foreclosure proceedings.
explanation.Rule_Application: The RAP applies to contingent remainders, and the quoted provision in the deed creates a contingent remainder in favor of the landowner and his heirs. The RAP dictates that such interests must vest within a life in being plus 21 years. In this case, the interest could vest decades after the initial conveyance, potentially exceeding the life in being plus 21 years, thus violating the RAP.
explanation.Legal_Conclusion: Given that the provision in the deed violates the RAP, the landowner's right to repurchase the property is void. Therefore, the correct answer is A, as the RAP provides a sound basis to rule against the landowner.

question: Six years ago, the owner of Blackacre in fee simple executed and delivered to a widower an instrument in the proper form of a warranty deed, purporting to convey Blackacre to "[the widower] and his heirs." At that time, the widower had one child. Three years ago, the widower executed and delivered to a buyer an instrument in the proper form of a warranty deed, purporting to convey Blackacre to "[the buyer]." The child did not join in the deed. The buyer was and still is unmarried and childless. The only possibly applicable statute in the jurisdiction states that any deed will be construed to convey the grantor's entire estate, unless expressly limited. Last month, the widower died, never having remarried. His child is his only heir. Blackacre is now owned by

options.optionA: A. the child, because the widower's death ended the buyer's life estate pur autre vie.
options.optionB: B. the buyer in fee simple pursuant to the widower's deed.
options.optionC: C. the child and the buyer as tenants in common of equal shares.
options.optionD: D. the child and the buyer as joint tenants, because both survived the widower.

explanation.Legal_Concept: Fee simple ownership and conveyance of real property, specifically the rights and limitations of a grantor and grantee in a warranty deed.
explanation.Fact_Analysis: The owner conveyed Blackacre to the widower in fee simple with the language '[the widower] and his heirs,' but this did not create an interest in the child. The widower then conveyed Blackacre to the buyer in fee simple without the child joining in the deed. The widower died, leaving the child as his only heir.
explanation.Rule_Application: A fee simple ownership is not terminated by any subsequent condition, and the owner has the right to transfer the land without restrictions. The language '[the widower] and his heirs' in the initial conveyance does not limit the widower's ability to re-convey the land. The applicable statute states that a deed will be construed to convey the grantor's entire estate unless expressly limited.
explanation.Legal_Conclusion: Given that the widower held Blackacre in fee simple and was free to convey it as he wished, the conveyance to the buyer in fee simple is upheld. The child has no rights in the property because the widower did not create an interest for the child in the initial conveyance or in his will. Therefore, the correct answer is that Blackacre is now owned by the buyer in fee simple, supporting option B.

question: A grantor executed an instrument in the proper form of a warranty deed purporting to convey a tract of land to his church. The granting clause of the instrument ran to the church "and its successors forever, so long as the premises are used for church purposes." The church took possession of the land and used it as its site of worship for many years. Subsequently, the church wanted to relocate and entered into a valid written contract to sell the land to a buyer for a substantial price. The buyer wanted to use the land as a site for business activities and objected to the church's title. The contract contained no provision relating to the quality of title the church was bound to convey. There is no applicable statute. When the buyer refused to close, the church sued the buyer for specific performance and properly joined the grantor as a party. Is the church likely to prevail?

options.optionA: A. No, because the grantor's interest prevents the church's title from being marketable.
options.optionB: B. No, because the quoted provision is a valid restrictive covenant.
options.optionC: C. Yes, because a charitable trust to support religion will attach to the proceeds of the sale.
options.optionD: D. Yes, because the grantor cannot derogate from his warranty to the church.

explanation.Legal_Concept: Fee simple determinable title and the marketability of title in real estate transactions.
explanation.Fact_Analysis: The church was granted a fee simple determinable title to the land by the grantor, with the condition that the premises be used for church purposes. The church seeks to sell the land to a buyer who intends to use it for business activities, which would trigger the limitation and cause the title to be forfeited to the grantor.
explanation.Rule_Application: A fee simple determinable title is subject to a limitation that can cause the title to be forfeited if the condition is not met. In this case, the condition is that the land be used for church purposes. If the buyer uses the land for business activities, the limitation will occur, and the title will be forfeited to the grantor. A title is considered unmarketable if a reasonable person would not purchase it due to the risk of title being forfeited.
explanation.Legal_Conclusion: Given that the buyer's intended use of the land would trigger the limitation and cause the title to be forfeited to the grantor, the church's title is unmarketable. Therefore, the church is unlikely to prevail in its suit for specific performance, supporting option A.

question: An investor purchased a tract of land, financing a large part of the purchase price by a loan from a business partner that was secured by a mortgage. The investor made the installment payments on the mortgage regularly for several years. Then the investor persuaded a neighbor to buy the land, subject to the mortgage to his partner. They expressly agreed that the neighbor would not assume and agree to pay the investor's debt to the partner. The investor's mortgage to the partner contained a due-on-sale clause stating, "If Mortgagor transfers his/her interest without the written consent of Mortgagee first obtained, then at Mortgagee's option the entire principal balance of the debt secured by this Mortgage shall become immediately due and payable." However, without seeking his partner's consent, the investor conveyed the land to the neighbor, the deed stating in pertinent part " . . . , subject to a mortgage to [the partner]," and giving details and recording data related to the mortgage. The neighbor took possession of the land and made several mortgage payments, which the partner accepted. Now, however, neither the neighbor nor the investor has made the last three mortgage payments. The partner has sued the neighbor for the amount of the delinquent payments. In this action, for whom should the court render judgment?

options.optionA: A. The neighbor, because she did not assume and agree to pay the investor's mortgage debt.
options.optionB: B. The neighbor, because she is not in privity of estate with the partner.
options.optionC: C. The partner, because the investor's deed to the neighbor violated the due-on-sale clause.
options.optionD: D. The partner, because the neighbor is in privity of estate with the partner.

explanation.Legal_Concept: Mortgage assumption and liability, specifically the distinction between assuming a mortgage and taking property subject to a mortgage.
explanation.Fact_Analysis: The investor sold the land to the neighbor, who took the property subject to the mortgage but did not assume the mortgage debt. The parties explicitly agreed that the neighbor would not assume and agree to pay the investor's debt to the partner.
explanation.Rule_Application: A grantee who takes property subject to a mortgage, without assuming the mortgage, is not personally liable for the debt. Only the original mortgagor, in this case the investor, remains liable for the mortgage payments.
explanation.Legal_Conclusion: Since the neighbor did not assume the mortgage debt and only took the property subject to the mortgage, the neighbor is not personally liable for the delinquent payments. Therefore, the court should render judgment for the neighbor, supporting option A.

question: A businessman owned a hotel, subject to a mortgage securing a debt he owed to a bank. The businessman later acquired a nearby parking garage, financing a part of the purchase price by a loan from a financing company, secured by a mortgage on the parking garage. Two years thereafter, the businessman defaulted on the loan owed to the bank, which caused the full amount of that loan to become immediately due and payable. The bank decided not to foreclose the mortgage on the hotel at that time, but instead properly sued for the full amount of the defaulted loan. The bank obtained and properly filed a judgment for that amount. A statute of the jurisdiction provides: "Any judgment properly filed shall, for ten years from filing, be a lien on the real property then owned or subsequently acquired by any person against whom the judgment is rendered." There is no other applicable statute, except the statute providing for judicial foreclosure of mortgages, which places no restriction on deficiency judgments. Shortly thereafter, the bank brought an appropriate action for judicial foreclosure of its first mortgage on the hotel and of its judgment lien on the parking garage. The financing company was joined as a party defendant, and appropriately counterclaimed for foreclosure of its mortgage on the parking garage, which was also in default. All procedures were properly followed and the confirmed foreclosure sales resulted in the following: The net proceeds of the sale of the hotel to a third party were $200,000 less than the bank's mortgage balance. The net proceeds of the sale of the parking garage to a fourth party were $200,000 more than the financing company's mortgage balance. How should the $200,000 surplus arising from the bid on the parking garage be distributed?

options.optionA: A. It should be paid to the bank.
options.optionB: B. It should be paid to the businessman.
options.optionC: C. It should be paid to the financing company.
options.optionD: D. It should be split equally between the bank and the financing company.

explanation.Legal_Concept: Priority of liens and distribution of surplus funds from foreclosure sales, particularly the application of a previously filed judgment lien to subsequently acquired property.
explanation.Fact_Analysis: The bank held a mortgage on the hotel and a judgment lien against the businessman, which was properly filed and applied to all his real property, including the parking garage acquired later. The foreclosure sales of both the hotel and the parking garage resulted in a deficiency for the bank but a surplus for the financing company.
explanation.Rule_Application: A properly filed judgment lien acts as a lien on all real property owned or subsequently acquired by the judgment debtor for a specified period. In this case, the bank's judgment lien, filed before the foreclosure actions, takes priority over the surplus funds from the sale of the parking garage, as it is considered an unsatisfied amount of the prior money judgment.
explanation.Legal_Conclusion: Given the bank's properly filed judgment lien and its priority over the surplus funds from the foreclosure sale of the parking garage, the $200,000 surplus should be paid to the bank to satisfy the unsatisfied amount of the prior money judgment, supporting option A.

question: A fee-simple landowner lawfully subdivided his land into 10 large lots. The recorded subdivision plan imposed no restrictions on any of the 10 lots. Within two months after recording the plan, the landowner conveyed Lot 1 to a buyer by a deed that contained no restriction on the lot's use. There was then a lull in sales. Two years later, the real estate market in the state had generally improved and, during the next six months, the landowner sold and conveyed eight of the remaining nine lots. In each of the eight deeds of conveyance, the landowner included the following language: "It is a term and condition of this conveyance, which shall be a covenant running with the land for the benefit of each of the 10 lots [with an appropriate reference to the recorded subdivision plan], that for 15 years from the date of recording of the plan, no use shall be made of the premises herein conveyed except for single-family residential purposes." The buyer of Lot 1 had actual knowledge of what the landowner had done. The landowner included the quoted language in part because the zoning ordinance of the municipality had been amended a year earlier to permit professional offices in any residential zone. Shortly after the landowner's most recent sale, when he owned only one unsold lot, the buyer of Lot 1 constructed a one-story house on Lot 1 and then conveyed Lot 1 to a doctor. The deed to the doctor contained no reference to any restriction on the use of Lot 1.
