explanation.Rule_Application: Under a notice-type recording statute, a party must be a bona fide purchaser who recorded their deed without notice of earlier purchasers. To be a bona fide purchaser, a party must give value for their interest in the land. The creditor recorded without notice of the deed to the purchaser, but the creditor's status as a bona fide purchaser hinges on whether they paid value within the meaning of the statute.
explanation.Legal_Conclusion: The outcome of the conflicting claims will depend on the jurisdiction's interpretation of 'paid value' under the recording statute, as this determines the creditor's status as a bona fide purchaser and thus their priority under the statute.

question: A landowner held 500 acres in fee simple absolute. In 1990 the owner platted and obtained all required governmental approvals of two subdivisions of 200 acres each. In 1990 and 1991 commercial buildings and parking facilities were constructed on one, Royal Center, in accordance with the plans disclosed by the plat for each subdivision. Royal Center continues to be used for commercial purposes. The plat of the other, Royal Oaks, showed 250 lots, streets, and utility and drainage easements. All of the lots in Royal Oaks were conveyed during 1990 and 1991. The deeds contained provisions, expressly stated to be binding upon the grantee, his heirs and assigns, requiring the lots to be used only for single-family, residential purposes until 2015. The deeds expressly stated that these provisions were enforceable by the owner of any lot in the Royal Oaks subdivision. At all times since 1979, the 200 acres of Royal Center have been zoned for shopping center use, and the 200 acres in Royal Oaks have been zoned for residential use in a classification which permits both single-family and multiple-family use. Assume that the owner now desires to open his remaining 100 acres as a residential subdivision of 125 lots (with appropriate streets, etc.). He has, as an essential element of his scheme, the feature that the restrictions are identical with those he planned for the original Royal Oaks residential subdivision and, further, that lot owners in Royal Oaks should be able to enforce (by lawsuits) restrictions on the lots in the 100 acres. The zoning for the 100 acres is identical with that for the 200 acres of Royal Oaks residential subdivision. Which of the following best states the chance of success for his scheme?

options.optionA: A. He can restrict use only to the extent of that imposed by zoning (that is, to residential use by not more than four dwelling units per lot).
options.optionB: B. He cannot restrict the 100 acres to residential use because of the conflicting use for retail commercial purposes in the 200 acres comprising the shopping center.
options.optionC: C. He cannot impose any enforceable restriction to residential use only.
options.optionD: D. Any chance of success depends upon the 100 acres being considered by the courts as part of a common development scheme which also includes the 200 acres of Royal Oaks.

explanation.Legal_Concept: Equitable servitudes in real property law, specifically the enforceability of restrictions on land use within a subdivision.
explanation.Fact_Analysis: The landowner created two subdivisions, Royal Center and Royal Oaks, with the latter having deed restrictions for single-family residential use until 2015. The owner now plans to develop the remaining 100 acres with identical restrictions, intending for lot owners in Royal Oaks to enforce these restrictions on the new lots.
explanation.Rule_Application: For an equitable servitude to be enforceable, there must be intent for the restriction to bind subsequent grantees, notice of the servitude to subsequent grantees, and the restriction must touch and concern the land. Additionally, for the servitude to bind an entire subdivision, it must be part of a common building plan. The restrictions in the original Royal Oaks deeds meet these criteria, and if the 100 acres are considered part of the same development scheme, the restrictions could be enforceable.
explanation.Legal_Conclusion: The success of the landowner's scheme depends on the courts considering the 100 acres as part of a common development scheme with Royal Oaks, thereby allowing the enforcement of the restrictions across the entire subdivision. This supports option D as the best statement of the chance of success for his scheme.

question: An owner conveyed Greenacre, her one-family residence, to "Perez for life, remainder to Rowan, her heirs and assigns, subject, however, to First Bank's mortgage thereon." There was an unpaid balance on the mortgage of $10,000, which is payable in $1,000 annual installments plus interest at 6 percent on the unpaid balance, with the next payment due on July 1. Perez is now occupying Greenacre. The reasonable rental value of the property exceeds the sum necessary to meet all current charges. There is no applicable statute. Under the rules governing contributions between life tenants and remaindermen, how should the burden for payment be allocated?

options.optionA: A. Rowan must pay the principal payment, but Perez must pay the interest to First Bank.
options.optionB: B. Rowan must pay both the principal and interest payments to First Bank.
options.optionC: C. Perez must pay both the principal and interest payments to first Bank.
options.optionD: D. Perez must pay the principal payment, but Rowan must pay the interest to First Bank.

explanation.Legal_Concept: Contribution between life tenants and remaindermen regarding mortgage payments on a property.
explanation.Fact_Analysis: Perez has a life estate in Greenacre, while Rowan holds a vested remainder. The property is subject to a mortgage with First Bank, with an unpaid balance of $10,000 and annual payments due. Perez is currently occupying the property, which has a reasonable rental value exceeding the necessary current charges.
explanation.Rule_Application: A life tenant, such as Perez, has a duty not to commit permissive waste, which includes paying interest on any mortgage but not the principal. The holder of the remainder, Rowan, is responsible for the principal payments. Thus, Perez must pay the interest to avoid committing permissive waste, while Rowan is obligated to pay the principal.
explanation.Legal_Conclusion: Given the duties of a life tenant and the holder of a remainder, Perez is responsible for paying the interest on the mortgage to First Bank, while Rowan must pay the principal. This allocation of burden supports answer A as the correct choice.

question: A grantor conveyed her only parcel of land to a grantee by a duly executed and delivered warranty deed, which provided: To have and to hold the described tract of land in fee simple, subject to the understanding that within one year from the date of the instrument, said grantee shall construct and thereafter maintain and operate on said premises a public health center. The grantee constructed a public health center on the tract within the time specified, and operated it for five years. At the end of this period, the grantee converted the structure into a senior citizens' recreational facility. It is conceded by all parties in interest that a senior citizens' recreational facility is not a public health center. In an appropriate action, the grantor seeks a declaration that the change in the use of the facility has caused the land and structure to revert to her. In this action, the grantor should

options.optionA: A. win, because the language of the deed created a determinable fee, which leaves a possibility of reverter in the grantor.
options.optionB: B. win, because the language of the deed created a fee subject to condition subsequent, which leaves a right of entry or power of termination in the grantor.
options.optionC: C. lose, because the language of the deed created only a contractual obligation and did not provide for retention of property interest by the grantor.
options.optionD: D. lose, because an equitable charge is enforceable only in equity.

explanation.Legal_Concept: The distinction between contractual obligations and property interests in the context of land conveyances, particularly focusing on the creation of determinable fees, fees subject to condition subsequent, and contractual obligations.
explanation.Fact_Analysis: The grantor conveyed land to the grantee with the understanding that the grantee would construct and operate a public health center within one year. The grantee fulfilled this obligation but later converted the facility into a senior citizens' recreational facility, which is not considered a public health center.
explanation.Rule_Application: The language of the deed is crucial in determining whether a contractual obligation or a property interest was created. In this case, the use of the phrase 'subject to the understanding' indicates a contractual obligation rather than a condition that would affect the grantee's property rights. Therefore, the grantor is entitled to contractual damages but not a reversion of the property.
explanation.Legal_Conclusion: Given that the condition in the deed created a contractual obligation rather than a determinable fee or a fee subject to condition subsequent, the grantor's remedy is limited to contractual damages. Thus, the grantor should lose the action seeking a declaration that the land and structure have reverted to her, supporting option C.

question: A man and a woman owned Brownacre as joint tenants with the right of survivorship. The man executed a mortgage on Brownacre to a lender in order to secure a loan. Subsequently, but before the indebtedness was paid to the lender, the man died intestate with his son as his only heir at law. The jurisdiction in which Brownacre is located recognizes the title theory of mortgages. In an appropriate action, the court should determine that title to Brownacre is vested

options.optionA: A. in the woman, with the entire interest subject to the mortgage.
options.optionB: B. in the woman, free and clear of the mortgage.
options.optionC: C. half in the woman, free of the mortgage, and half in the son subject to the mortgage.
options.optionD: D. half in the woman and half in the son, with both subject to the mortgage.

explanation.Legal_Concept: The effect of a mortgage on a joint tenancy in a title theory jurisdiction, specifically the severance of the joint tenancy and the resulting interests of the parties involved.
explanation.Fact_Analysis: The man and the woman owned Brownacre as joint tenants with the right of survivorship. The man executed a mortgage on Brownacre to a lender, and subsequently died intestate with his son as his only heir at law. The jurisdiction recognizes the title theory of mortgages.
explanation.Rule_Application: In a title theory jurisdiction, the execution of a mortgage by one joint tenant severs the joint tenancy to the extent of the mortgage, resulting in the property being held by the parties as tenants in common. The interest of the joint tenant who executed the mortgage remains subject to the mortgage. Upon the death of the joint tenant, their interest in the property is bequeathed to their heir, subject to the mortgage.
explanation.Legal_Conclusion: Given that the man executed a mortgage in a title theory jurisdiction, the joint tenancy was severed, and the property was held by the man and the woman as tenants in common. Upon the man's death, his interest in one-half of the property was bequeathed to his son, subject to the mortgage. Therefore, title to Brownacre is vested half in the woman, free of the mortgage, and half in the son, subject to the mortgage, supporting option C.

question: While hospitalized, a client requested her attorney to draw a deed conveying her home to her son. While the client remained in the hospital, the deed was drawn, properly executed, and promptly recorded. On being informed of the existence of the deed, the son told his mother, "I want no part of the property; take the deed right back." The client recovered and left the hospital, but shortly thereafter, before any other relevant event, the son died intestate. The client brought an appropriate action against the son's heirs to determine title. If the client wins, it will be because

options.optionA: A. the court will impose a constructive trust to carry out the intent of the deceased son.
options.optionB: B. the presumption of delivery arising from the recording is not valid unless the grantee has knowledge at the time of the recording.
options.optionC: C. the son's declaration was a constructive reconveyance of the land.
options.optionD: D. there was no effective acceptance of delivery of the deed.

explanation.Legal_Concept: The requirements for a valid conveyance of land, specifically the necessity of execution and delivery of a deed.
explanation.Fact_Analysis: The client executed a deed conveying her home to her son while she was hospitalized. The deed was properly executed and recorded. However, upon learning of the deed, the son explicitly rejected it, stating he wanted no part of the property.
explanation.Rule_Application: For a conveyance of land to be valid, the deed must be executed and delivered. Delivery is established by a proven intent to pass title, and acceptance by the grantee is presumed unless explicitly rejected. In this scenario, the son's explicit rejection of the deed means it was never accepted.
explanation.Legal_Conclusion: Given that the son never accepted the deed due to his explicit rejection, there was no effective delivery of the deed. Therefore, the client will win the action to determine title because there was no effective acceptance of delivery of the deed, supporting option D.

question: A plaintiff and a defendant own adjoining lots in the central portion of a city. Each of their lots had an office building. The defendant decided to raze the existing building on her lot and to erect a building of greater height. The defendant has received all governmental approvals required to pursue her project. There is no applicable statute or ordinance (other than those dealing with various approvals for zoning, building, etc.). After the defendant had torn down the existing building, she proceeded to excavate deeper. The defendant used shoring that met all local, state, and federal safety regulations, and the shoring was placed in accordance with those standards. The plaintiff notified the defendant that cracks were developing in the building situated on the plaintiff's lot. The defendant took the view that any subsidence suffered by the plaintiff was due to the weight of the plaintiff's building, and correctly asserted that none would have occurred had the plaintiff's soil been in its natural state. The defendant continued to excavate. The building on the plaintiff's lot did suffer extensive damage, requiring the expenditure of $750,000 to remedy the defects. Which of the following is the best comment concerning the plaintiff's action to recover damages from the defendant?

options.optionA: A. The defendant is liable, because she removed necessary support for the plaintiff's lot.
options.optionB: B. The defendant cannot be held liable simply upon proof that support was removed, but may be held liable if negligence is proved.
options.optionC: C. Once land is improved with a building, the owner cannot invoke the common law right of lateral support.
options.optionD: D. The defendant's only obligation was to satisfy all local, state, and federal safety regulations.

explanation.Legal_Concept: Lateral support and negligence in the context of excavation and construction on adjoining properties.
explanation.Fact_Analysis: The defendant, after receiving necessary approvals, excavated her lot to build a taller structure, using shoring that met safety regulations. The plaintiff's building on the adjacent lot suffered damage due to subsidence, which the defendant attributed to the weight of the plaintiff's building and the altered state of the soil.
explanation.Rule_Application: While the defendant may have met safety regulations, the plaintiff can still pursue a claim for negligence. This could involve proving the defendant failed to adequately investigate the impact of her excavation, did not properly shore up the plaintiff's building when aware of potential subsidence, or did not follow sound engineering practices.
explanation.Legal_Conclusion: The defendant's compliance with safety regulations does not absolve her of potential liability for negligence. Therefore, the best comment concerning the plaintiff's action is that the defendant cannot be held liable simply for removing support, but may be held liable if negligence is proven, supporting option B.

question: A business woman was the owner in fee simple of adjoining lots known as Lot 1 and Lot 2. She built a house in which she took up residence on Lot 1. Thereafter, she built a house on Lot 2, which she sold, house and lot, to a buyer. Consistent with the contract of sale and purchase, the deed conveying Lot 2 from the business woman to the buyer contained the following clause: In the event the buyer, his heirs or assigns, decide to sell the property hereby conveyed and obtain a purchaser ready, willing, and able to purchase Lot 2 and the improvements thereon on terms and conditions acceptable to the buyer, said Lot 2 and improvements shall be offered to the business woman, her heirs or assigns, on the same terms and conditions. The business woman, her heirs or assigns, as the case may be, shall have ten days from said offer to accept said offer and thereby to exercise said option. Three years after delivery and recording of the deed and payment of the purchase price, the buyer became ill and moved to a climate more compatible with his health. The buyer's daughter orally offered to purchase the premises from the buyer at its then fair market value. The buyer declined his daughter's offer but instead deeded Lot 2 to his daughter as a gift. Immediately thereafter, the buyer's daughter sold Lot 2 to a man at the then fair market value of Lot 2. The sale was completed by the delivery of deed and payment of the purchase price. At no time did the buyer or his daughter offer to sell Lot 2 to the business woman. The business woman learned of the conveyance to the buyer's daughter and the sale by the daughter to the man one week after the conveyance of Lot 2 from the daughter to the man. The business woman promptly brought an appropriate action against the man to enforce rights created in him by the deed of the business woman to the buyer. The business woman tendered the amount paid by the man into the court for whatever disposition the court deemed proper. The common-law Rule Against Perpetutities is unmodified by statute. Which of the following will determine whether the business woman will prevail? I. The parol evidence rule. II. The Statute of Frauds. III. The type of recording statute of the jurisdiction in question. IV. The Rule Against Perpetuities

options.optionA: A. I only.
options.optionB: B. IV only.
options.optionC: C. I and IV only.
options.optionD: D. II and III only.

explanation.Legal_Concept: The application of the Rule Against Perpetuities (RAP) to a right of first refusal in a deed, particularly when the conditional wording is vague.
explanation.Fact_Analysis: The business woman included a right of first refusal in the deed to Lot 2, which was sold to the buyer. The buyer later deeded Lot 2 to his daughter as a gift, and she subsequently sold it to a man without offering the business woman the opportunity to purchase it first. The business woman seeks to enforce her rights under the deed.
explanation.Rule_Application: The RAP applies to options and rights of first refusal if they are mere contract or covenant rights, not interests retained by the grantor. The vague conditional wording of the right of first refusal may violate the RAP, which requires that the interest must vest, if at all, within 21 years of a life in being at the time of the creation of the interest.
explanation.Legal_Conclusion: The business woman's ability to prevail depends on whether the right of first refusal violates the RAP. If the court determines that the right of first refusal is too vague and does not comply with the RAP, it may be struck down, and the business woman's claim may fail. Therefore, the correct answer is B, as the RAP is the determining factor in this case.

question: A plaintiff and a defendant own adjoining lots in the central portion of a city. Each of their lots had an office building. The defendant decided to raze the existing building on her lot and erect a building of greater height. The defendant had received all governmental approvals required to pursue her project. There is no applicable statute or ordinance (other than those dealing with various approvals for zoning, building, etc.). Assume that no problems with subsidence or other misadventures occurred during construction of the defendant's new building. However, when it was completed, the plaintiff discovered that the shadow created by the new higher building placed her building in such deep shade that the ability to lease space was diminished, and the rent she could charge and the occupancy rate were substantially lower. Assume that these facts are proved in an appropriate action the plaintiff instituted against the defendant for all and any relief available. Which of the following is the most appropriate comment concerning this lawsuit?

options.optionA: A. The plaintiff is entitled to a mandatory injunction requiring the defendant to restore conditions to those existing with the prior building insofar as the shadow is concerned.
options.optionB: B. The court should award permanent damages, in lieu of an injunction, equal to the present value of all rents lost and loss on rents for the reasonable life of the building.
options.optionC: C. The court should award damages for losses suffered to the date of trial and leave open recovery of future damages.
options.optionD: D. Judgment should be for the defendant, because the plaintiff has no cause of action.

explanation.Legal_Concept: Property rights, specifically the rights of landowners to sunlight, fresh air, and view.
explanation.Fact_Analysis: The defendant constructed a new building on her lot that cast a deep shadow on the plaintiff's adjacent building, reducing its ability to lease space and charge rent. The defendant had obtained all necessary governmental approvals for the project.
explanation.Rule_Application: Landowners possess rights to their property and the areas above and below it, but there are no inherent rights to sunlight, fresh air, or view. Therefore, the plaintiff has no legal basis for a cause of action against the defendant for the impact of the new building's shadow on her property.
explanation.Legal_Conclusion: Given the absence of a recognized property right to sunlight, the plaintiff's lawsuit against the defendant must fail. Thus, the most appropriate comment concerning this lawsuit is that judgment should be for the defendant, as the plaintiff has no cause of action.

question: An owner contracted to sell Blackacre to his cousin. The written contract required the owner to provide evidence of marketable title of record, specified a closing date, stated that "time is of the essence," and provided that at closing, the owner would convey by warranty deed. The cousin paid the owner $2,000 earnest money toward the $40,000 purchase price. The title evidence showed that an undivided one-eighth interest in Blackacre was owned by a woman. The cousin immediately objected to title and said he would not close on the owner's title. The owner responded, accurately, that the woman was his daughter who would be trekking in Nepal until two weeks after the specified closing date. He said that she would gladly deed her interest upon her return, and that meanwhile his deed warranting title to all of Blackacre would fully protect the cousin. The owner duly tendered his deed but the cousin refused to close. The cousin brought an appropriate action to recover the $2,000 earnest money promptly after the specified closing date. The owner counterclaimed for specific performance, tendering a deed from himself and the woman, who had by then returned. The court will hold for

options.optionA: A. the owner, because the woman's deed completing the transfer was given within a reasonable time.
options.optionB: B. the owner, because his warranty deed would have given his cousin adequate interim protection.
options.optionC: C. the cousin, because the owner's title was not marketable and time was of the essence.
options.optionD: D. the cousin, because under the circumstances the earnest money amount was excessive.

explanation.Legal_Concept: The requirement of marketable title in real estate transactions and the effect of a 'time is of the essence' clause on contract performance.
explanation.Fact_Analysis: The owner contracted to sell Blackacre to his cousin with a written contract specifying a closing date, requiring marketable title of record, and stating that 'time is of the essence.' The title evidence showed an undivided one-eighth interest in Blackacre was owned by the owner's daughter, prompting the cousin to object to the title and refuse to close.
explanation.Rule_Application: A 'time is of the essence' clause in a contract makes timely performance a crucial element. If the specified date passes without performance, the party failing to perform loses their right to enforce the contract. In real estate transactions, marketable title is typically required at closing. The presence of the daughter's interest made the title unmarketable at the time of the scheduled closing.
explanation.Legal_Conclusion: Given the 'time is of the essence' clause and the owner's failure to provide marketable title by the scheduled closing date due to the daughter's interest, the cousin will prevail. The owner's subsequent provision of a deed from himself and the daughter does not rectify the failure to meet the contractual deadline, supporting option C.

question: A banker owned Whiteacre, a dwelling house situated on a two-acre lot in an area zoned for single-family residential uses only. Although it was not discernible from the outside, Whiteacre had been converted by the banker from a single-family house to a structure that contained three separate apartments, in violation of the zoning ordinance. Further, the conversion was in violation of the building code. The banker and an employee entered into a valid written contract for the purchase and sale of Whiteacre. The contract provided that the banker was to convey to the employee a marketable title. The contract was silent as to zoning. The employee had fully inspected Whiteacre. Prior to the closing, the employee learned that Whiteacre did not conform to the zoning ordinance and refused to close even though the banker was ready, willing, and able to perform his contract obligations. The banker brought an appropriate action for specific performance against the employee . In that action, the banker should

options.optionA: A. win, because the banker was able to convey a marketable title.
options.optionB: B. win, because the employee was charged with knowledge of the zoning ordinance prior to entering the contract.
options.optionC: C. lose, because the illegal conversion of Whiteacre creates the risk of litigation.
options.optionD: D. lose, because the illegal conversion of Whiteacre was done by the banker rather than by a predecessor.

explanation.Legal_Concept: Marketability of title in real estate transactions, specifically the impact of zoning law violations on the marketability of title.
explanation.Fact_Analysis: The banker owned a property, Whiteacre, which was converted into three separate apartments in violation of the zoning ordinance and building code. The employee discovered the zoning violation prior to closing and refused to proceed, despite the banker's readiness to convey the property.
explanation.Rule_Application: A title is considered marketable if it is free of encumbrances. While building code violations do not affect marketability, zoning law violations are considered encumbrances that render the title unmarketable. In this case, the banker's conversion of Whiteacre into apartments in violation of the zoning ordinance creates a risk of litigation, making the title unmarketable.
explanation.Legal_Conclusion: Given that the title to Whiteacre is unmarketable due to the zoning law violation, the employee's refusal to close is justified. Therefore, the banker should lose the action for specific performance, supporting option C.

question: By warranty deed, a woman conveyed Blackacre to her friend and her neighbor "as joint tenants with right of survivorship." The friend and neighbor are not related. The friend conveyed all her interest to her boyfriend by warranty deed and subsequently died intestate. Thereafter, the neighbor conveyed to his girlfriend by warranty deed. There is no applicable statute, and the jurisdiction recognizes the common-law joint tenancy. Title to Blackacre is in

options.optionA: A. The girlfriend.
options.optionB: B. The woman.
options.optionC: C. The girlfriend and the boyfriend.
options.optionD: D. The girlfriend and the heirs of the friend.

explanation.Legal_Concept: Joint tenancy and its severance, particularly through inter vivos conveyance, and the resulting change in property ownership to tenancy in common.
explanation.Fact_Analysis: The property, Blackacre, was initially conveyed to the friend and neighbor as joint tenants with right of survivorship. The friend then conveyed her interest to her boyfriend, and subsequently died intestate. Afterward, the neighbor conveyed his interest to his girlfriend.
explanation.Rule_Application: In a joint tenancy, an inter vivos conveyance by one joint tenant severs the joint tenancy, converting the interest into a tenancy in common for the parties involved. Following the friend's conveyance to her boyfriend, the joint tenancy was severed, making the boyfriend and the neighbor tenants in common. The neighbor's subsequent conveyance to his girlfriend was thus a transfer of his interest as a tenant in common.
explanation.Legal_Conclusion: Given the severance of the joint tenancy upon the friend's conveyance to her boyfriend, and the neighbor's subsequent conveyance to his girlfriend, the title to Blackacre is held by the girlfriend and the boyfriend as tenants in common, supporting option C.

question: 3 months ago, a buyer agreed in writing to buy a property owner's single-family residence, Liveacre, for $110,000. The buyer paid the owner a $5,000 deposit to be applied to the purchase price. The contract stated that the owner had the right at his option to retain the deposit as liquidated damages in the event of the buyer's default. The closing was to have taken place last week. Six weeks ago, the buyer was notified by his employer that he was to be transferred to another job 1,000 miles away. The buyer immediately notified the owner that he could not close, and therefore he demanded the return of his $5,000. The owner refused, waited until after the contract closing date, listed with a broker, and then conveyed Liveacre for $108,000 to a subsequent purchaser found by the real estate broker. The subsequent purchaser paid the full purchase price and immediately recorded his deed. The subsequent purchaser knew of the prior contract with the original buyer. In an appropriate action, the original buyer seeks to recover the $5,000 deposit from the owner. The most probable result will be that the owner

options.optionA: A. must return the $5,000 to the original buyer, because the owner can no longer carry out his contract with the original buyer.
options.optionB: B. must return the $5,000 to the original buyer, because he was legally justified in not completing the contract.
options.optionC: C. must return $3,000 to the original buyer, because the owner's damages were only $2,000.
options.optionD: D. may keep the $5,000 deposit, because the original buyer breached the contract.

explanation.Legal_Concept: Liquidated damages in real estate contracts, specifically the seller's right to retain a buyer's deposit as damages following the buyer's breach of contract.
explanation.Fact_Analysis: The buyer agreed to purchase the property for $110,000 with a $5,000 deposit, which was to be applied to the purchase price. The contract allowed the owner to retain the deposit as liquidated damages in the event of the buyer's default. The buyer was notified of a job transfer and immediately notified the owner that he could not close, demanding the return of his deposit. The owner refused, waited until after the closing date, and then sold the property to a subsequent purchaser for $108,000.
explanation.Rule_Application: A seller is entitled to keep a buyer's deposit as liquidated damages following the buyer's breach of contract, as long as that deposit was 10% of the sale price or less. In this case, the deposit was $5,000, or 4.5% of the sale price, making it a valid liquidated damages provision.
explanation.Legal_Conclusion: Given that the buyer breached the contract and the deposit was a valid liquidated damages provision, the owner is entitled to keep the $5,000 deposit. Therefore, the correct answer is D, and the owner may keep the deposit.

question: A woman owned Woodsedge, a tract used for commercial purposes, in fee simple and thereafter mortgaged it to a bank. She signed a promissory note secured by a duly executed and recorded mortgage. There was no "due on sale" clause, that is, no provision that, upon sale, the whole balance then owing would become due and owing. The woman conveyed Woodsedge to a friend "subject to a mortgage to the bank, which the grantee assumes and agrees to pay." The friend conveyed Woodsedge to his son "subject to an existing mortgage to the bank." A copy of the note and the mortgage that secured it had been exhibited to each grantee. After the son made three timely payments, no further payments were made by any party. In fact, the real estate had depreciated to a point where it was worth less than the debt. There is no applicable statute or regulation. In an appropriate foreclosure action, the bank joined the woman, her friend, and the son as defendants. At the foreclosure sale, although the fair market value for Woodsedge in its depreciated state was obtained, a deficiency resulted. The bank is entitled to collect a deficiency judgment against

options.optionA: A. the woman only.
options.optionB: B. the woman and the friend only.
options.optionC: C. the friend and his son only.
options.optionD: D. the woman, the friend, and the son.

explanation.Legal_Concept: Personal liability on a mortgage and the effect of assumption versus subject to language in conveyances.
explanation.Fact_Analysis: The woman, as the original mortgagor, conveyed Woodsedge to her friend with an explicit agreement to assume and pay the mortgage. The friend then conveyed it to his son 'subject to an existing mortgage to the bank,' without an assumption of the mortgage. The son made three timely payments before defaulting, and the property depreciated to a value less than the debt.
explanation.Rule_Application: A mortgagor remains personally liable on the mortgage regardless of transfers. Subsequent grantees who explicitly assume the mortgage also become personally liable. However, grantees who take the property 'subject to' the mortgage without assuming it are not personally liable but risk losing the property through foreclosure. In this scenario, the woman and the friend are personally liable due to the original mortgage and the friend's explicit assumption, respectively.
explanation.Legal_Conclusion: Given the rules of personal liability on mortgages and the distinction between assumption and 'subject to' language, the bank is entitled to collect a deficiency judgment against the woman and the friend only, as they are the parties personally liable on the mortgage.

question: A testator owned Blackacre, a vacant one-acre tract of land. Five years ago, he executed a deed conveying Blackacre to "the church for the purpose of erecting a church building thereon." Three years ago, the testator died leaving his son as his sole heir at law. His duly probated will left "all my estate, both real and personal, to my friend." The church never constructed a church building on Blackacre and last month the church, for valid consideration, conveyed Blackacre to a developer. The developer brought an appropriate action to quiet title against the son, the friend, and the church, and joined the appropriate state official. Such official asserted that a charitable trust was created which has not terminated. In such action, the court should find that title is now in

options.optionA: A. the developer.
options.optionB: B. the son.
options.optionC: C. the friend.
options.optionD: D. the state official.

explanation.Legal_Concept: Charitable gifts and conveyances in real property law, specifically the interpretation of unconditional gifts for a particular purpose.
explanation.Fact_Analysis: The testator conveyed Blackacre to the church for the purpose of erecting a church building without specifying any conditions for the conveyance. The church never built on the land but later sold it to a developer. The testator's will left his entire estate to a friend, but the conveyance to the church occurred before the testator's death.
explanation.Rule_Application: A charitable gift of real property is valid if it is made without conditions. The language of the conveyance did not impose a condition that the church must build on the land to retain ownership. Therefore, the church's failure to build does not affect its ownership or its ability to convey the land to a third party.
explanation.Legal_Conclusion: Since the conveyance to the church was unconditional and valid, the church was free to sell the land to the developer. The developer now holds valid legal title to the land, and the court should find title in the developer, supporting option A.

question: A brother and a sister acquired title in fee simple to Blackacre, as equal tenants in common, by inheritance from their aunt. During the last 15 years of her lifetime, the aunt allowed the brother to occupy an apartment in the house on Blackacre, to rent the other apartment in the house to various tenants, and to retain the rent. The brother made no payments to the aunt; and since the aunt's death 7 years ago, he has made no payments to his sister. For those 22 years, the brother has paid the real estate taxes on Blackacre, kept the building on Blackacre insured, and maintained the building. At all times, the sister has lived in a distant city and has never had anything to do with the aunt, her brother, or Blackacre. Recently, the sister needed money to run her business and demanded that her brother join her in selling Blackacre. He refused. The period of time to acquire title by adverse possession in the jurisdiction is 10 years. There is no other applicable statute. The sister brought an appropriate action against her brother for partition. The brother asserted all available defenses and counterclaims. In that action, the court should

options.optionA: A. deny partition and find that title has vested in the brother by adverse possession.
options.optionB: B. deny partition, confirm the tenancy in common, but require an accounting to determine if either the sister or brother is indebted to the other on account of the rental payment, taxes, insurance premiums, and maintenance costs.
options.optionC: C. grant partition and require, as an adjustment, an accounting to determine if either the sister or brother is indebted to the other on account of the rental payments, taxes, insurance premiums, and maintenance costs.
options.optionD: D. grant partition to the sister and brother as equal owners, but without an accounting.

explanation.Legal_Concept: Rights and duties of tenants in common, particularly the right to partition and contribution for expenditures.
explanation.Fact_Analysis: The brother and sister inherited Blackacre as equal tenants in common. The brother has exclusively managed the property, collected rent, paid taxes, maintained the building, and kept it insured for 22 years without making any payments to the sister. The sister has had no involvement with the property and now seeks partition to raise funds for her business.
explanation.Rule_Application: Tenants in common have the right to partition, even if one co-tenant opposes it. Additionally, co-tenants have a right to contribution from each other for certain expenditures such as taxes, mortgage payments, and necessary repairs. An accounting is necessary to determine each co-tenant's contribution rights.
explanation.Legal_Conclusion: Given the rights of tenants in common, the court should grant partition as requested by the sister. Furthermore, an accounting is required to determine the contribution rights of the sister and brother regarding the rental payments, taxes, insurance premiums, and maintenance costs, supporting option C.

question: A brother and sister owned Greenacre in fee simple as tenants in common, each owning an undivided one-half interest. The brother and sister joined in mortgaging Greenacre to a private lender by a properly recorded mortgage that contained a general warranty clause. The brother became disenchanted with land-owning and notified his sister that he would no longer contribute to the payment of installments due to the private lender. After the mortgage was in default and the private lender made demand for payment of the entire amount of principal and interest due, the sister tendered to the private lender, and the private lender deposited, a check for one-half of the amount due the private lender. The sister then demanded a release of her undivided one-half interest. The private lender refused to release any interest in Greenacre. The sister promptly brought an action against the private lender to quiet title to an undivided one-half interest in Greenacre. In such action, the sister should

options.optionA: A. lose, because the private lender's title had been warranted by an express provision of the mortgage.
options.optionB: B. lose, because there was no redemption from the mortgage.
options.optionC: C. win, because the sister is entitled to marshalling.
options.optionD: D. win, because the cotenancy of the mortgagors was in common and not joint.

explanation.Legal_Concept: Joint and several liability in the context of a mortgage held by co-owners of a property.
explanation.Fact_Analysis: The brother and sister, as tenants in common, jointly mortgaged their undivided interests in Greenacre to a private lender, creating a joint mortgage with joint and several liability. The sister made a payment of half of what was owed on the mortgage after it went into default.
explanation.Rule_Application: In a joint mortgage, co-owners are jointly and severally liable for the debt. This means that each co-owner is responsible for the entire debt, and the creditor can seek the full amount from either co-owner. The sister's payment of half the debt does not extinguish the private lender's interest in the property because the debt remains outstanding.
explanation.Legal_Conclusion: Given the joint nature of the mortgage and the joint and several liability of the co-owners, the private lender is not required to release any interest in Greenacre. Therefore, the sister will lose her action to quiet title to an undivided one-half interest in Greenacre, supporting option B.

question: A business owner owned a hotel, subject to a mortgage securing a debt the owner owed to bank. The owner later acquired a nearby parking garage, financing a part of the purchase price by a loan from a private lender, secured by a mortgage on the parking garage. Two years thereafter, the owner defaulted on the loan owed to the bank, which caused the full amount of that loan to become immediately due and payable. The bank decided not to foreclose on the mortgage on the owner's hotel at that time, but instead brought an action, appropriate under the laws of the jurisdiction and authorized by the mortgage loan documents, for the full amount of the defaulted loan. The bank obtained and properly filed a judgment for that amount. A statute of the jurisdiction provides: "Any judgment properly filed shall, for ten years from filing, be a lien on the real property then owned or subsequently acquired by any person against whom the judgment is rendered." There is no other applicable statute, except the statute providing for judicial foreclosure of mortgages, which places no restriction on deficiency judgments. The bank later brought an appropriate action for judicial foreclosure of its first mortgage on the hotel and of its judgment lien on the parking garage. The private lender was joined as a party defendant, and appropriately counterclaimed for foreclosure of its mortgage on the parking garage, which was also in default. All procedures were properly followed and the confirmed foreclosure sales resulted as follows: The bank purchased the hotel for $100,000 less than its mortgage balance. The bank purchased the parking garage for an amount that is $200,000 in excess of the private lender's mortgage balance. The $200,000 surplus arising from the bid paid by the bank for the parking garage should be paid

options.optionA: A. $100,000 to the bank and $100,000 to the owner.
options.optionB: B. $100,000 to the private lender and $100,000 to the owner.
options.optionC: C. $100,000 to the bank and $100,000 to the private lender.
options.optionD: D. $200,000 to the owner.

explanation.Legal_Concept: Priority of liens and distribution of surplus funds after foreclosure sales, particularly in the context of mortgage liens and judgment liens.
explanation.Fact_Analysis: The bank held a mortgage on the hotel and a judgment lien on the parking garage. The private lender held a mortgage on the parking garage. After the foreclosure sales, the bank purchased the hotel for $100,000 less than its mortgage balance and the parking garage for $200,000 in excess of the private lender's mortgage balance, resulting in a surplus.
explanation.Rule_Application: In the distribution of surplus funds after foreclosure, priority is given to the party with the senior lien. The bank, as the holder of the judgment lien on the parking garage, stands ahead of the private lender in the line of priority. The private lender, having been fully paid, is not entitled to any of the surplus. The bank must receive all the money it is owed before the owner will be entitled to receive anything.
explanation.Legal_Conclusion: Given the priority of liens and the distribution rules, the $200,000 surplus should be paid $100,000 to the bank to satisfy its remaining debt and $100,000 to the owner, supporting option A.

question: A woman owned Blueacre, a tract of land, in fee simple. The woman wrote and executed, with the required formalities, a will that devised Blueacre to "my daughter for life with remainder to my descendants per stirpes." At the time of writing the will, the woman had a husband and no descendants living other than her two children, a daughter and a son. The woman died and the will was duly admitted to probate. The woman's husband predeceased her. The woman was survived by her two children, four grandchildren, and one great-grandchild. The two children were the woman's sole heirs at law. The two children brought an appropriate action for declaratory judgment as to title of Blueacre. Guardians ad litem were appointed and all other steps were taken so that the judgment would bind all persons interested whether born or unborn. In that action, if the court rules that the daughter has a life estate in the whole of Blueacre and that the remainder is contingent, it will be because the court chose one of several possible constructions and that the chosen construction

options.optionA: A. related all vesting to the time of writing of the will.
options.optionB: B. related all vesting to the death of the woman.
options.optionC: C. implied a condition that remaindermen survive the daughter.
options.optionD: D. implied a gift of a life estate to the son.

explanation.Legal_Concept: Contingent remainders in wills, specifically the conditions under which a remainder becomes vested.
explanation.Fact_Analysis: The woman's will devises Blueacre to her daughter for life with a remainder to her descendants per stirpes. At the time of the will, she had two children and no other descendants. She was survived by her two children, four grandchildren, and one great-grandchild.
explanation.Rule_Application: A remainder is contingent if there is a condition precedent that must be satisfied before the interest will vest. In this case, the remainder to the descendants per stirpes implies a condition that the remaindermen must survive the daughter for the interest to vest.
explanation.Legal_Conclusion: Given that the court's ruling of a contingent remainder implies a condition that must be satisfied, the correct answer is that the court chose a construction that implied a condition that remaindermen survive the daughter, supporting option C.

question: Thirty years ago, a landowner conveyed land by warranty deed to a church (a charity) "so long as the land herein conveyed is used as the site for the principal religious edifice maintained by said church." Twenty years ago, the landowner died intestate, survived by a single heir. One year ago, the church dissolved and its church building situated on the land was demolished. There is no applicable statute. The common law Rule Against Perpetuities is unmodified in the jurisdiction. In an appropriate action, the landowner's heir and the attorney general, who is the appropriate official to assert public interests in charitable trusts, contest the right to the land. In such action, who will prevail?

options.optionA: A. The landowner's heir, as successor to the landowner's possibility of reverter.
options.optionB: B. The landowner's heir, because a charity cannot convey assets donated to it.
options.optionC: C. The attorney general, because cy pres should be applied to devote the land to religious purposes to carry out the charitable intent of the landowner.
options.optionD: D. The attorney general, because the landowner's attempt to restrict the church's fee simple violated the Rule Against Perpetuities.

explanation.Legal_Concept: Fee simple determinable and the Rule Against Perpetuities in the context of conveyances with conditional uses.
explanation.Fact_Analysis: A landowner conveyed land to a church by warranty deed with the condition that the land be used as the site for the church's principal religious edifice. The church has since dissolved, and the building has been demolished, triggering the end of the church's right to possession.
explanation.Rule_Application: The conveyance created a fee simple determinable, with the landowner retaining a possibility of reverter. This future interest is not subject to the Rule Against Perpetuities, as it is a grantor's interest. Upon the church's failure to meet the condition, the land automatically reverted to the landowner's heir, who inherited the possibility of reverter.
explanation.Legal_Conclusion: Given that the church's right to possession ended upon its failure to meet the condition, and the landowner's heir inherited the possibility of reverter, the heir is entitled to possession of the land. Therefore, the landowner's heir will prevail, supporting option A.

question: A seller who owned land in fee simple entered into a valid written agreement to sell the land to a buyer by installment purchase. The contract stipulated that the seller would deliver to the buyer, upon the payment of the last installment due, "a warranty deed sufficient to convey a fee simple title." The contract contained no other provision that could be construed as referring to title. The buyer entered into possession of the land. After making 10 of the 300 installment payments obligated under the contract, the buyer discovered that there was outstanding a valid and enforceable mortgage on the land, securing the payment of a debt in the amount of 25 percent of the purchase price that the buyer had agreed to pay. There was no evidence that the seller had ever been late in payments due under the mortgage and there was no evidence of any danger of insolvency of the seller. The value of the land was then four times the amount due on the debt secured by the mortgage. The buyer quit possession of the land, stopped making payments on the contract, and demanded that the seller repay the amounts that the buyer had paid under the contract. After the seller refused the demand, the buyer sued the seller to recover damages for the seller's alleged breach of the contract. In such action, should damages be awarded to the buyer?

options.optionA: A. Yes, because in the absence of a contrary express agreement, an obligation to convey marketable title is implied.
options.optionB: B. Yes, because an installment purchase contract is treated as a mortgage and the outstanding mortgage impairs the buyer's equity of redemption.
options.optionC: C. No, because an installment purchase contract is treated as a security device.
options.optionD: D. No, because the time for the seller to deliver marketable title has not arrived.

explanation.Legal_Concept: The requirement of marketable title in a real estate transaction, specifically in the context of an installment purchase contract.
explanation.Fact_Analysis: The buyer and seller entered into a valid written agreement for the sale of land by installment purchase. The contract stipulated that the seller would deliver a warranty deed sufficient to convey a fee simple title upon the payment of the last installment due. After making 10 of the 300 installment payments, the buyer discovered an outstanding mortgage on the land, but there was no evidence of late payments or danger of insolvency by the seller, and the land's value was four times the amount due on the debt.
explanation.Rule_Application: In an installment purchase contract, the obligation to convey marketable title is implied, but this obligation is not triggered until the closing date when all payments have been received. Since the buyer still has 290 payments to make, the time for the seller to deliver marketable title has not yet arrived.
explanation.Legal_Conclusion: Given that the seller's obligation to deliver marketable title has not yet been triggered, and it is likely that the mortgage debt will be paid off by the time the seller must provide the warranty deed, the buyer is not entitled to damages at this time. Therefore, the correct answer is D, as the time for the seller to deliver marketable title has not arrived.

question: A man contacted his lawyer regarding his right to use a path that was on his neighbor's vacant land. Fifteen years ago, after a part of the path located on his land and connecting his cabin to the public highway washed out, the man cleared a small part of his neighbor's land and rerouted a section of the path through the neighbor's land. Twelve years ago, the neighbor leased her land to some hunters. For the next 12 years, the hunters and the man who had rerouted the path used the path for access to the highway. A month ago, the neighbor discovered that part of the path was on her land. The neighbor told the man that she had not given him permission to cross her land and that she would be closing the rerouted path after 90 days. The man's land and the neighbor's land have never been in common ownership. The period of time necessary to acquire rights by prescription in the jurisdiction is 10 years. The period of time necessary to acquire title by adverse possession in the jurisdiction is 10 years. What should the lawyer tell the man concerning his right to use the rerouted path on the neighbor's land?

options.optionA: A. The man has fee title by adverse possession of the land included in the path.
options.optionB: B. The man has an easement by necessity to use the path.
options.optionC: C. The man has an easement by prescription to use the path.
options.optionD: D. The man has no right to use the path.

explanation.Legal_Concept: Easement by prescription, specifically the acquisition of a right to use a portion of another's land without their permission for a statutory period.
explanation.Fact_Analysis: The man rerouted a path through his neighbor's land 15 years ago due to a washout on his own property. He and the neighbor's tenants (hunters) have used the path for the past 12 years without the neighbor's knowledge or permission. The neighbor has recently discovered the path and intends to close it.
explanation.Rule_Application: An easement by prescription requires use of the land without the owner's permission for the requisite period (10 years in this jurisdiction), which must be open, notorious, continuous, and actual. The man's use of the path meets these criteria, and the concurrent use by the hunters does not interfere with the man's use, nor does his use interfere with theirs.
explanation.Legal_Conclusion: Given the man's uninterrupted use of the path for 15 years, which meets the requirements for an easement by prescription, he has acquired a right to use the path. Therefore, the correct advice the lawyer should give the man is that he has an easement by prescription to use the path, supporting option C.

question: Seven years ago, a man, his sister, and his cousin became equal owners, as tenants in common, of a house. Until a year ago, the man lived in the house alone. The sister and the cousin are longtime residents of another state. One year ago, the man moved to an apartment and rented the house to a tenant for three years under a lease that the man and the tenant both signed. The tenant has since paid the rent each month to the man. Recently, the sister and the cousin learned about the rental. They brought an appropriate action against the tenant to have the lease declared void and to have the tenant evicted. The tenant raised all available defenses. What will the court likely decide?

options.optionA: A. The lease is void, and the tenant is evicted.
options.optionB: B. The lease is valid, and the tenant retains exclusive occupancy rights for the balance of the term.
options.optionC: C. The lease is valid, but the tenant is evicted because one-third of the lease term has expired and the man had only a one-third interest to transfer.
options.optionD: D. The lease is valid, and the tenant is not evicted but must share possession with the sister and the cousin.

explanation.Legal_Concept: Transfer of interest in a tenancy in common, specifically the rights and limitations of leasing a property by one co-owner.
explanation.Fact_Analysis: The man, as one of three equal owners of a house as tenants in common, leased the property to a tenant for three years without the knowledge or consent of his sister and cousin. The tenant has been paying rent to the man, who has been living elsewhere.
explanation.Rule_Application: A tenant in common may transfer their undivided interest in the property by leasing it for a term of years. However, this transfer does not grant the tenant exclusive possession but rather a concurrent right of possession with the other co-owners. Thus, the tenant must share the property with the other tenants in common for the duration of the lease.
explanation.Legal_Conclusion: Given that the man validly transferred his interest in the tenancy in common to the tenant, the lease is valid. However, the tenant does not gain exclusive occupancy rights but must share possession with the sister and the cousin. Therefore, the correct outcome is that the lease is valid, and the tenant is not evicted but must share possession with the other co-owners.

question: A woman died, devising land that she owned in another state to her daughter, who was then 17 years old. A neighbor who owned the property immediately adjacent to the land wrongfully began to possess the land at that time. For 24 of the next 25 years, the neighbor planted and harvested crops on the land, hunted on it, and parked cars on it. However, in the sixth year after he first took possession of the land, the neighbor neither planted crops nor hunted nor parked cars on the land because he spent that entire year living in Europe. The neighbor built a small gardening shed on the land, but he never built a residence on it. When the daughter was 28, she was declared mentally incompetent and had a conservator appointed to oversee her affairs. Since then, she has continuously resided in a care facility. The applicable statute of limitations provides as follows: "An ejectment action shall be brought within 21 years after the cause of action accrues, but if the person entitled to bring the cause of action is under age 18 or mentally incompetent at the time the cause of action accrues, it may be brought by such person within 10 years after attaining age 18 or after the person becomes competent." If the daughter's conservator wins an ejectment action against the neighbor, what will be the most likely explanation?

options.optionA: A. The daughter was age 17 when the neighbor first took possession of the land.
options.optionB: B. Because the daughter is mentally incompetent, the statute of limitations has been tolled.
options.optionC: C. The neighbor never built a residence on the land.
options.optionD: D. The neighbor was not in continuous possession of the land for 21 years.

explanation.Legal_Concept: Adverse possession and the statute of limitations for ejectment actions, particularly the requirements for continuous possession and the impact of minority and mental incompetence on the statute of limitations.
explanation.Fact_Analysis: The neighbor took possession of the land when the daughter was 17, and for 24 of the next 25 years, the neighbor openly and exclusively used the land. However, the neighbor spent one year in Europe, breaking the continuity of possession. The daughter turned 18 within a year of the neighbor's initial possession and was later declared mentally incompetent.
explanation.Rule_Application: To acquire title by adverse possession, the claimant must have open, notorious, actual, exclusive, hostile, and continuous possession for the statutory period of 21 years. The statute of limitations for ejectment actions may be tolled for minors or the mentally incompetent, but only within specific timeframes. In this case, the neighbor's possession was not continuous for 21 years, and the daughter's minority and subsequent mental incompetence do not extend the time for her to bring an ejectment action beyond the 21-year minimum.
explanation.Legal_Conclusion: Given that the neighbor was not in continuous adverse possession for the full 21-year period, the most likely explanation for the daughter's conservator winning an ejectment action is that the neighbor failed to meet the continuous possession requirement for adverse possession, supporting option D.

question: Meadowview is a large tract of undeveloped land. The man who owns Meadowview prepared a development plan creating 200 house lots in Meadowview with the necessary streets and public areas. The plan was fully approved by all necessary governmental agencies and duly recorded. However, construction of the streets, utilities, and other aspects of the development of Meadowview has not yet begun, and none of the streets can be opened as public ways until they are completed in accordance with the applicable ordinances of the municipality in which Meadowview is located. College Avenue, one of the streets laid out as part of the Meadowview development, abuts Whiteacre, an adjacent one-acre parcel owned by a woman. Whiteacre has no access to any public way except an old, poorly developed road which is inconvenient and cannot be used without great expense. The woman sold Whiteacre to a friend. The description used in the deed from the woman to the friend was the same as that used in prior deeds except that the portion of the description which formerly said, "thence by land of Black, north-easterly a distance of 200 feet, more or less," was changed to "thence by College Avenue as laid out on the Plan of Meadowview North 46-East 201.6 feet," with full reference to the plan and its recording data. The friend now seeks a building permit which will show that the friend intends to use College Avenue for access to Whiteacre. The man objects to the granting of a building permit on the grounds that he has never granted any right to the woman or her friend to use College Avenue. There are no governing statutes or ordinances relating to the problem. The man brings an appropriate action in which the right of the friend to use College Avenue without an express grant from the man is at issue. The best argument for the friend in this action is that

options.optionA: A. there is a way by necessity over Meadowview's lands to gain access to a public road.
options.optionB: B. the deed from the woman to her friend referred to the recorded plan and therefore created rights to use the streets delineated on the plan.
options.optionC: C. sale of lots in Meadowview by reference to its plan creates private easements in the streets shown in the plan.
options.optionD: D. the recording of the plan is a dedication of the streets shown on the plan to public use.

explanation.Legal_Concept: Public dedication of land for streets and public areas in a development plan.
explanation.Fact_Analysis: The owner of Meadowview prepared and recorded a development plan that included streets and public areas, which was fully approved by all necessary governmental agencies. The plan was referenced in the deed from the woman to her friend, describing the boundaries of Whiteacre. The friend seeks to use College Avenue, one of the streets in the plan, for access to Whiteacre, but the owner objects, claiming no express grant was given.
explanation.Rule_Application: A public dedication of land is established when there is an expressed intent to dedicate land for public use and an acceptance of the dedication. The recording of the plan with language indicating streets and public areas set aside for public use, combined with the approval by governmental agencies, suggests an intent to dedicate and acceptance by the public entity.
explanation.Legal_Conclusion: Given the expressed intent to dedicate and the acceptance by the public entity, the friend's best argument is that the plan constitutes a public dedication of the street areas, supporting the right to use College Avenue without an express grant from the owner, which aligns with option D.

question: A testator devised his farm "to my son for life, then to my son's children and their heirs and assigns." The son, a widower, had two unmarried adult children. In an appropriate action to construe the will, the court will determine that the remainder to children is

options.optionA: A. indefeasibly vested.
options.optionB: B. contingent.
options.optionC: C. vested subject to partial defeasance.
options.optionD: D. vested subject to complete defeasance.

explanation.Legal_Concept: Vested and contingent remainders in wills, specifically the classification of a remainder to a group of beneficiaries.
explanation.Fact_Analysis: The testator devised the farm to his son for life, with a remainder to the son's children and their heirs and assigns. The son is a widower with two unmarried adult children.
explanation.Rule_Application: A vested remainder is one that is guaranteed to become possessory, whereas a contingent remainder is dependent on the occurrence of a specific event. A remainder is vested subject to partial defeasance if it is certain to become possessory but may be reduced in size by the birth of additional beneficiaries. In this case, the remainder to the son's children is vested because it is guaranteed to become possessory, but it is subject to partial defeasance because the son may have additional children, which would reduce the share of the existing children.
explanation.Legal_Conclusion: Given the language of the will and the rules governing vested and contingent remainders, the remainder to the son's children is vested subject to partial defeasance, as it is certain to become possessory but may be reduced in size by the birth of additional beneficiaries, supporting option C.

question: By way of a gift, a father executed a deed naming his daughter as grantee. The deed contained descriptions as follows: (I) All of my land and dwelling known as 44 Main Street, Midtown, United States, being one acre. (II) All that part of my farm, being a square with 200-foot sides, the southeast corner of which is in the north line of my neighbor. The deed contained covenants of general warranty, quiet enjoyment, and right to convey. The father handed the deed to his daughter who immediately returned it to her father for safekeeping. Her father kept it in his safe deposit box. The deed was not recorded. The property at 44 Main Street covered 7/8 of an acre of land, had a dwelling and a garage situated thereon, and was subject to a right of way, described in prior deeds, in favor of a different neighbor. The father owned no other land on Main Street. This neighbor had not used the right of way for ten years and it was not visible on inspection of the property. The description of part of the father's farm

options.optionA: A. is sufficient if consideration has been paid.
options.optionB: B. is sufficient because no ambiguity therein appears on the face of the deed.
options.optionC: C. could be enforced if the deed contained a covenant of seisin.
options.optionD: D. is insufficient because of vagueness.

explanation.Legal_Concept: The requirements for a valid description of land in a deed, specifically the need for sufficient specificity to identify and locate the property.
explanation.Fact_Analysis: The deed contains two descriptions: one for a specific property at 44 Main Street, and another for a part of the father's farm. The description of the farm is vague, using a square with 200-foot sides and referencing the southeast corner being in the north line of a neighbor's property, without providing clear boundaries or identifiable landmarks.
explanation.Rule_Application: A description of land in a deed must be specific enough to allow a party to identify and locate the property. While minor discrepancies are allowed, a description that is too vague to enable location of the property will render the deed void for vagueness. In this case, the description of the farm fails to meet this standard, making it insufficient.
explanation.Legal_Conclusion: Given the vagueness of the description of the farm in the deed, it is insufficient to allow location of the property, and thus any attempted transfer of rights using that deed would be void. Therefore, the correct answer is D, as the description is insufficient due to vagueness.

question: The owner of Blackacre conveyed a right-of-way to a utility company "for the underground transportation of gas by pipeline, the location of right-of-way to be mutually agreed upon by [the owner] and [the utility company]." The utility company then installed a six-inch pipeline at a location selected by it and not objected to by the owner. Two years later, the utility company advised the owner of its intention to install an additional six-inch pipeline parallel to and three feet laterally from the original pipeline. In an appropriate action, the owner sought a declaration that the utility company has no right to install the second pipeline. If the owner prevails, it will be because

options.optionA: A. any right implied to expand the original use of the right-of-way creates an interest that violates the Rule Against Perpetuities.
options.optionB: B. the original installation by the utility company defined the scope of the easement.
options.optionC: C. the owner did not expressly agree to the location of the right-of-way.
options.optionD: D. the assertion of the right to install an additional pipeline constitutes inverse condemnation.

explanation.Legal_Concept: Express easements in gross and the scope of their use, particularly in relation to the rights of easement holders and landowners.
explanation.Fact_Analysis: The owner of Blackacre granted a right-of-way to a utility company for the underground transportation of gas by pipeline, with the location to be mutually agreed upon. The utility company installed a six-inch pipeline at a selected location without objection from the owner. Later, the utility company sought to install an additional pipeline parallel to the original one.
explanation.Rule_Application: An easement holder is entitled to reasonable use of the easement in accordance with the scope defined by the express grant. Excessive use beyond this scope can be prevented by the landowner through an injunction, but the original grant remains intact. In this case, the utility company's attempt to install another pipeline in a different location exceeds the scope of the easement granted.
explanation.Legal_Conclusion: Given that the original installation defined the scope of the easement, the utility company's action to install a second pipeline is beyond the agreed-upon use. Therefore, the owner prevails, supporting option B.

question: The owner of Profitacre executed an instrument in the proper form of a deed, purporting to convey Profitacre "to my brother for life, then to my nephew in fee simple." The brother, who is the owner's brother and nephew's father, promptly began to manage Profitacre, which is valuable income-producing real estate. The brother collected all rents and paid all expenses, including real estate taxes. The nephew did not object, and this state of affairs continued for five years until 1987. In that year, the brother executed an instrument in the proper form of a deed, purporting to convey Profitacre to his girlfriend. The nephew, no admirer of the girlfriend, asserted his right to ownership of Profitacre. The girlfriend asserted her ownership and said that if the nephew had any rights he was obligated to pay real estate taxes, even though the brother had been kind enough to pay them in the past. Income from Profitacre is ample to cover expenses, including real estate taxes. In an appropriate action to determine the rights of the parties, the court should decide

options.optionA: A. The brother's purported deed forfeited his life estate, so the nephew owns Profitacre in fee simple.
options.optionB: B. The girlfriend owns an estate for her life, is entitled to all income, and must pay real estate taxes; the nephew owns the remainder interest.
options.optionC: C. The girlfriend owns an estate for the life of the brother, is entitled to all income, and must pay real estate taxes; the nephew owns the remainder interest.
options.optionD: D. The girlfriend owns an estate for the life of the brother and is entitled to all income; the nephew owns the remainder interest, and must pay real estate taxes.

explanation.Legal_Concept: Estates in land, specifically life estates and vested remainders, and the rights and responsibilities associated with each.
explanation.Fact_Analysis: The owner of Profitacre conveyed the property to the brother for life, with a vested remainder in the nephew. The brother managed the property, collected rents, and paid expenses, including real estate taxes, for five years before conveying the property to his girlfriend. The nephew asserts his right to ownership, while the girlfriend claims ownership and suggests the nephew is responsible for paying real estate taxes.
explanation.Rule_Application: A life tenant has the right to convey their interest, but the conveyance is only valid for the duration of the measuring life. The life tenant also has a duty not to commit voluntary or permissive waste, which includes paying real estate taxes. A vested remainder is unaffected by the life tenant's conveyance. In this case, the brother's conveyance to the girlfriend created a life estate in the girlfriend, lasting for the remainder of the brother's life, with the nephew retaining the vested remainder.
explanation.Legal_Conclusion: The girlfriend owns a life estate for the duration of the brother's life, is entitled to all income, and must pay real estate taxes to avoid committing permissive waste. The nephew owns the vested remainder interest, which is unaffected by the brother's conveyance to the girlfriend. Therefore, the correct answer is C.

question: A woman owned Blackacre, her home. Her daughter lived with her and always referred to Blackacre as "my property." Two years ago, the daughter, for a valuable consideration, executed and delivered to her boyfriend an instrument in the proper form of a warranty deed purporting to convey Blackacre to the boyfriend in fee simple, reserving to herself an estate for two years in Blackacre. The boyfriend promptly and properly recorded the deed. One year ago, the woman died and by will, duly admitted to probate, left her entire estate to the daughter. One month ago, the daughter, for a valuable consideration, executed and delivered to a buyer an instrument in the proper form of a warranty deed purporting to convey Blackacre to the buyer, who promptly and properly recorded the deed. The daughter was then in possession of Blackacre and the buyer had no actual knowledge of the deed to the boyfriend. Immediately thereafter, the daughter gave possession to the buyer. The recording act of the jurisdiction provides: "No conveyance or mortgage of real property shall be good against subsequent purchasers for value and without notice unless the same be recorded according to law." Last week, the daughter fled the jurisdiction. Upon learning the facts, the buyer brought an appropriate action against the boyfriend to quiet title to Blackacre. If the buyer wins, it will be because

options.optionA: A. the daughter had nothing to convey to the boyfriend two years ago.
options.optionB: B. the daughter's deed to the boyfriend was not to take effect until after the daughter's deed to the buyer.
options.optionC: C. the buyer was first in possession.
options.optionD: D. the daughter's deed to the boyfriend was not in the buyer's chain of title.

explanation.Legal_Concept: The application of a notice act in a recording statute to determine priority among purchasers of real property.
explanation.Fact_Analysis: The daughter executed a warranty deed to the boyfriend two years ago, reserving an estate for two years, and the boyfriend recorded the deed. The daughter then executed another warranty deed to the buyer one month ago, who promptly recorded it without actual knowledge of the deed to the boyfriend. The buyer had no notice of the earlier deed because it was not in their chain of title.
explanation.Rule_Application: Under a notice act, a bona fide purchaser who records their deed without notice of earlier purchasers will prevail. To be a bona fide purchaser, one must give value for their interest in the land and record without notice. The buyer meets these requirements, having given value and recorded without notice of the boyfriend's deed, which was not in their chain of title.
