explanation.Legal_Conclusion: Given the 'as is' provision in the contract, the woman may not be liable for the defects, as this provision could be seen as sufficient notice to the plaintiff of potential issues with the property. Therefore, the correct answer is B, as the 'as is' provision controls the rights of the parties.

question: A gentleman owned Greenacre in fee simple of record on January 10. On that day, a bank loaned the gentleman $50,000 and the gentleman mortgaged Greenacre to the bank as security for the loan. The mortgage was recorded on January 18. The gentleman conveyed Greenacre to a buyer for a valuable consideration on January 11. The bank did not know of this, nor did the buyer know of the mortgage to the bank, until both discovered the facts on January 23, the day on which the buyer recorded the gentleman's deed. The recording act of the jurisdiction provides: "No unrecorded conveyance or mortgage of real property shall be good against subsequent purchasers for value without notice, who shall first record." There is no provision for a grace period, and there is no other relevant statutory provision. The bank sued the buyer to establish that its mortgage was good against Greenacre. The court should decide for

options.optionA: A. the buyer, because he paid valuable consideration without notice before the bank recorded its mortgage.
options.optionB: B. the buyer, because the bank's delay in recording means that it is estopped from asserting its priority in time.
options.optionC: C. the bank, because the buyer did not record his deed before the bank's mortgage was recorded.
options.optionD: D. the bank, because after the mortgage to the bank, the gentleman's deed to the buyer was necessarily subject to its mortgage.

explanation.Legal_Concept: Priority of interests in real property under a race-notice recording act.
explanation.Fact_Analysis: The gentleman mortgaged Greenacre to the bank on January 10, which was recorded on January 18. Meanwhile, the gentleman conveyed Greenacre to the buyer on January 11, but the buyer did not record the deed until January 23, after discovering the mortgage. The bank was unaware of the conveyance until January 23.
explanation.Rule_Application: Under a race-notice act, a party must be a bona fide purchaser who records their deed first and acquires the land without notice of earlier purchasers. In this scenario, the bank recorded its mortgage first without notice of the gentleman's conveyance to the buyer, making it the first to record and prevail under the act.
explanation.Legal_Conclusion: Given that the bank was the first to record its interest without notice of the buyer's interest, the court should decide in favor of the bank, supporting option C.

question: A mother owned Blackacre, a two-family apartment house on a small city lot not suitable for partition-in-kind. Upon the mother's death, her will devised Blackacre to "my son and daughter." A week ago, a creditor obtained a money judgment against the son, and properly filed the judgment in the county where Blackacre is located. A statute in the jurisdiction provides: any judgment properly filed shall, for ten years from filing, be a lien on the real property then owned or subsequently acquired by any person against whom the judgment is rendered. The son needed cash, but the daughter did not wish to sell Blackacre. The son commenced a partition action against the daughter and the creditor. Assume that the court properly ordered a partition by judicial sale. After the sale, the creditor's judgment will be a lien on

options.optionA: A. all of Blackacre.
options.optionB: B. only a one-half interest in Blackacre.
options.optionC: C. all of the proceeds of a sale of Blackacre.
options.optionD: D. only the portion of the proceeds of sale due to the brother.

explanation.Legal_Concept: Partition of co-owned property and the effect of a creditor's lien on a co-owner's interest.
explanation.Fact_Analysis: The mother's will devised Blackacre to her son and daughter without specifying a joint tenancy, resulting in them holding the property as tenants in common with equal 50% interests. A creditor obtained a judgment against the son and filed it properly, creating a lien on the son's real property. The son commenced a partition action, and the court ordered a partition by judicial sale.
explanation.Rule_Application: A creditor's lien only attaches to the interest of the debtor, in this case, the son's 50% interest in Blackacre. Upon the judicial sale of the property, the son's interest is terminated, and the creditor's lien can only attach to the portion of the proceeds due to the son, not the entire property or all proceeds.
explanation.Legal_Conclusion: Given that the creditor's lien only applies to the son's interest in Blackacre, which is terminated upon sale, the correct outcome is that the creditor's judgment will be a lien on only the portion of the proceeds of sale due to the brother, supporting option D.

question: A man entered into a valid written contract to sell Blackacre, a large tract of land, to a purchaser. At that time, Blackacre was owned by the man's father; the man had no title to Blackacre and was not the agent of the father. After the contract was executed and before the scheduled closing date, the father died intestate, leaving the man as his sole heir. Shortly thereafter, the man received an offer for Blackacre that was substantially higher than the purchase price in the contract with the purchaser. The man refused to close with the purchaser even though she was ready, willing, and able to close pursuant to the contract. The purchaser brought an appropriate action for specific performance against the man. In that action, the purchaser should be awarded

options.optionA: A. nothing, because the man had no authority to enter into the contract with the purchaser.
options.optionB: B. nothing, because the doctrine of after-acquired title does not apply to executory contracts.
options.optionC: C. judgment for specific performance, because the man acquired title prior to the scheduled closing.
options.optionD: D. judgment for specific performance, to prevent unjust enrichment of the man.

explanation.Legal_Concept: Specific performance in contract law, particularly in the context of real estate transactions and the doctrine of after-acquired title.
explanation.Fact_Analysis: The man entered into a contract to sell Blackacre, a property he did not own at the time, to a purchaser. Before the scheduled closing, the man's father, the actual owner, died intestate, leaving the man as his sole heir and thus acquiring title to Blackacre.
explanation.Rule_Application: The doctrine of after-acquired title allows for the transfer of property rights to a buyer even if the seller did not have title at the time of contracting, as long as the seller acquires title before the closing date. Since the man acquired good title to Blackacre before the scheduled closing, he is bound by the contract and the purchaser is entitled to specific performance.
explanation.Legal_Conclusion: Given that the man acquired good title to Blackacre before the closing date, the purchaser's claim for specific performance should be granted, as the man's acquisition of title provides a basis for the purchaser's claim against him for breach of contract.

question: The owner of Blackacre had promised his best friend that, if at any time the owner decided to sell his summer cottage property known as Blackacre, he would give his best friend the opportunity to purchase Blackacre. At a time when the best friend was serving overseas with the United States Navy, the owner decided to sell Blackacre and spoke to his best friend's mother. Before the best friend sailed, he had arranged for his mother to become a joint owner of his various bank accounts so that she would be able to pay his bills when he was gone. When she heard from the owner, the best friend's mother took the necessary funds from the best friend's account and paid the owner $20,000, the fair market value of Blackacre. The owner executed and delivered to the best friend's mother a deed in the proper form purporting to convey Blackacre to the best friend. The mother promptly and properly recorded the deed. Shortly thereafter, the mother learned that the best friend (her son) had been killed in an accident at sea one week before the delivery of the deed. The best friend's will, which has now been duly probated, leaves his entire estate to First Church. His mother is the sole heir-at-law of the best friend. There is no statute dealing with conveyances to dead persons. Title to Blackacre is now in

options.optionA: A. First Church.
options.optionB: B. the best friend's mother.
options.optionC: C. the owner free and clear.
options.optionD: D. the owner, subject to a lien to secure $20,000 to the best friend's estate.

explanation.Legal_Concept: Conveyance of property to a deceased person and its effect on title.
explanation.Fact_Analysis: The owner of Blackacre sold the property to the best friend, who had died a week before the delivery of the deed. The best friend's mother, who was a joint owner of his bank accounts, paid the owner $20,000 and received the deed, which was properly recorded. However, the best friend's death occurred before the delivery of the deed, rendering the transaction incomplete during his lifetime.
explanation.Rule_Application: A deed to a dead person is void and does not convey good title. Since the best friend died before the delivery of the deed, the transaction is considered incomplete, and the title to Blackacre was not effectively conveyed to the best friend or his estate.
explanation.Legal_Conclusion: Given that the deed was delivered after the best friend's death, the title to Blackacre remains with the owner, but the owner is subject to a lien to secure $20,000 to the best friend's estate, as the payment was made but the conveyance was not effective.

question: Blackacre was a tract of 100 acres retained by the owner after he had developed the adjoining 400 acres as a residential subdivision. The owner had effectively imposed restrictive covenants on each lot in the 400 acres. A buyer offered the owner a good price for a five-acre tract located in a corner of Blackacre far away from the existing 400-acre residential subdivision. The owner conveyed the five-acre tract to the buyer and imposed the same restrictive covenants on the five-acre tract as he had imposed on the lots in the adjoining 400 acres. The owner further covenanted that when he sold the remaining 95 acres of Blackacre he would impose the same restrictive convenants in the deed or deeds for the 95 acres. The owner's conveyance to the buyer was promptly and properly recorded. However, shortly thereafter, the owner conveyed the remaining 95 acres to a businessman for $100,000 by a deed that made no mention of any restrictive convenants in the buyer's deed. The businessman now proposes to build an industrial park which would violate such restrictive covenants if they are applicable. The recording act of the jurisdiction provides: "No conveyance or mortgage of real property shall be good against subsequent purchasers for value and without notice unless the same be recorded according to law." In an appropriate action by the buyer to enforce the restrictive covenants against the businessman's 95-acre tract, if the businessman wins it will be because

options.optionA: A. the deed imposing the restrictions was not in the chain of title for the 95 acres when the businessman bought them.
options.optionB: B. the disparity in acreage means that the covenant can only be personal to the owner.
options.optionC: C. negative reciprocal covenants are not generally recognized.
options.optionD: D. a covenant to impose restrictions is an illegal restraint on alienation.

explanation.Legal_Concept: The enforceability of restrictive covenants against subsequent purchasers of real property under a notice-type recording act.
explanation.Fact_Analysis: The owner conveyed a five-acre tract of Blackacre to the buyer with restrictive covenants and promised to include the same covenants in future sales of the remaining 95 acres. However, when the owner sold the 95 acres to the businessman, the deed did not mention the restrictive covenants. The businessman was not aware of the covenants and proposes to build an industrial park, which would violate them.
explanation.Rule_Application: Under a notice-type recording act, a subsequent purchaser is protected from earlier purchasers if they recorded their deed without notice of the earlier purchasers. In this case, a title search on the 95 acres would not have revealed any deeds including the residential subdivision restrictions. The businessman purchased the land without notice of the restrictive covenants, so they cannot be enforced against him.
explanation.Legal_Conclusion: The businessman will prevail because the deed imposing the restrictions was not in the chain of title for the 95 acres when he bought them, making him a bona fide purchaser without notice. Therefore, the correct answer is A.

question: The owner of Greenacre owned the land in fee simple. By warranty deed he conveyed Greenacre to a friend for life, "and from and after the death of my friend to my uncle, his heirs and assigns." Subsequently the uncle died, devising all of his estate to a hospital. The uncle was survived by his daughter, his sole heir-at-law. Shortly thereafter the friend died, survived by the owner, the hospital, and the daughter. Title to Greenacre now is in

options.optionA: A. the owner, because the contingent remainder never vested, and the owner's reversion was entitled to possession immediately upon the friend's death.
options.optionB: B. the hospital, because the vested remainder in the uncle was transmitted by his will.
options.optionC: C. The daughter, because she is the uncle's heir.
options.optionD: D. either the owner or the daughter, depending upon whether the destructibility of contingent remainders is recognized in the applicable jurisdiction.

explanation.Legal_Concept: Vested remainders in real property law, specifically the transmission of vested remainders through wills.
explanation.Fact_Analysis: The owner conveyed Greenacre to a friend for life, with a vested remainder to the uncle and his heirs and assigns. The uncle died, devising his estate to a hospital, and was survived by his daughter. The friend then died, leaving the question of who holds title to Greenacre.
explanation.Rule_Application: A vested remainder is a future interest that is guaranteed to become possessory, and it can be transmitted through a will. In this case, the uncle's vested remainder was transmitted to the hospital through his will, as he had the right to devise his interest.
explanation.Legal_Conclusion: Given that the uncle's vested remainder was properly transmitted to the hospital through his will, the hospital now holds title to Greenacre. Therefore, the correct answer is option B, the hospital.

question: A plaintiff and a defendant own adjoining lots in the central portion of a city. Each of their lots had an office building. The defendant decided to raze the existing building on her lot and erect a building of greater height. The defendant had received all governmental approvals required to pursue her project. There is no applicable statute or ordinance (other than those dealing with various approvals for zoning, building, etc.). After the defendant had torn down the existing building, she proceeded to excavate deeper. The defendant used shoring that met all local, state, and federal safety regulations, and the shoring was placed in accordance with those standards. The plaintiff notified the defendant that cracks were developing in the building situated on the plaintiff's lot. The defendant took the view that any subsidence suffered by the plaintiff was due to the weight of the plaintiff's building, and correctly asserted that none would have occurred had the plaintiff's soil been in its natural state. The defendant continued to excavate. The building on the plaintiff's lot did suffer extensive damage, requiring the expenditure of $750,000 to remedy the defects. Which of the following is the best comment concerning the plaintiff's action to recover damages from the defendant?

options.optionA: A. The defendant is liable, because she removed necessary support for the plaintiff's lot.
options.optionB: B. The defendant cannot be held liable simply upon proof that support was removed, but may be held liable if negligence is proved.
options.optionC: C. Once land is improved with a building, the owner cannot invoke the common-law right of lateral support.
options.optionD: D. The defendant's only obligation was to satisfy all local, state, and federal safety regulations.

explanation.Legal_Concept: The right to lateral support in property law, specifically the duty of a landowner to provide support to neighboring land and the limitations of this duty regarding structures built on the land.
explanation.Fact_Analysis: The defendant excavated her land to build a new office building, using shoring that met all safety regulations. The plaintiff's adjacent building suffered damage, allegedly due to the excavation. The defendant claimed the damage was caused by the weight of the plaintiff's building, not the excavation itself.
explanation.Rule_Application: A landowner has a right to lateral support from neighboring land, but this right only extends to the land itself, not structures built upon it. The excavating landowner is strictly liable only if the neighboring land would have collapsed without the weight of the structure. Otherwise, liability is based on negligence.
explanation.Legal_Conclusion: Given that the defendant's excavation may have caused damage to the plaintiff's building, but the right to lateral support does not extend to structures, the defendant's liability would depend on proving negligence rather than strict liability for removing support. Therefore, the correct answer is option B.

question: A farmer owned Greenacre in fee simple. The small house on Greenacre was occupied, with the farmer's oral permission, rent-free, by the farmer's son, and the college classmate of the farmer's son. The farmer's son was then 21 years old. The farmer, by properly executed instrument, conveyed Greenacre to "my beloved son, his heirs and assigns, upon the condition precedent that he earn a college degree by the time he reaches the age of 30. If, for any reason, he does not meet this condition, then Greenacre shall become the sole property of my beloved daughter, her heirs and assigns." At the time of conveyance, the farmer's son and the college classmate attended a college located several blocks from Greenacre. Neither had earned a college degree. One week after the delivery of the deed to the farmer's son, the farmer's son recorded the deed and immediately told the college classmate that he was going to begin charging the college classmate rent since "I am now your landlord." There is no applicable statute. The farmer's son and the college classmate did not reach an agreement, and the farmer's son served the appropriate notice to terminate whatever tenancy the college classmate had. The farmer's son then sought, in an appropriate action, to oust the college classmate. Who should prevail?

options.optionA: A. The farmer's son, because the conveyance created a fee simple subject to divestment in the farmer's son.
options.optionB: B. The farmer's son, because the farmer's conveyance terminated the college classmate's tenancy.
options.optionC: C. The college classmate, because the farmer's permission to occupy preceded the farmer's conveyance to the farmer's son.
options.optionD: D. The college classmate, because the college classmate is a tenant of the farmer, not of the farmer's son.

explanation.Legal_Concept: Future interests in property law, specifically the concept of a contingent remainder and its implications for present possessory interests.
explanation.Fact_Analysis: The farmer conveyed Greenacre to his son with a condition precedent that the son earn a college degree by age 30. At the time of conveyance, the son and his college classmate occupied the property rent-free with the farmer's oral permission. The son then attempted to charge the classmate rent and eventually sought to oust him.
explanation.Rule_Application: A contingent remainder is a future interest that is subject to a condition precedent. Until the condition is met, the present interest in the property remains with the grantor. In this case, the farmer's son's interest is a contingent remainder, and the present interest in Greenacre is still held by the farmer. As such, the college classmate remains a tenant of the farmer.
explanation.Legal_Conclusion: Given that the farmer's son's interest in Greenacre is a future interest contingent upon earning a college degree, and the college classmate's tenancy was created with the farmer's permission, the college classmate is still a tenant of the farmer. Therefore, the correct verdict would be in favor of the college classmate, supporting option D.

question: Twenty years ago, a testator who owned Blackacre, a one-acre tract of land, duly delivered a deed of Blackacre "to the school district so long as it is used for school purposes." The deed was promptly and properly recorded. Five years ago, the testator died leaving his son as his only heir but, by his duly probated will, he left "all my Estate to my friend Fanny." Last month, the school district closed its school on Blackacre and for valid consideration duly executed and delivered a quitclaim deed of Blackacre to a developer, who planned to use the land for commercial development. The developer has now brought an appropriate action to quiet title against the testator's son, Fanny, and the school district. The only applicable statute is a provision in the jurisdiction's probate code which provides that any property interest which is descendible is devisable. In such action, the court should find that title is now in

options.optionA: A. The developer.
options.optionB: B. The son.
options.optionC: C. Fanny.
options.optionD: D. The school district.

explanation.Legal_Concept: Future interests in real property, specifically the reversion of a fee simple determinable and the inheritance of a possibility of reverter.
explanation.Fact_Analysis: The testator originally conveyed Blackacre to the school district with the condition that it be used for school purposes. Upon the school district's cessation of this use, the interest terminated, and the land reverted to the testator. However, the testator had passed away, leaving his estate to Fanny according to his will.
explanation.Rule_Application: A fee simple determinable can be terminated by the occurrence of a specific event, in this case, the school district's cessation of using the land for school purposes. Upon termination, the interest reverts to the grantor or their heirs, unless otherwise specified. In this scenario, the testator's interest reverted, but due to his death, it passed to Fanny as per his will, in accordance with the jurisdiction's probate code allowing devisable interests.
explanation.Legal_Conclusion: Given the termination of the school district's interest and the subsequent reversion of the land to the testator, who had devised his estate to Fanny, the court should find that title is now in Fanny, supporting option C.

question: A man was the owner of Blackacre, an undeveloped city lot. The man and a neighbor executed a written document in which the man agreed to sell Blackacre to the neighbor and the neighbor agreed to buy Blackacre from the man for $100,000; the document did not provide for an earnest money down payment. The man recorded the document, as authorized by statute. The man orally gave the neighbor permission to park his car on Blackacre without charge prior to the closing. Thereafter, the neighbor frequently parked his car on Blackacre. Another property came on the market that the neighbor wanted more than Blackacre. The neighbor decided to try to escape any obligation to the man. The neighbor had been told that contracts for the purchase and sale of real property require consideration and concluded that because he had made no earnest money down payment, he could refuse to close and not be liable. The neighbor notified the man of his intention not to close and, in fact, did refuse to close on the date set for the closing. The man brought an appropriate action to compel specific performance by the neighbor. If the man wins, it will be because

options.optionA: A. the neighbor's use of Blackacre for parking constitutes part performance.
options.optionB: B. general contract rules regarding consideration apply to real estate contracts.
options.optionC: C. the doctrine of equitable conversion applies.
options.optionD: D. the document was recorded.

explanation.Legal_Concept: Consideration in contract law, specifically its application to real estate contracts and the enforceability of such contracts.
explanation.Fact_Analysis: The neighbor and the man entered into a written contract for the sale of Blackacre, with the neighbor agreeing to purchase the property for $100,000. The contract did not include an earnest money down payment, and the neighbor later attempted to escape the obligation, claiming lack of consideration due to the absence of a down payment.
explanation.Rule_Application: General contract rules regarding consideration do apply to real estate contracts. A contract is enforceable if it meets the requirements of offer, acceptance, and consideration. In this case, the written contract between the man and the neighbor, although lacking an earnest money down payment, still represents a valid agreement with consideration, as the neighbor's promise to pay $100,000 serves as sufficient consideration.
explanation.Legal_Conclusion: Given that general contract rules regarding consideration apply to real estate contracts, and the neighbor's promise to pay $100,000 constitutes valid consideration, the man's action to compel specific performance by the neighbor can proceed on this basis, supporting option B.

question: An owner owned 80 acres of land, fronting on a town road. Two years ago, the owner sold to a buyer the back 40 acres. The 40 acres sold to the buyer did not adjoin any public road. The owner's deed to the buyer expressly granted a right-of-way over a specified strip of the owner's retained 40 acres, so the buyer could reach the town road. The deed was promptly and properly recorded. Last year, the buyer conveyed the back 40 acres to a doctor. They had discussed the right-of-way over the owner's land to the road, but the buyer's deed to the doctor made no mention of it. The doctor began to use the right-of-way as the buyer had, but the owner sued to enjoin such use by the doctor. The court should decide for

options.optionA: A. the doctor, because he has an easement by implication.
options.optionB: B. the doctor, because the easement appurtenant passed to him as a result of the buyer's deed to him.
options.optionC: C. the owner, because the buyer's easement in gross was not transferable.
options.optionD: D. the owner, because the buyer's deed failed expressly to transfer the right-of-way to the doctor.

explanation.Legal_Concept: Easements appurtenant in property law, specifically the automatic transfer of such easements with the land despite not being re-identified in subsequent deeds.
explanation.Fact_Analysis: The owner sold 40 acres to the buyer with an express grant of a right-of-way over the owner's retained land for access to the town road. The buyer then sold the 40 acres to the doctor without mentioning the right-of-way in the deed. The doctor used the right-of-way as the buyer had, prompting the owner to sue for an injunction.
explanation.Rule_Application: An easement appurtenant, which benefits a specific piece of land, automatically runs with the land and does not need to be re-identified in subsequent deeds after its initial recording. This means that the easement transfers with the land regardless of whether it is mentioned in later deeds.
explanation.Legal_Conclusion: Given that the easement was an easement appurtenant and was properly recorded, it automatically passed to the doctor with the land, despite not being mentioned in the buyer's deed to the doctor. Therefore, the court should decide in favor of the doctor, supporting option B.

question: A man owns his home, Blackacre, which was mortgaged to a bank by a duly recorded purchase money mortgage. Last year, the man replaced all of Blackacre's old windows with new windows. Each new window consists of a window frame with three inserts: regular windows, storm windows, and screens. The windows are designed so that each insert can be easily inserted or removed from the window frame without tools to adjust to seasonal change and to facilitate the cleaning of the inserts. The new windows were expensive. The man purchased them on credit, signed a financing statement, and granted a security interest in the windows to a vendor, the supplier of the windows. The vendor promptly and properly filed and recorded the financing statement before the windows were installed. The man stored the old windows in the basement of Blackacre. This year, the man has suffered severe financial reverses and has defaulted on his mortgage obligation to the bank and on his obligation to the vendor. The bank brought an appropriate action to enjoin the vendor from its proposed repossession of the window inserts. In the action, the court should rule for

options.optionA: A. The bank, because its mortgage was recorded first.
options.optionB: B. The bank, because the windows and screens, no matter their characteristics, are an integral part of a house.
options.optionC: C. The vendor, because the inserts are removable.
options.optionD: D. The vendor, because the availabilty of the old windows enables the bank to return Blackacre to its original condition.

explanation.Legal_Concept: Fixtures in real property law, specifically the criteria for determining whether an item attached to a property becomes a fixture.
explanation.Fact_Analysis: The man replaced the old windows of his home, Blackacre, with new windows consisting of removable inserts. He granted a security interest in the windows to the vendor, who properly filed and recorded the financing statement before installation. The man defaulted on both his mortgage obligation to the bank and his obligation to the vendor.
explanation.Rule_Application: A court determines whether an item is a fixture by considering the degree of attachment, potential damage from removal, and general custom. Since the window inserts are easily removable without damage and there is no indication that custom dictates they stay with the property, they do not qualify as fixtures. Thus, the vendor's lien on the inserts takes precedence over the bank's mortgage claim.
explanation.Legal_Conclusion: Given that the window inserts are not considered fixtures, the vendor has the right to repossess them. Therefore, the court should rule in favor of the vendor, supporting option C.

question: The owner of Greenacre, a tract of land, mortgaged Greenacre to a bank to secure his preexisting obligation to the bank. The mortgage was promptly and properly recorded. The owner and a buyer then entered into a valid written contract for the purchase and sale of Greenacre, which provided for the transfer of "a marketable title, free of encumbrances." The contract did not expressly refer to the mortgage. Shortly after entering into the contract, the buyer found another property that much better suited her needs and decided to try to avoid her contract with the owner. When the buyer discovered the existence of the mortgage, she asserted that the title was encumbered and that she would not close. The owner responded by offering to provide for payment and discharge of the mortgage at the closing from the proceeds of the closing. The buyer refused to go forward, and the owner brought an appropriate action against her for specific performance. If the court holds for the owner in this action, it will most likely be because

options.optionA: A. the mortgage is not entitled to priority because it was granted for preexisting obligations.
options.optionB: B. the doctrine of equitable conversion supports the result.
options.optionC: C. The owner's arrangements for the payment of the mortgage fully satisfied the owner's obligation to deliver marketable title.
options.optionD: D. the existence of the mortgage was not the buyer's real reason for refusing to close.

explanation.Legal_Concept: The requirement for a seller to provide marketable title in a real estate transaction, including the impact of encumbrances such as mortgages.
explanation.Fact_Analysis: The owner of Greenacre mortgaged the property to a bank and then entered into a contract to sell it to a buyer, with the contract specifying the transfer of 'a marketable title, free of encumbrances.' The buyer discovered the mortgage and refused to close, despite the owner's offer to pay off the mortgage at closing.
explanation.Rule_Application: A seller is required to provide marketable title, which means the title must be free of encumbrances. However, if the contract does not state that 'time is of the essence,' the seller has a reasonable time after the scheduled closing date to provide marketable title. In this case, the owner's arrangement to pay off the mortgage at closing would render the title free of encumbrances, thus satisfying the requirement for marketable title.
explanation.Legal_Conclusion: Given that the owner can provide marketable title by paying off the mortgage at closing, the buyer has no valid reason to refuse to perform, and the owner is entitled to bring an action for specific performance. Therefore, the court will most likely hold for the owner, supporting option C.

question: Eight years ago, a doctor, prior to moving to a distant city, conveyed Blackacre, an isolated farm, to his son by a quitclaim deed. His son paid no consideration. The son, who was 19 years old, without formal education, and without experience in business, took possession of Blackacre and operated the farm but neglected to record his deed. Subsequently, the doctor conveyed Blackacre to a buyer by warranty deed. The buyer, a substantial land and timber promoter, paid valuable consideration for the deed to him. He was unaware of the son's possession, his quitclaim deed, or his relationship to the doctor. The buyer promptly and properly recorded his deed and began removing timber from the land. Immediately upon learning of the buyer's actions, the son recorded his deed and brought an appropriate action to enjoin the buyer from removing the timber and to quiet title. The recording act of the jurisdiction provides: "No conveyance or mortgage of real property shall be good against subsequent purchasers for value and without notice unless the same be recorded according to law." In this action, the buyer should

options.optionA: A. prevail, because a warranty deed for valuable consideration takes priority over a quitclaim deed without consideration.
options.optionB: B. prevail, because the doctor's subsequent conveyance to the buyer revoked the gift to the son.
options.optionC: C. lose, because the son's possession charged the buyer with notice.
options.optionD: D. lose, because the equities favor the son.

explanation.Legal_Concept: The application of a notice-type recording act in determining priority among purchasers of real property.
explanation.Fact_Analysis: The doctor conveyed Blackacre to his son by quitclaim deed, who took possession and operated the farm without recording the deed. The doctor then conveyed the same property to the buyer by warranty deed for valuable consideration, who promptly recorded the deed and began removing timber. The son, upon learning of the buyer's actions, recorded his deed and brought an action to enjoin the buyer and quiet title.
explanation.Rule_Application: Under a notice-type recording act, a bona fide purchaser must record their deed without notice of earlier purchasers to prevail. However, possession of the land by another party that is open and notorious may charge a subsequent purchaser with inquiry notice, requiring them to make reasonable inquiries that would yield knowledge of the earlier purchaser's rights.
explanation.Legal_Conclusion: The son's open and notorious possession of Blackacre charged the buyer with inquiry notice, preventing him from being a bona fide purchaser protected by the recording statute. Therefore, the buyer should lose, and the correct answer is C.

question: A financier was the owner of Greenacre, a large tract of land. The financier entered into a binding written contract with a buyer for the sale and purchase of Greenacre for $125,000. The contract required the financier to convey marketable record title. The buyer decided to protect his interest and promptly and properly recorded the contract. Thereafter, but before the date scheduled for the closing, an old customer obtained and properly filed a final judgment against the financier in the amount of $1 million in a personal injury suit. A statute in the jurisdiction provides: "Any judgment properly filed shall, for ten years from filing, be a lien on the real property then owned or subsequently acquired by any person against whom the judgment is rendered." The recording act of the jurisdiction authorizes recording of contracts and also provides: "No conveyance or mortgage of real property shall be good against subsequent purchasers for value and without notice unless the same be recorded according to law." There are no other relevant statutory provisions. At the closing, the buyer declined to accept the title of the financier on the ground that the customer's judgment lien encumbered the title he would receive and rendered it unmarketable. The financier brought an appropriate action against the buyer for specific performance of the contract and joined the customer as a party. In this action, the judgment should be for

options.optionA: A. the financier, because in equity a purchaser takes free of judgment liens.
options.optionB: B. the financier, because the contract had been recorded.
options.optionC: C. the buyer, because the financier cannot benefit from the buyer's action in recording the contract.
options.optionD: D. the buyer, because the statute creating judgment liens takes precedence over the recording act.

explanation.Legal_Concept: The protection afforded by a notice-type recording statute to a bona fide purchaser for value against earlier purchasers who failed to record their interests.
explanation.Fact_Analysis: The financier contracted to sell Greenacre to the buyer, who promptly recorded the contract. Before closing, a judgment lien was filed against the financier. The buyer refused to accept title due to the judgment lien, claiming it rendered the title unmarketable.
explanation.Rule_Application: Under a notice-type recording statute, a bona fide purchaser for value who records their deed without notice of earlier purchasers will prevail against those earlier purchasers. The buyer, having given value for the interest in Greenacre and recorded the contract, qualifies as a bona fide purchaser and is protected against the customer's judgment lien.
explanation.Legal_Conclusion: Since the buyer is protected by the recording statute and is receiving marketable title, the buyer has no grounds for refusing to perform. Therefore, the financier should prevail in the action for specific performance, supporting option B.

question: A plaintiff and a defendant own adjacent parcels of land. On each of their parcels was a low-rise office building. The two office buildings were of the same height. Last year the defendant decided to demolish the low-rise office building on her parcel and to erect a new high-rise office building of substantially greater height on the parcel as permitted by the zoning and building ordinances. She secured all the governmental approvals necessary to pursue her project. As the defendant's new building was in the course of construction, the plaintiff realized that the shadows it would create would place her (the plaintiff's) building in such deep shade that the rent she could charge for space in her building would be substantially reduced. The plaintiff brought an appropriate action against the defendant to enjoin the construction in order to eliminate the shadow problem and for damages. The plaintiff presented uncontroverted evidence that her evaluation as to the impact of the shadow on the fair rental value of her building was correct. There is no statute or ordinance (other than the building and zoning ordinances) that is applicable to the issues before the court. The court should

options.optionA: A. grant to the plaintiff the requested injunction.
options.optionB: B. award the plaintiff damages measured by the loss of rental value, but not an injunction.
options.optionC: C. grant judgment for the defendant, because she had secured all the necessary governmental approvals for the new building.
options.optionD: D. grant judgment for the defendant, because the plaintiff has no legal right to have sunshine continue to reach the windows of her building.

explanation.Legal_Concept: Property rights, specifically the rights of landowners to sunlight, fresh air, and view.
explanation.Fact_Analysis: The defendant is constructing a high-rise office building on her parcel of land, which will cast a shadow on the plaintiff's adjacent building, reducing its rental value. The defendant has secured all necessary governmental approvals for the project.
explanation.Rule_Application: Landowners do not possess inherent rights to sunlight, fresh air, or view. The creation of a negative easement or restrictive covenant would be required to establish such rights, but there are no facts to suggest their existence in this case.
explanation.Legal_Conclusion: Given the lack of inherent or established rights to sunlight, the plaintiff has no legal basis for a cause of action against the defendant. Therefore, the correct verdict would be to grant judgment for the defendant, supporting option D.

question: A seller owned Blackacre, improved with an aging four-story warehouse. The warehouse was built to the lot lines on all four sides. On the street side, recessed loading docks permitted semi-trailers to be backed in. After the tractors were unhooked, the trailers extended into the street and occupied most of one lane of the street. Over the years, as trailers became larger, the blocking of the street became more severe. The municipality advised the seller that the loading docks could not continue to be used because the trailers blocked the street; it gave the seller 90 days to cease and desist. During the 90 days, the seller sold and conveyed Blackacre by warranty deed for a substantial consideration to a buyer. The problem of the loading docks was not discussed in the negotiations. Upon expiration of the 90 days, the municipality required the buyer to stop using the loading docks. This action substantially reduced the value of Blackacre. The buyer brought an appropriate action against the seller seeking cancellation of the deed and return of all monies paid. Such action should be based upon a claim of

options.optionA: A. misrepresentation.
options.optionB: B. breach of the covenant of warranty.
options.optionC: C. failure of consideration.
options.optionD: D. mutual mistake.

explanation.Legal_Concept: Misrepresentation in real estate transactions, specifically the reliance on false or misleading information by the buyer.
explanation.Fact_Analysis: The seller was aware that the municipality had advised against the continued use of the loading docks due to street blockage, but failed to disclose this information to the buyer during negotiations. The buyer purchased the property without knowledge of this issue, which significantly impacted the property's value.
explanation.Rule_Application: A misrepresentation occurs when a party makes a false statement of material fact that induces the other party to enter into a contract. In this case, the seller's failure to disclose the municipality's advisory against using the loading docks constitutes a misrepresentation, as it is a material fact that would have influenced the buyer's decision to purchase the property.
explanation.Legal_Conclusion: Given that the buyer relied on the seller's misrepresentation when purchasing the property, the buyer's cause of action should be based on a claim of misrepresentation, supporting option A.

question: A little more than five years ago, a businessman completed construction of a single-family home located on Homeacre, a lot that the businessman owned. Five years ago, the businessman and a scientist entered into a valid five-year written lease of Homeacre that included the following language: "This house is rented as is, without certain necessary or useful items. The parties agree that the scientist may acquire and install such items as she wishes at her expense, and that she may remove them if she wishes at the termination of this lease." The scientist decided that the house needed, and she paid cash to have installed, standard-sized combination screen/storm windows, a freestanding refrigerator to fit a kitchen alcove built for that purpose, a built-in electric stove and oven to fit a kitchen counter opening left for that purpose, and carpeting to cover the plywood living room floor. Last month, by legal description of the land, the businessman conveyed Homeacre to a new owner for $100,000. The new owner knew of the scientist's soon-expiring tenancy, but did not examine the written lease. As the lease expiration date approached, the new owner learned that the scientist planned to vacate on schedule, and learned for the first time that she claimed and planned to remove all of the above-listed items that she had installed. The new owner promptly brought an appropriate action to enjoin the scientist from removing those items. The court should decide that the scientist may remove

options.optionA: A. none of the items.
options.optionB: B. only the refrigerator.
options.optionC: C. all items except the carpet.
options.optionD: D. all of the items.

explanation.Legal_Concept: Fixtures in property law, specifically the distinction between chattels and fixtures, and the role of agreements between landlords and tenants in determining what items may be removed at the end of a lease.
explanation.Fact_Analysis: The scientist, as a tenant, installed various items in the rented property, including windows, a refrigerator, a stove, and carpeting. The lease agreement between the scientist and the businessman explicitly stated that the scientist could install and remove such items at her expense. The lease has now expired, and the property has been sold to a new owner, who is seeking to prevent the scientist from removing the installed items.
explanation.Rule_Application: In the absence of an agreement, the determination of whether an item is a fixture (and thus cannot be removed) would depend on factors such as the degree of attachment, potential damage to the structure upon removal, and general custom. However, the lease agreement in this case explicitly allows the scientist to remove any items she installed, taking precedence over these factors.
explanation.Legal_Conclusion: Given the explicit terms of the lease agreement permitting the scientist to remove the installed items, the court should decide in favor of the scientist, allowing her to remove all of the items. This supports option D as the correct answer.

question: The owner in fee simple of Richacre, a large parcel of vacant land, executed a deed purporting to convey Richacre to her nephew. The owner told her nephew, who was then 19, about the deed and said that she would give it to him when he reached 21 and had received his undergraduate college degree. Shortly afterward the nephew searched the owner's desk, found and removed the deed, and recorded it. A month later, the nephew executed an instrument in the proper form of a warranty deed purporting to convey Richacre to his fiancee. He delivered the deed reciting that it was given in exchange for "$1 and other good and valuable consideration," and explained that to make it valid the fiancee must pay him $1. The fiancee, impressed and grateful, did so. Together, they went to the recording office and recorded the deed. The fiancee assumed the nephew had owned Richacre, and knew nothing about the nephew's dealing with the owner. Neither the owner's deed to the nephew nor the nephew's deed to his fiancee mentioned anything about any conditions. The recording act of the jurisdiction provides: "No conveyance or mortgage of real property shall be good against subsequent purchasers for value and without notice unless the same be recorded according to law." Two years passed. The nephew turned 21, then graduated from college. At the graduation party, the owner was chatting with the fiancee and for the first time learned the foregoing facts.The age of majority in the jurisdiction is 18 years old. The owner brought an appropriate action against the fiancee to quiet title to Richacre. The court will decide for

options.optionA: A. the owner, because the nephew's deed to the fiancee before the nephew satisfied the owner's conditions was void, because the fiancee had paid only nominal consideration.
options.optionB: B. the owner, because her deed to the nephew was not delivered.
options.optionC: C. the fiancee, because the nephew has satisfied the owner's oral conditions.
options.optionD: D. the fiancee, because the deed to her was recorded.

explanation.Legal_Concept: Delivery of a deed in real property law, specifically the role of intent in determining the effectiveness of a deed's delivery.
explanation.Fact_Analysis: The owner executed a deed to her nephew with the expressed intention that it would be given to him upon reaching age 21 and completing his undergraduate degree. The nephew, however, took possession of the deed before these conditions were met and recorded it, then conveyed the property to his fiancee, who paid him $1 and recorded the deed.
explanation.Rule_Application: In real property law, the delivery of a deed requires not just physical possession but also the intent to pass title. If the grantor does not intend for the title to pass at the time of physical transfer, the delivery is not effective. Here, the owner's clear intent was that the title would not pass until the nephew met specific conditions, which were not fulfilled at the time the nephew took possession of the deed.
explanation.Legal_Conclusion: Given that the owner's intent was a crucial element in the delivery of the deed and this intent was not met at the time of physical possession by the nephew, the deed was never effectively delivered to the nephew. Therefore, the correct verdict would be in favor of the owner, supporting option B.

question: Several years ago, a carpenter purchased Goldacre, financing a large part of the purchase price by a loan from a bank that was secured by a mortgage. The carpenter made the installment payments on the mortgage regularly until last year. Then the carpenter persuaded a friend to buy Goldacre, subject to the mortgage to the bank. They expressly agreed that the friend would not assume and agree to pay the carpenter's debt to the bank. The carpenter's mortgage to the bank contained a due-on-sale clause stating, "If Mortgagor transfers his/her interest without the written consent of Mortgagee first obtained, then at Mortgagee's option the entire principal balance of the debt secured by this Mortgage shall become immediately due and payable." However, without seeking the bank's consent, the carpenter conveyed Goldacre to the friend, the deed stating in pertinent part ". . . subject to a mortgage to the bank [giving details and recording data]." The friend took possession of Goldacre and made several mortgage payments, which the bank accepted. Now, however, neither the friend nor the carpenter has made the last three mortgage payments. The bank has brought an appropriate action against the friend for the amount of the delinquent payments. In this action, judgment should be for

options.optionA: A. the friend, because she did not assume and agree to pay the carpenter's mortgage debt.
options.optionB: B. the friend, because she is not in privity of estate with the bank.
options.optionC: C. the bank, because the carpenter's deed to the friend violated the due-on-sale clause.
options.optionD: D. the bank, because the friend is in privity of estate with the bank.

explanation.Legal_Concept: Mortgage law, specifically the concept of assumption of mortgage debt and the effect of a due-on-sale clause.
explanation.Fact_Analysis: The carpenter conveyed Goldacre to the friend subject to the mortgage, without the bank's consent, and the friend did not assume the mortgage debt. The friend made several mortgage payments, which the bank accepted, but later stopped making payments.
explanation.Rule_Application: A grantee who does not assume a mortgage debt is not personally liable for the debt, but the property remains subject to the mortgage. The due-on-sale clause allows the bank to demand immediate payment of the entire outstanding mortgage balance if the property is transferred without the bank's consent.
explanation.Legal_Conclusion: Since the friend did not assume the mortgage debt, she is not personally liable for the delinquent payments. The bank's action against the friend for the amount of the delinquent payments should be dismissed, supporting option A.

question: A land owner owned in fee simple Lots 1 and 2 in an urban subdivision. The lots were vacant and unproductive. They were held as a speculation that their value would increase. The land owner died and, by his duly probated will, devised the residue of his estate (of which Lots 1 and 2 were part) to his sister for life with remainder in fee simple to his niece. The land owner's executor distributed the estate under appropriate court order, and notified the sister that future real estate taxes on Lots 1 and 2 were her responsibility to pay. Except for the statutes relating to probate and those relating to real estate taxes, there is no applicable statute. The sister failed to pay the real estate taxes due for Lots 1 and 2. To prevent a tax sale of the fee simple, the niece paid the taxes and demanded that the sister reimburse her for same. When the sister refused, the niece brought an appropriate action against the sister to recover the amount paid. In such action, the niece should recover

options.optionA: A. the amount paid, because a life tenant has the duty to pay current charges.
options.optionB: B. the present value of the interest that the amount paid would earn during the sister's lifetime.
options.optionC: C. nothing, because the sister's sole possession gave the right to decide whether or not taxes should be paid.
options.optionD: D. nothing, because the sister never received any income from the lots.

explanation.Legal_Concept: Life tenant's responsibility for paying real estate taxes and the concept of permissive waste in the context of a life estate.
explanation.Fact_Analysis: The sister held a life estate in Lots 1 and 2, with the niece holding a vested remainder. The sister failed to pay real estate taxes on the lots, prompting the niece to pay the taxes and seek reimbursement. The lots were vacant and unproductive, generating no income.
explanation.Rule_Application: A life tenant has a duty not to commit permissive waste, which includes paying real estate taxes. However, this responsibility is limited to the amount of income the land generates. Since the lots were vacant and unproductive, the sister's responsibility to pay taxes was limited to $0, the amount of income she received from the property.
explanation.Legal_Conclusion: Given that the sister had no income from the property and thus no responsibility to pay taxes beyond that amount, the niece has no recourse against the sister for reimbursement of the taxes paid. Therefore, the correct verdict is that the niece should recover nothing, supporting option D.

question: A farmer and a rancher owned Greenacre, a large farm, in fee simple as tenants in common, each owning an undivided one-half interest. For five years the farmer occupied Greenacre and conducted farming operations. The farmer never accounted to the rancher for any income, but the farmer did pay all real estate taxes when the taxes were due and kept the buildings located on Greenacre insured against loss from fire, storm, and flood. The rancher lived in a distant city and was interested only in realizing a profit from the sale of the land when market conditions produced the price the rancher wanted. The farmer died intestate, survived only by the farmer's sole heir. Thereafter, the sole heir occupied Greenacre but was inexperienced in farming operations. The result was a financial disaster. The sole heir failed to pay real estate taxes for two years. The appropriate governmental authority held a tax sale to recover the taxes due. At such sale the rancher was the only bidder and obtained a conveyance from the appropriate governmental authority upon payment of an amount sufficient to discharge the amounts due for taxes, plus interest and penalties, and the costs of holding the tax sale. The amount paid was one-third of the reasonable market value of Greenacre. Thereafter, the rancher instituted an appropriate action against the sole heir to quiet title in and to recover possession of Greenacre. The sole heir asserted all defenses available to her. Except for the statutes related to real estate taxes and tax sales, there is no applicable statute. In this lawsuit, the rancher is entitled to a decree quieting title so that the rancher is the sole owner in fee simple of Greenacre

options.optionA: A. because the rancher survived the farmer.
options.optionB: B. because the farmer's sole heir defaulted in the obligations undertaken by the farmer.
options.optionC: C. unless the farmer's sole heir pays the rancher one-half of the reasonable market value of Greenacre.
options.optionD: D. unless the farmer's sole heir pays the rancher one-half of the amount the rancher paid for the tax deed.

explanation.Legal_Concept: Rights and duties of tenants in common, specifically the right to contribution for expenditures such as taxes.
explanation.Fact_Analysis: The farmer and the rancher owned Greenacre as tenants in common, each with an undivided one-half interest. The farmer paid all real estate taxes and kept the buildings insured, but never accounted to the rancher for any income. After the farmer's death, the sole heir failed to pay real estate taxes for two years, leading to a tax sale where the rancher obtained a conveyance for one-third of the reasonable market value of Greenacre.
explanation.Rule_Application: Co-tenants have a right to contribution from each other for certain expenditures, including taxes. Since the farmer's sole heir failed to pay the taxes, she is responsible for contributing to the cost of the tax deed obtained by the rancher. An accounting is not necessary in this case since there is only one expenditure to divide.
explanation.Legal_Conclusion: The rancher is entitled to a decree quieting title to Greenacre unless the farmer's sole heir pays the rancher one-half of the amount the rancher paid for the tax deed, which is the correct contribution for the tax expenditure.

question: A landowner owned Greenacre, a tract of land, in fee simple. The landowner entered into a valid written agreement with a purchaser under which the landowner agreed to sell and the purchaser agreed to buy Greenacre by installment purchase. The contract stipulated that the landowner would deliver to the purchaser, upon the payment of the last installment due, "a warranty deed sufficient to convey the fee simple." The contract contained no other provision that could be construed as referring to title. The purchaser entered into possession of Greenacre. After making 10 of the 300 installment payments obligated under the contract, the purchaser discovered that there was outstanding a valid and enforceable mortgage on Greenacre, securing the payment of debt in the amount of 25% of the purchase price the purchaser had agreed to pay. There was no evidence that the landowner had ever been late in payments due under the mortgage and there was no evidence of any danger of insolvency of the landowner. The value of Greenacre now is four times the amount on the debt secured by the mortgage. The purchaser quit possession of Greenacre and demanded that the landowner repay the amounts the purchaser had paid under the contract. After the landowner refused the demand, the purchaser brought an appropriate action against the landowner to recover damages for the landowner's alleged breach of the contract. In such action, should damages be awarded to the purchaser?

options.optionA: A. No, because the time for the landowner to deliver marketable title has not arrived.
options.optionB: B. No, because the purchaser assumed the risk by taking possession.
options.optionC: C. Yes, because in the absence of a contrary express agreement, an obligation to convey marketable title is implied.
options.optionD: D. Yes, because the risk of loss assumed by the purchaser in taking possession relates only to physical loss.

explanation.Legal_Concept: The requirement of marketable title in real estate transactions, specifically in the context of installment purchase contracts.
explanation.Fact_Analysis: The landowner and purchaser entered into a valid written installment purchase agreement for Greenacre, with the landowner to deliver a warranty deed upon the purchaser's payment of the last installment. The purchaser took possession and made 10 payments before discovering a valid mortgage on the property, then quit possession and demanded repayment.
explanation.Rule_Application: In real estate purchases, including those under installment contracts, the seller is not required to provide marketable title until the closing date or the time for delivery of the deed. The obligation to provide marketable title is implied unless the contract states otherwise, but the time for performance has not yet arrived if the payments are not complete.
explanation.Legal_Conclusion: Since the landowner's time for performance (delivery of marketable title) has not yet arrived, as there are still 290 payments to be made, damages should not be awarded to the purchaser at this time, supporting option A.

question: A landowner owned Blackacre in fee simple and conveyed Blackacre to a teacher by warranty deed. An adjoining owner asserted title to Blackacre and brought an appropriate action against the teacher to quiet title to Blackacre. The teacher demanded that the landowner defend the teacher's title under the deed's covenant of warranty, but the landowner refused. The teacher then successfully defended at her own expense. The teacher brought an appriopriate action against the landowner to recover the teacher's expenses incurred in defending against the adjoining owner's action to quiet title to Blackacre. In this action, the court should decide for

options.optionA: A. the teacher, because in effect it was the landowner's title that was challenged.
options.optionB: B. the teacher, because the landowner's deed to her included the covenant of warranty.
options.optionC: C. the landowner, because the title the landowner conveyed was not defective.
options.optionD: D. the landowner, because the adjoining owner may elect which of the landowner or the teacher to sue.

explanation.Legal_Concept: Covenant of warranty in property law, specifically the obligation of the grantor to defend the grantee's title against valid claims.
explanation.Fact_Analysis: The landowner conveyed Blackacre to the teacher by warranty deed, and the teacher was later sued by an adjoining owner in an action to quiet title. The teacher prevailed in that action and then sought reimbursement from the landowner for the expenses incurred in defending against the claim.
explanation.Rule_Application: The covenant of warranty requires the grantor to defend the grantee's title only against valid claims that result in the loss of possession or a wrongful eviction. It does not obligate the grantor to defend the grantee in all actions against title. Since the teacher successfully defended against the adjoining owner's claim and did not lose possession, the landowner's obligation under the covenant of warranty was not triggered.
explanation.Legal_Conclusion: Given that the landowner conveyed good title and did not fail to defend against any valid claims, the landowner should prevail in the action brought by the teacher to recover expenses. Therefore, the correct verdict would be for the landowner, supporting option C.

question: A landowner owned a large tract of land known as Peterhill. During the landowner's lifetime, the landowner conveyed the easterly half (East Peterhill), situated in one municipality, to a farmer, and the westerly half (West Peterhill), situated in a different municipality, to a teacher. Each of the conveyances, which were promptly and properly recorded, contained the following language: The parties agree for themselves and their heirs and assigns that the premises herein conveyed shall be used only for residential purposes; that each lot created within the premises herein conveyed shall contain not less than five acres; and that each lot shall have not more than one single-family dwelling. This agreement shall bind all successor owners of all or any portion of Peterhill and any owner of any part of Peterhill may enforce this covenant. After the landowner's death, the farmer desired to build houses on one-half acre lots in the East Peterhill tract as authorized by current applicable zoning and building codes in its municipality. The area surrounding East Peterhill in the municipality was developed as a residential community with homes built on one-half acre lots. West Peterhill was in a residential area covered by the other municipality's zoning code, which allowed residential development only on five-acre tracts of land. In an appropriate action brought by the teacher to enjoin the farmer's proposed construction on one-half acre lots, the court will find the quoted restriction to be

options.optionA: A. invalid, because of the change of circumstance in the neighborhood.
options.optionB: B. invalid, because it conflicts with the applicable zoning code.
options.optionC: C. valid, but only so long as the original grantees from the landowner own their respective tracts of Peterhill.
options.optionD: D. valid, because the provision imposed an equitable servitude.

explanation.Legal_Concept: Equitable servitudes in property law, specifically the enforceability of restrictions on land use by subsequent grantees.
explanation.Fact_Analysis: The landowner conveyed two halves of Peterhill to a farmer and a teacher, respectively, with each deed containing a restriction on land use for residential purposes, minimum lot size, and single-family dwellings. The deeds were promptly recorded, and the restriction was intended to bind and be enforceable by successor owners.
explanation.Rule_Application: For an equitable servitude to be enforceable, there must be intent for the restriction to bind subsequent grantees, notice of the servitude to those grantees, and the restriction must touch and concern the land. The language of the deeds and their recording provide the necessary intent and notice, and the restriction on land use touches and concerns the plots of land.
explanation.Legal_Conclusion: Given that the restriction meets the requirements for an equitable servitude, it is valid and enforceable by the teacher against the farmer's proposed construction on one-half acre lots, supporting option D.

question: A man owns Townacres in fee simple, and a woman owns the adjoining Greenacres in fee simple. The man has kept the lawns and trees on Townacres trimmed and neat. The woman "lets nature take its course" at Greenacres. The result on Greenacres is a tangle of underbrush, fallen trees, and standing trees that are in danger of losing limbs. Many of the trees on Greenacres are near Townacres. In the past, debris and large limbs have been blown from Greenacres onto Townacres. By local standards Greenacres is an eyesore that depresses market values of real property in the vicinity, but the condition of Greenacres violates no applicable laws or ordinances. The man demanded that the woman keep the trees near Townacres trimmed. The woman refused. The man brought an appropriate action against the woman to require her to abate what the man alleges to be a nuisance. In the lawsuit, the only issue is whether the condition of Greenacres constitutes a nuisance. The strongest argument that the man can present is that the condition of Greenacres

options.optionA: A. has an adverse impact on real estate values.
options.optionB: B. poses a danger to the occupants of Townacres.
options.optionC: C. violates community aesthetic standards.
options.optionD: D. cannot otherwise be challenged under any law or ordinance.

explanation.Legal_Concept: Private nuisance, specifically the right to quiet enjoyment of one's property and the limits of reasonable use of adjacent land.
explanation.Fact_Analysis: The woman's property, Greenacres, is overgrown with underbrush, fallen trees, and standing trees at risk of losing limbs, causing debris and large limbs to be blown onto the man's property, Townacres. The man has demanded the woman trim the trees near Townacres, but she has refused.
explanation.Rule_Application: A private nuisance claim requires an unreasonable interference with the plaintiff's use and enjoyment of their property. This interference must be more than mere aesthetics or market value considerations; it must pose a threat to safety or otherwise substantially interfere with the plaintiff's use of their land. The man must show that the woman's use of her land constitutes such an unreasonable interference.
explanation.Legal_Conclusion: The strongest argument the man can present is that the condition of Greenacres poses a danger to the occupants of Townacres, as it involves a risk to safety from falling limbs and debris. This argument supports answer B as the correct choice.

question: A landlord leased an apartment to a tenant by written lease for two years ending on the last day of a recent month. The lease provided for $700 monthly rental. The tenant occupied the apartment and paid the rent for the first 15 months of the lease term, until he moved to a new job in another city. Without consulting the landlord, the tenant moved a friend into the apartment and signed an informal writing transferring to the friend his "lease rights" for the remaining nine months of the lease. The friend made the next four monthly $700 rental payments to the landlord. For the final five months of the lease term, no rent was paid by anyone, and the friend moved out with three months left of the lease term. The landlord was on an extended trip abroad, and did not learn of the default and the vacancy until last week. The landlord sued the tenant and the friend, jointly and severally, for $3,500 for the last five months' rent. What is the likely outcome of the lawsuit?

options.optionA: A. Both the tenant and the friend are liable for the full $3,500, because the tenant is liable on privity of contract and the friend is liable on privity of estate as assignee.
options.optionB: B. The friend is liable for $1,400 on privity of estate, which lasted only until he vacated, and the tenant is liable for $2,100 on privity of contract and estate for the period after the friend vacated.
options.optionC: C. The friend is liable for $3,500 on privity of estate and the tenant is not liable, because the landlord's failure to object to the friend's payment of rent relieved the tenant of liability.
options.optionD: D. The tenant is liable for $3,500 on privity of contract and the friend is not liable, because a sublessee does not have personal liability to the original landlord.

explanation.Legal_Concept: Privity of contract and privity of estate in the context of landlord-tenant law, specifically regarding assignments and the liability of tenants and assignees.
explanation.Fact_Analysis: The tenant leased an apartment for two years and occupied it for 15 months before moving and assigning the remaining nine months to a friend without consulting the landlord. The friend made four monthly payments, but no rent was paid for the final five months, with the friend vacating three months before the lease ended.
explanation.Rule_Application: An assignment creates privity of estate between the assignee and the landlord for promises that run with the land, such as the covenant to pay rent. However, the original tenant remains liable on privity of contract unless released by the landlord. In this scenario, both the tenant and the friend are liable for the unpaid rent, as the tenant never obtained a release from the landlord and the friend's privity of estate obligated him to pay rent for the duration of his occupancy.
explanation.Legal_Conclusion: Given that the tenant retained liability on privity of contract and the friend assumed liability on privity of estate, both parties are jointly and severally liable for the $3,500 in unpaid rent, supporting option A.

question: A landowner executed an instrument in the proper form of a deed, purporting to convey his land to a friend. The landowner handed the instrument to the friend, saying, "This is yours, but please do not record it until after I am dead. Otherwise, it will cause me no end of trouble with my relatives." Two days later, the landowner asked the friend to return the deed to him because he had decided that he should devise the land to the friend by will rather than by deed. The friend said that he would destroy the deed and a day or so later falsely told the landowner that the deed had been destroyed. Six months later, the landowner, who had never executed a will, died intestate, survived by a daughter as his sole heir at law. The day after the landowner's death, the friend recorded the deed from him. As soon as the daughter discovered this recording and the friend's claim to the land, she brought an appropriate action against the friend to quiet title to the land. For whom should the court hold?

options.optionA: A. The daughter, because the death of the landowner deprived the subsequent recordation of any effect.
options.optionB: B. The daughter, because the friend was dishonest in reporting that he had destroyed the deed.
options.optionC: C. The friend, because the deed was delivered to him.
options.optionD: D. The friend, because the deed was recorded by him.

explanation.Legal_Concept: The requirements for a valid deed, specifically the necessity of delivery and the role of intent in determining delivery.
explanation.Fact_Analysis: The landowner executed a deed in the proper form, handed it to the friend with the words 'this is yours,' and requested that the friend not record it until after the landowner's death. The friend later falsely claimed to have destroyed the deed, but instead recorded it after the landowner's death.
explanation.Rule_Application: Delivery of a deed is a question of intent, and the landowner's words and actions, including handing the deed to the friend, demonstrate the necessary intent to transfer title. The request not to record the deed until later does not negate the delivery, as recording is not required for a deed to be valid.
explanation.Legal_Conclusion: Given that the deed was delivered to the friend, as evidenced by the landowner's intent and actions, the friend has a valid claim to the land. Therefore, the court should hold for the friend, supporting option C.

question: A landowner conveyed his land by quitclaim deed to his daughter and son "as joint tenants in fee simple." The language of the deed was sufficient to create a common-law joint tenancy, which is unmodified by statute. The daughter then duly executed a will devising her interest in the land to a friend. Then the son duly executed a will devising his interest in the land to a cousin. The son died; then the daughter died. Neither had ever married. The daughter's friend and the cousin survived. After both wills have been duly probated, who owns what interest in the land?

options.optionA: A. The cousin owns the land in fee simple.
options.optionB: B. The daughter's friend and the cousin own equal shares as joint tenants.
options.optionC: C. The daughter's friend and the cousin own equal shares as tenants in common.
options.optionD: D. The daughter's friend owns the land in fee simple.

explanation.Legal_Concept: Joint tenancy in property law, specifically the characteristics of joint tenancy and the effect of the right of survivorship.
explanation.Fact_Analysis: The landowner conveyed the land to his daughter and son as joint tenants in fee simple. The son died first, followed by the daughter, who had devised her interest in the land to a friend in her will. The son had also devised his interest to a cousin, but the joint tenancy's right of survivorship took precedence.
explanation.Rule_Application: A joint tenancy is characterized by the right of survivorship, which means that upon the death of one joint tenant, the remaining joint tenant(s) automatically inherit the deceased's share. This right cannot be severed by a will. Therefore, when the son died, the daughter's interest in the land swelled, and she became the sole owner in fee simple, free to devise her interest as she wished.
explanation.Legal_Conclusion: Given the right of survivorship in a joint tenancy, the daughter's interest in the land became absolute upon the son's death. She then had the right to devise her entire interest in the land to her friend through her will, making the friend the sole owner of the land in fee simple, supporting option D.

question: A creditor received a valid judgment against a debtor and promptly and properly filed the judgment in the county. Two years later, the debtor purchased land in the county and promptly and properly recorded the warranty deed to it. Subsequently, the debtor borrowed $30,000 from his aunt, signing a promissory note for that amount, which note was secured by a mortgage on the land. The mortgage was promptly and properly recorded. The aunt failed to make a title search before making the loan. The debtor made no payment to the creditor and defaulted on the mortgage loan from his aunt. A valid judicial foreclosure proceeding was held, in which the creditor, the aunt, and the debtor were named parties. A dispute arose as to which lien has priority. A statute of the jurisdiction provides: "Any judgment properly filed shall, for 10 years from filing, be a lien on the real property then owned or subsequently acquired by any person against whom the judgment is rendered." A second statute of the jurisdiction provides: "No unrecorded conveyance or mortgage of real property shall be good against subsequent purchasers for value without notice, who shall first record." Who has the prior lien?
